entry.title: Health Information & Decision Support Systems
entry.content:
Storing and exchanging medical images mobile health

Definition

â€œMobile Health (mHealth) is a sub-segment of eHealth and covers medical and public health practice supported by mobile devices. It especially includes the use of mobile communication devices for health and well-being services and information purposes as well as mobile health applications.â€

The EU infographic on mHealth

This one has a strong unilateral approach:

  • The patient collects data,
  • the doctor consumes the data

There are other perspectives as well.

Smartphones

  • Defined as having an operating systems capable of hosting medical software or it Internet capable
  • Cloud computing allowed more medical programs of higher complexity to be accessed
  • Majority of adults and 80% of physicians carry a smartphone
  • Many access medical issues on the phone and a minority have at least one medical app and/or receive text messages from a healthcare system

In particular developing countries

  • Large distance between patient and caregiver

  • Shortage of skilled people

  • More smartphones than landlines

  • So mHealth could potentially

    • increase access to healthcare
    • improve ability to diagnose and track diseases
    • Provide timelier, more actionable public health information
    • expand access to ongoing medical education and training for health workers

Taxonomy: Bringing some structure

Who creates the data?

  • Healthcare professionals
  • Patients
  • General population
  • Researchers
  • Others

Who consumes the data?

  • Healthcare professionals
  • Patients
  • General populations
  • researchers
  • Others

Apps for doctors

Education

Diagnosis

EHR on the smartphone

Clinical decision support

Apps used by patients

Category

Personal data storage

  • Apple Health App

  • Microsoft Health Vault

  • Fitness trackers

  • Diet trackers

  • Either manual data input or sensors

Communities and groups

  • Patient communities (e.g. Esperity) for information exchange
  • Fitness / workout team challenges and competitions (e.g teemo

Medication reminders

  • SMS smartphone based service
  • Standallone app or online service

Real diagnostic apps?

Patient education

Telemonitoring / home monitoring

Benefits of using apps

  • Improve Patient Engagement

    • Complexity, long lines, lack of transparency of quality, etc. discourages patient engagement. Having medical application minimizes complexity. Suppose, you are using a medication reminder application, it knows how many tablets you have taken and when you have to take your next pills.

  • Reduced Healthcare Fraud

    • An increase in the number of patient access to healthcare also results in huge medical cost and frauds. With the help of digital health care system, frauds can minimize around $60 billion annually. Mobile applications are best to trace people and transactions that ultimately minimizes frauds.

  • Instant Healthcare Service

    • Without any wait, mobile technology delivers patients a quick way to access doctorâ€™s advice or treatment information. It is useful for rural areas, where patients havenâ€™t found physicians or limited access to them.

      Moreover, it is also helpful when patients are unable to visit the physicians because of chronic diseases. It enables patients and physicians to decide whether a visit to them is essential or not. Giving better care, checking prescriptions, monitoring improvements, etc. become easy with mobile healthcare app.

Why Health Apps?

Current trend: the quantified self

  • New movement (â€œwearable HITâ€ and â€œquantified selfâ€)

  • New devices and sensors to monitor diet, exercise, sleep, heart rate, respiratory rate, oxygen level, skin temperature, hydration, etc.

  • Oriented towards patients

  • Communicate with smartphone via Bluetooth LE

  • Smart watches a new platform

  • We cannot add more and more sensors the way we are doing

Wearables: beyond sensors

Game based rehabilitation

Apps unifying diagnosis, treatment and monitoring

Clinical trials will go digital

Challenges for mHealth

Information overload and the need for multiple devices

  • Cost, business models, reimbursement schemes
  • Data storage, security and ownership
  • Interoperability issues
  • Connecting EHR
  • Regulatory: they may need FDA clearance
  • Are they evidence based? Too early to know for many. Chicken and Egg
  • Accountability: the guarantee that somebody acts upon the collected data
  • â€¦

Remark

Core ideas exist for a very long time

Barriers:

  • Technology
  • Policy
  • Legal
  • Ethical
  • Business

Technical background

Database at the server side

  • â€œA database is an organized collection of data, generally stored and accessed electronically from a computer system.â€ (Wikipedia)

  • There are different ways for organising data in a database. The most common kind of database is the Relational Database, based on the Relational Model (Codd, IBM, 1970).

  • In the Relation Model, data is structured in tables (relations), with rows and columns.

  • Every row has a unique identifier, a primary key

  • Examples: mysql, postgresql, â€¦

  • Simple python bindings available

Example relational DB structure

staff:

idfirstnamelastnameprofession
1JohnDoePhysiotherapist
2EvaMaxSurgeon

patient:

idfirstnamelastnameaddress
1MarcBrigsA street 12
2TaylorJenningsB street 77

SQL (structured query language)

SQL is a standard language for storing, manipulating and retrieving data in databases.

Examples

Get all patients with first name Marc

Get the names of all patients who visited a surgeon

Relational data model strengths

  • Data model is clear.
  • Data is comosed into atomic units.
  • Data is stored once.
  • Data integrity.
  • Complex join queries are nit that fast.

NoSQL: document databases

Strengths of noSQL

  • Intuitive data model: The documtn model directly maps onto objects in code. Easier to wrk with froma coding perspective

  • Flexible schema: The database struture is not pre-defined, so it is adaptive, flexible, â€¦

  • Distributed and Scalable: Documents are independent â€œunitsâ€, so super easy to distribute over multiple databases etc.

4 types of http requests

Example requests to the webservice

Response of by the webservice

  • Response can be anything: data, images, html, sound, â€¦
  • When response is data, it is often json

Communication between wearable and DB

Data format

  • JSON (Javascript Object Notation) is more or less standard lightweigth data-interchange format

  • Text format

  • Completely program language independent

  • Consists of 2 elements

    • Objects: an unordered set of name/value pairs {â€œfirstnameâ€:â€johnâ€, â€œlastname:doeâ€}
    • Arrays: an ordered collection of values [â€œappleâ€,â€pearâ€]

  • SEE NOSQL SLIDE

entry.title: Extends, Casting, Higher Order Functions
entry.content:
Extends, Casting, Higher Order Functions

CS61B: Data structure

Video

Implementation Inheritance: Extends

The Extends Keyword

When a class is a hyponym of an interface, we used implements.

  • Example: SLList<Blorp> implements List61B<Blorp>

If you want one class to be a hyponym of another class (instead of an interface), you use extends.

Weâ€™d like to build RotatingSLList that can perform any SLList operation as well as:

  • rotateRight(): Moves back item the front.

Example: Suppose we have [5, 9, 15, 22].

  • After rotateRight: [22, 5, 9, 15]

RotatingSLList

public class RotatingSLList<Blorp> extends SLList<Blorp>{public void rotateRight() {       Blorp oldBack = removeLast();       addFirst(oldBack);}}

Because of extends, RotatingSLList inherits all members of SLList:

  • All instance and static variables.
  • All methods.
  • All nested classes.
  • Note: but members may be private and thus inaccessible!

Constructors are not inherited.

Extends with Overriding

Another Example: VengefulSLLis

Suppose we want to build an SLList that:

  • Remembers all Items that have been destroyed by removeLast.
  • Has an additional method printLostItems(), which prints all deleted items.
public static void main(String[] args) {    VengefulSLList<Integer> vs1 = new VengefulSLList<Integer>();    vs1.addLast(1);    vs1.addLast(5);    vs1.addLast(10);    vs1.addLast(13);      /* [1, 5, 10, 13] */    vs1.removeLast();     /* 13 gets deleted. */    vs1.removeLast();     /* 10 gets deleted. */    System.out.print("The fallen are: ");    vs1.printLostItems(); /* Should print 10 and 13. */}
public class VengefulSLList<Item> extends SLList<Item> {private SLList<Item> deletedItems;public VengefulSLList() {       deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}  @Overridepublic Item removeLast() {    Item oldBack = super.removeLast();            /* calls Superclassâ€™s version of removeLast() */    deletedItems.addLast(oldBack);    return oldBack;} public void printLostItems() {    deletedItems.print();}}

Note: Java syntax disallows super.super. For a nice description of why, see this link.

Constructor Behaviour Is Slightly Weird

Constructors are not inherited. However, the rules of Java say that all constructors must start with a call to one of the super classâ€™s constructors [Link].

  • Idea: If every VengefulSLList is-an SLList, every VengefulSLList must be set up like an SLList.
    • If you didnâ€™t call SLList constructor, sentinel would be null. Very bad.
  • You can explicitly call the constructor with the keyword super (no dot).
  • If you donâ€™t explicitly call the constructor, Java will automatically do it for you.

These constructors are exactly equivalent.

public VengefulSLList() {   deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}
public VengefulSLList() {   super(); // must come first!   deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}

Calling Other Constructors

If you want to use a super constructor other than the no-argument constructor, can give parameters to super.

public VengefulSLList(Item x) {   super(x); // calls SLList(Item x)   deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}public VengefulSLList(Item x) {   deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}

Not equivalent! Code below makes implicit call to super(), not super(x).

The Object Class

As it happens, every type in Java is a descendant of the Object class.

  • VengefulSLList extends SLList.
  • SLList extends Object (implicitly)

Is-A vs. Has-A

Important Note: extends should only be used for is-a (hypernymic) relationships!

Common mistake is to use it for â€œhas-aâ€ relationships. (a.k.a. meronymic).

  • Possible to subclass SLList to build a Set, but conceptually weird, e.g. get(i) doesnâ€™t make sense, because sets are not ordered.

Encapsulation

Complexity: The Enemy

When building large programs, our enemy is complexity.

Some tools for managing complexity:

  • Hierarchical abstraction.
    • Create layers of abstraction, with clear abstraction barriers!
  • â€œDesign for changeâ€ (D. Parnas)
    • Organize program around objects.
    • Let objects decide how things are done.
    • Hide information others donâ€™t need.

Modules and Encapsulation [Shewchuk]

Module: A set of methods that work together as a whole to perform some task or set of related tasks.

A module is said to be encapsulated if its implementation is completely hidden, and it can be accessed only through a documented interface.

  • Instance variables private. Methods like resize private.
  • As weâ€™ll see: Implementation inheritance (e.g. extends) breaks encapsulation!

A Cautionary Tal

Abstraction Barriers

As the user of an ArrayDeque, you cannot observe its internals

  • Even when writing tests, you donâ€™t (usually) want to peer inside.

Java is a great language for enforcing abstraction barriers with syntax.

Implementation Inheritance Breaks Encapsulation

Suppose we have a Dog class with the two methods shown.

public void bark() {   System.out.println("bark");} public void barkMany(int N) {   for (int i = 0; i < N; i += 1) {      bark();     }}

We could just as easily have implemented methods as shown below.

  • From the outside, functionality is exactly the same, itâ€™s just a question of aesthetics.
public void bark() {   barkMany(1);} public void barkMany(int N) {   for (int i = 0; i < N; i += 1) {      System.out.println("bark");     }}

1. What would vd.barkMany(3) output?

  • As a dog, I say: bark bark bark
  • bark bark bark
  • Something else
public void bark() {   System.out.println("bark");}public void barkMany(int N) {   for (int i = 0; i < N; i += 1) {      bark();     }}
@Overridepublic void barkMany(int N) {    System.out.println("As a dog, I say: ");for (int i = 0; i < N; i += 1) {       bark(); // calls inherited bark method}}

2. What would vd.barkMany(3) output?

  • As a dog, I say: bark bark bark
  • bark bark bark
  • Something else
    • Gets caught in an infinite loop!
public void bark() {barkMany(1);}public void barkMany(int N) {   for (int i = 0; i < N; i += 1) {      System.out.println("bark");     }}
@Overridepublic void barkMany(int N) {    System.out.println("As a dog, I say: ");for (int i = 0; i < N; i += 1) {       bark(); // calls inherited bark method}}

Type Checking and Casting

Dynamic Method Selection and Type Checking Puzzle

For each line of code, determine:

  • Does that line cause a compilation error?
  • Which method does dynamic method selection use?
public static void main(String[] args) {   VengefulSLList<Integer> vsl =           new VengefulSLList<Integer>(9);   SLList<Integer> sl = vsl;   sl.addLast(50); // VengefulSLList doesnâ€™t override, uses SLListâ€™s.   sl.removeLast(); // Uses VengefulSLListâ€™s.        sl.printLostItems(); // Compilation errorvg!    VengefulSLList<Integer> vsl2 = sl; // Compilation error!}

Reminder: Dynamic Method Selection

If overridden, decide which method to call based on run-time (Also called dynamic type) type of variable.

  • slâ€™s runtime type: VengefulSLList.

Compile-Time Type Checking

Compiler allows method calls based on compile-time (Also called static type) type of variable.

  • slâ€™s runtime type: VengefulSLList.
  • But cannot call printLostItems.

Compiler also allows assignments based on compile-time types.

  • Even though slâ€™s runtime-type is VengefulSLList, cannot assign to vsl2.
  • Compiler plays it as safe as possible with type checking.

Compile-Time Types and Expressions

Expressions have compile-time types

  • An expression using the new keyword has the specified compile-time type.
SLList<Integer> sl = new VengefulSLList<Integer>();
  • Compile-time type of right hand side (RHS) expression is VengefulSLList.
  • A VengefulSLList is-an SLList, so assignment is allowed.
VengefulSLList<Integer> vsl = new SLList<Integer>(); // Compilation error!

  • Compile-time type of RHS expression is SLList.

  • An SLList is not necessarily a VengefulSLList, so compilation error results.

  • Method calls have compile-time type equal to their declared type.

public static Dog maxDog(Dog d1, Dog d2) { â€¦ }
  • Any call to maxDog will have compile-time type Dog!
/* Example */Poodle frank  = new Poodle("Frank", 5);Poodle frankJr = new Poodle("Frank Jr.", 15);Dog largerDog = maxDog(frank, frankJr);Poodle largerPoodle = maxDog(frank, frankJr); /* Compilation error! RHS has compile-time type Dog. */

Casting

Java has a special syntax for specifying the compile-time type of any expression.

  • Put desired type in parenthesis before the expression.

  • Examples:

    • Compile-time type Dog:

      maxDog(frank, frankJr);

    • Compile-time type Poodle:

      (Poodle) maxDog(frank, frankJr);

      Tells compiler to pretend it sees a particular type.

oodle frank  = new Poodle("Frank", 5);Poodle frankJr = new Poodle("Frank Jr.", 15);Dog largerDog = maxDog(frank, frankJr);Poodle largerPoodle = (Poodle) maxDog(frank, frankJr);/* Compilation OK! RHS has compile-time type Poodle. */

Casting is a powerful but dangerous tool.

  • Tells Java to treat an expression as having a different compile-time type.
  • In example below, effectively tells the compiler to ignore its type checking duties.
  • Does not actually change anything: sunglasses donâ€™t make the world dark.
Poodle frank  = new Poodle("Frank", 5);Malamute frankSr = new Malamute("Frank Sr.", 100);Poodle largerPoodle = (Poodle) maxDog(frank, frankSr);

If we run the code above, we get a ClassCastException at runtime.

  • So much for .class files being verifiably type checked...

Dynamic Method Selection and Casting Puzzle

Is it Overriding? Overloading?

public class Bird {public void gulgate(Bird b) {    System.out.println("BiGulBi"); }}
public class Falcon extends Bird {public void gulgate(Falcon f) {    System.out.println("FaGulFa");}}
Bird bird = new Falcon();Falcon falcon = (Falcon) bird;bird.gulgate(falcon);falcon.gulgate(falcon);

What gets printed?

  • BiGulBi BiGulBi
  • BiGulBi FaGulFa
  • FaGulFa BiGulBi
  • FaGulFa FaGulFa

Casting causes no change to the bird variable, nor to the object the bird variable points at!

Remember: The compiler chooses the most specific matching method signature from the static type of the invoking class.

  • Falcon is overloading the gulgate method, not overriding.
  • Compiler basically thinks â€œdoes Bird class have a gulgate method? Yes! Iâ€™ll use thatâ€. Since there is no overriding, no dynamic method selection occurs.

Higher Order Functions in Java

Higher Order Function: A function that treats another function as data.

  • e.g. takes a function as input.

Example in Python:

def tenX(x):return 10*x def do_twice(f, x):return f(f(x)) print(do_twice(tenX, 2))>>> 200

Higher Order Functions in Java 7

Old School (Java 7 and earlier)

  • Fundamental issue: Memory boxes (variables) cannot contain pointers to functions.

Can use an interface instead. Letâ€™s try it out.

Java code below is equivalent to given python code.

public interface IntUnaryFunction {int apply(int x);}
public class TenX implements IntUnaryFunction {public int apply(int x) {   return 10 * x;}}
public class HoFDemo {public static int do_twice(IntUnaryFunction f, int x) {   return f.apply(f.apply(x));}public static void main(String[] args) {   System.out.println(do_twice(new TenX(), 2));}}

Higher Order Functions in Java 8 or Later

In Java 8, new types were introduced: now can can hold references to methods.

  • Why? The old way is still widely used, e.g. Comparators (see next lecture).
public class Java8HoFDemo {    public static int tenX(int x) {       return 10*x;}    public static int doTwice(Function<Integer, Integer> f, int x) {     return f.apply(f.apply(x));}    public static void main(String[] args) {    int result = doTwice(Java8HoFDemo::tenX, 2);     System.out.println(result);}}

Implementation Inheritance Cheatsheet

VengefulSLList extends SLList means a VenglefulSLList is-an SLList. Inherits all members!

  • Variables, methods, nested classes.
  • Not constructors.
  • Subclass constructor must invoke superclass constructor first.
  • Use super to invoke overridden superclass methods and constructors.

Invocation of overridden methods follows two simple rules:

  • Compiler plays it safe and only lets us do things allowed by static type.
  • For overridden methods the actual method invoked is based on dynamic type of invoking expression, e.g. Dog.maxDog(d1, d2).bark();
  • Can use casting to overrule compiler type checking.

Extra Problem Just For Fun

Showdog dogC = new ShowDog("Franklin", "Malamute", 180, 6);Showdog dogD = new ShowDog("Gargamel", "Corgi", 44, 12);Dog.maxDog(dogC, dogD);Dog md = Dog.maxDog(dogC, dogD);ShowDog msd = Dog.maxDog(dogC, dogD);Object o = new Dog("Hammy", "Beagle", 15);Dog d = new Dog("Ammo", "Labrador", 54);Object stuff[] = new Object[5];stuff[0] = o;stuff[1] = d;stuff[2] = null;

1. What is the static type of Dog.maxDog(dogC, dog D)?

2. Which (if any), will compile:

3. How many memory boxes are there in the code below? What are the dynamic types of their contents?

Overview

The Interface and implements. Up to now we have been writing classes and interfaces, and you have may noticed places where we have had to write redundant code for different (but similar!) classes. This leads us to the idea of inheritance, the idea that a class/object does not need to redefine all its methods, and instead can use properties of a parent class. Lets first note some differences between inheritence of a parent class and interfaces (Note that a class can do both, even at the same time! Here is the syntax for implemeting an interface:

SLList<Blorp> implements List61B<Blorp>

Similarly, the way for a class to extend the qualities of another class the syntax is as follows:

Class_Name extends Class_Name

Usage of Inheritance. Say we wanted to make a special type of SLList called RotatingSLList. RotatingSLList should be able to do everyhthing that SLList can; however, it should also be able to rotate to the right. How can we do this? Well this is just an application of Inheritance! Doing the following will allow for RotatingSLList to have all the qualities of SLList as well as its own method rotateRight.

public class RotatingSLList<Blorp> extends SLList<Blorp>{  public void rotateRight() {...}}

What is Inherited? We have a powerful tool in Inheritance now; however, we will define a few rules. For now, we will say that we can inherit:

  • instance and static variables
  • all methods
  • all nested classes This changes a little bit with the introduction of private variables but donâ€™t worry about that right now. The one item that is not inherited is a classâ€™s constructor.

The Special Case of the Constructor? Even though constructorâ€™s are not inherited, we still use them. We can call the constructor explicitly by using the keyword super(). At the start of every constructor, there is already an implicit call to its super class`s constructor. As a result

public VengefulSLList() {  deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}

is equivalent to

public VengefulSLList() {  super();  deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();}

However, constructor`s with arguments are not implicitly called. This means that.

public VengefulSLList() {    super(x);    deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();  }

is not equivalent to

public VengefulSLList() {    deletedItems = new SLList<Item>();  }

This is because only the empty argument super() is called.

Is A. When a class inherits from another, we know that it must have all the qualities of it. This means that VengefulSLList is a SLList because it has all the qualities of an SLList- it just has a few additional ones too.

Every single class is a descendent on the Object class, meaning they are all Objects.

Abstraction As youâ€™ll learn later in this class, programs can get a tad confusing when they are really large. A way to make programs easier to handle is to use abstraction. Basically abstraction is hiding components of programs that people do not need to see. The user of the hidden methods should be able to use them without knowing how they work.

An intuitive way to realize the motivation of abstraction is to look at yourself. You are a human (unless some robot is looking at this in which case I am sorry for offending you) and humans can eat food and convert it to energy. You do not need to know how you convert food to energy you just know that it works. In this case think of your conversion of food to energy as a method and the input is food and the output is energy.

Casting In Java, every object has a static type (defined at compile-time) and a dynamic type (defined at run-time). Our code may rely on the fact that some variable may be a more specific type than the static type. For example if we had the below definitions:

Poodle frank  = new Poodle("Frank", 5);Poodle frankJr = new Poodle("Frank Jr.", 15);

This statement would be valid

Dog largerDog = maxDog(frank, frankJr);

But this one would not be

Poodle largerPoodle = maxDog(frank, frankJr);

The reason the former statement is valid is because the compilers knows for a fact that anything that is returned from a maxDog function call is a Dog. However, in the latter case, the compiler does not know for a fact that the return value of maxDog would result in a Poodle even though both Dog arguments are Poodles.

Instead of being happy with just having a generic Dog, we can be a bit risky and use a technique called casting. Casting allows us to force the static type of a variable, basically tricking the compiler into letting us force the static type of am expression. To make largerPoodle into a static type Poodle we will use the following:

Poodle largerPoodle = (Poodle) maxDog(frank, frankJr);

Note that we are not changing the actual dynamic type of maxDog- we are just telling the compiler what is coming out of maxDog will be a Poodle. This means that any reference to largerPoodle will have a static type of Poodle associated with it.

Casting, while powerful is also quite dangerous. You need to ensure that what you are casting to can and will actually happen. There are a few rules that can be used:

  • You can always cast up (to a more generic version of a class) without fear of ruining anything because we know the more specific version is a version of the generic class. For example you can always cast a Poodle to a Dog because all Poodles are Dogâ€™s.
  • You can also cast down (to a more specific version of a class) with caution as you need to make sure that, during runtime, nothing is passed in that violates your cast. For example, sometimes Dogâ€™s are Poodleâ€™s but not always.
  • Finally, you cannot ever cast to a class that is neither above or below the class being cast. For an example, you cannot cast a Dog to a Monkey because a Monkey is not in the direct lineage of a Dog - it is a child of Animal so a bit more distant. You can think of this as â€œside castingâ€ and it will result in a compile time error since the compiler knows this cast cannot possibly work.

entry.title: Structured Query Language
entry.content:
Structured Query Language

Video

Structured Query Language (SQL) 00:39

  • Declarative query language to create database schemas, insert, update, delete and query information based on a data definition and data manipulation language
  • Data definition language (DDL)
    • definition of database structure (relation schemas)
    • data access control
  • Data manipulation language (DML)
    • query language to create, read, update and delete tuples (CRUD operations)
  • The SQL language further deals with the following issues
    • transaction control
    • integrity constraints (DDL)
    • authorisation (DDL)
    • views (DDL)
    • embedded SQL and dynamic SQL

History of SQL 2:58

  • SEQUEL (70's)
    • structured english query language
    • developed by Raymond F. Boyce and Donald D. Chamberlin
    • access data stored in IBM's System R relational database
  • SQL-86
    • first ANSI standard version
  • SQL-89 / SQL 1
  • SQL-92 / SQL 2
    • we will mainly discuss features of the SQL-92 standard
  • SQL:1999 / SQL 3
    • recursive queries, triggers, object-oriented features, ...
  • SQL:2003
    • window functions, XML-related features, ...
  • SQL:2006
    • XML Query Language (XQuery) support, ...
  • SQL:2008
  • SQL:2011
    • improved support for temporal databases
  • â€¦

SQL "Standard" 4:06

  • Each specific SQL implementation by a database vendor is called a dialect
  • The vendors implement parts of the SQL standard (e.g. most implement SQL-92) but add their vendor-specific extensions
  • Most relational database vendors conform to a set of Core SQL features but portability might still be limited due to missing or additional features

Data Definition Language (DDL) 4:56

The data definition language (DDL) is used to specify the relation schemas as well as other information about the relations

  • relation schemas
  • attribute domain types
  • integrity constraints (e.g. foreign keys)
  • relation indexes
  • access information
  • physical storage structure of relations

Database Creation 5:26

  • The concrete process of creating a new database might differ for different relational database products

  • According to the SQL standard, an SQL environment contains one or more catalogues

  • Each catalogue manages various metadata

    • set of schemas consisting of
      • relations/tables
      • views
      • assertions
      • indexes
    • SET SCHEMA name can be used to set the current schema
    • users and user groups

  • The creation of catalogues is not covered by the SQL standard and therefore implementation specific

  • Schemas can be created and deleted via the CREATE and DROP statements

  • The default parameter of the DROP SCHEMA statement is RESTRICT
    • only empty schema can be deleted
  • If CASCADE is specified, all objects associated with the schema will be dropped

Extended Backus-Naur Form (EBNF) 8:08

Notation to describe computer programming languages (context-free grammars)

  • developed by Niklaus Wirth
  • We use the EBNF to describe different SQL concepts
NotationMeaning
=Definition
,Sequence
;Termination
|Choice
[...]Option
{...}Repetition
(...)Grouping
"..."Terminal String

Customer (customerID, name, street, postcode, city)

CD (cdID, name, duration, price, year)

Order (orderId, customerID, cdID, date, amount, status)

Supplier (supplierID, name, postcode, city)

Table Definition Example 10:53

Table Constraints 15:37

  • We can have only one PRIMARY KEY constraint but multiple UNIQUE constraints
    • if no primary key is defined, duplicates are allowed (bag)
  • Referential integrity
    • a foreign key always has to have a matching value in the referenced table (or it can be null)
    • different referential actions can be defined for update (ON UPDATE) and delete (ON DELETE) operations on the referenced candidate key
      • CASCADE: propagate operations to the foreign keys which might lead to further cascaded operations
      • SET DEFAULT: set the foreign keys to their default value
      • SET NULL: set the foreign keys to NULL
      • NO ACTION: the operation on the candidate key will be rejected (default)

Table Definition

SQL Datatypes 20:24

Character data

  • fixed-length or variable-length sequence of characters
  • optional multibyte character sets (e.g. for Japanese etc.)

Large character data or binary data

  • often a so-called locator is returned to access a large object in pieces instead of loading the entire object into memory

Numeric data

The DECIMAL datatype is sometimes used as a synonym for the NUMERIC datatype

Datetime data

Format of the datetime values:

  • date: YYYY-MM-DD
  • time: hh:mm:ss.p Â± hh:mm
  • timestamp: YYYY-MM-DD hh:mm:ss.p Â± hh:mm

Boolean

  • the domain of boolean values consist of the two truth values TRUE and FALSE
  • a thrid UNKNOWN truth value is used to represent NULL values
  • introduced in SQL:1999

Bit data

  • fixed or varying sequence of binary digits (0 or 1)

For further details about the presented datatypes as well as information about vendor-specific datatypes one has to consult the specific database manuals

Data Manipulation 25:32

After a table has been created, we can use the INSERT command to add tuples

  • unspecified attribute values are set to the default value or NULL
  • attribute order can be changed via optional column names
  • "bulk loader" utilities to insert large amounts of tuples

Example

Expressions

  • The DELETE statement can be used to delete tuples

  • Tuples can be updated via the UPDATE statement

    • Example

  • The DROP TABLE statement can be used to delete a relation from the database

  • A relation schema can be modified via the ALTER TABLE command

    • existing tuples are assigned a NULL value for the new attribute

    • Example

    ## Basic SQL Query Structure 34:53

A basic SQL query consists of a SELECT, a FROM and a WHERE clause

  • SELECT
    • specifies the columns to appear in the result (projection in relational algebra)
  • FROM
    • specifies the relations to be used (cartesian product in relational algebra)
  • WHERE
    • filters the tuples (selection in relational algebra)
    • join conditions are explicitly specified in the WHERE clause
  • GROUP BY
    • groups rows with the same column values
    • the HAVING construct can be used to further filter the groups
  • ORDER BY
    • defines the order of the resulting tuples

In general, the SELECT FROM WHERE parts are evaluated as follows

  1. generate a cartesian product of the relations listed in the FROM clause
  2. apply the predicates specified in the WHERE clause on the result of the first step
  3. for each tuple in the result of the second step output the attributes (or results of expressions) specified in the SELECT clause

The evaluation is normally optimised by a query optimiser

The order of clauses in an SQL query cannot be changed

Note that the SELECT is equivalent to a relational algebra projection

In contrast to the relational algebra, SQL does not eliminate duplicates automatically

  • the automatic elimination of duplicates would be time consuming
  • user has to eliminate duplicates explicitly via DISTINCT keyword

SELECT Clause 41:06

customerIDnamestreetpostcodecity

A '*' can be used in the SELECT clause as a shortcut to get all tuple attributes

  • The DISTINCT keyword can be used to eliminate duplicates

Computed Attributes and Rename 42:57

namenewprice
Falling into Place26.85

Chromatic24.75
  • Computations can be performed in the SELECT clause
    • multiple numeric attributes can be used in a computation
  • The rename operation (AS) is used to rename relations as well as attributes
    • computed columns have no name by default
    • also used when multiple relations have the same attribute names

WHERE Clause 44:11

In the WHERE clause we can use five basic predicates (search conditions)

  • comparison
    • compare two expressions
  • range
    • check whether the value is within a specified range of values (BETWEEN)
  • set membership
    • check whether the value is equal to a value of a given set (IN)
  • pattern matching
    • test whether the expression matches a specifies string pattern (LIKE)
  • check for NULL values
    • check whether the expression is a NULL value (IS NULL)
Max Frisch8001
Max Frisch8092
nameprice
Carcassonne15.50
Chromatic16.50
  • Check for set membership with the IN construct
customerIDnamestreetpostcodecity
1Max FrischBahnhofstrasse 78001Zurich
2Eddy MerckxPleinlaan 251050Brussels
53Albert EinsteinBergstrasse 188037Zurich
8Max FrischETH Zentrum8092Zurich

Pattern Matching 45:54

  • Strings are enclosed in single quotes
    • use a double single quote for escaping
  • The LIKE operator is used for pattern matching
    • the underscore ( _ ) is a placeholder for a single character
    • the percent sign ( % ) is a placeholder for any substring
    • e.g. LIKE '_e%'
name
Albert Einstein

Null Values 47:04

  • Missing (unknown) info is represented by NULL values
    • result of any comparison involving a NULL value is Unknown
    • three-valued logic (3VL) based on True, False and Unknown

  • The NULL keyword can also be used in predicates to check for null values
cdIDnamedurationpriceyear
1Falling into Place200717.902007
2Carcassonne315615.501993
3Chromatic301216.501993
  • Note that a check for NULL is not the same as a check for the empty String ''

FROM Clause 51:35

  • The FROM clause creates a cartesian product of multiple relations and can be used to specify join operations
  • In a previous lecture we have seen the following relational algebra expression
    • "list the name and street of customers whose order is still open"
    • Ï€name, street(Ïƒstatus="open"(order â‹ˆ customer))
    • the same can be achieved in SQL by explicitly specifying the matching attributes
namestreet
Albert EinsteinBergstrasse 18

Inner and Outer Joins 53:53

Note that there exist SQL extensions to perform join operations between two relations R and S in the FROM clause

  • Inner Joins
  • Outer Joins

Correlation Variable 55:22

  • A correlation variable can be used as an alias for a table
  • Example
    • "Find all pairs of CDs that were produced in the same year"
name1name2
CarcassonneChromatic

Sorting 58:35

The ORDER BY clause can be used to arrange the result tuples in acending (ASC) or descending (DESC) order

  • multiple sort keys can be specified; highest priority first
  • tuples with NULL values are either before or after non-NULL tuples
Eddy MerckxPleinlaan 25Brussels

Set Operations 59:01

The UNION, INTERSECT and EXCEPT operations correspond to the âˆª, âˆ© and - relational algebra operations

  • the relations have to be compatible (same attributes)
  • these operations remove duplicates by default
    • the ALL keyword has to be used to retain duplicates
name
Max Frisch

Aggregate Functions and Grouping 1:01:11

In SQL there are five aggregate functions (MIN, MAX, AVG, SUM and COUNT) that take a set or multiset of values as input and return a single value

Example:

  • "Find the number of customers in each city"
citynumber
Zurich3
Brussels1
Paris1
  • Aggregate functions (except COUNT(*)) ignore NULL values in the input set
    • input set might be empty in which case NULL is returned

Subqueries 1:04:06

  • A subquery is a SELECT FROM WHERE expression that is nested within another query
    • e.g. via check for set membership (IN or NOT IN)
  • Example
    • "Find all the suppliers who are no customers"
name
Mario Botta

Nested Subqueries 1:04:45

Example: "Find all CDs with a price smaller than average"

cdIDnamedurationpriceyear
2Carcassonne315615.501993
3Chromatic301216.501993

Set Comparison 1:06:22

For nested queries with conditions like "greater than at least one" we can use these set comparison operators

  • > SOME, >= SOME, < SOME, <= SOME, = SOME, <> SOME as well as the same combination with AL

Example: "Find the customers with a postcode greater than all supplier postcodes"

namepostcode
Claude Debussy75008
Max Frisch8092

Existence Test 1:07:37

The EXISTS operator can be used to check if a tuple exists in a subquery

  • Example: "Find the customers who are also suppliers"
name
Max Frisch

Derived Relations 1:08:15

A subquery expression can also be used in the FROM clause

  • in this case, a name has to be given to the relation

Example: "Find the number of customers in the city with the most customers"

Basic SQL Query Structure

The query statement can be used to retrieve information from one or multiple database tables

  • can perform the relational algebra's selection, projection and join operation in a single SELECT FROM WHERE command

WITH Clause 1:09:53

The WITH clause can be used to improve the readability by introducing temporary new relations

  • introduced only in SQL:1999 and not supported by all databases

Example: "Find all customers who bought one of the most expensive CDs"

name
Albert Einstein

Views 1:11:42

New virtual relations (views) can be defined on top of an existing logical model

  • simplify queries
  • provide access to only parts of the logical model (security)
  • computed by executing the query whenever the view is used

Some DBMS allow views to be stored (materialised views)

  • materialised views have to be updated when its relations change (view maintenance)

Example:

  • Note that a view can be used like any other relation
  • Views are useful for queries but they present a serious problem for UPDATE, INSERT and DELETE operations
    • modifications are difficult to be propagated to the actual relations
    • modifications on views are therefore generally not permitted

Transactions 1:22:34

  • A transaction consists of a sequence of query and/or update statements
    • atomic set of statements
  • A transaction explicitly starts when an SQL statement is executed and is ended by
    • a COMMIT statement
    • a ROLLBACK statement
  • In many SQL implementations each SQL statement is a transaction on its own (automatic commit)
    • this default behaviour can be disabled
    • SQL:1999 introduced BEGIN ATOMIC ... END blocks
  • Transactions will be discussed in detail later

entry.title: Finite Automata and their Languages
entry.content:
Finite Automata and their Languages

Introduction

  • Recognition is a fundamental computational problem for formal languages:
    • For string x and language L: does x belong to L?
  • The problem is solved by designing an automaton for L:
    • Complete computational model of the recognition process for L
  • The complexity of language classes can be studied by comparing the complexity of the corresponding classes of automata

Automata: The General Idea

  • An automaton is a specification for a symbol processing machine
  • Different from a real machine:
    • It is a specification
    • Operates on symbols
    • Relatively simple internal structure to study
  • An automaton can recognize whether a string is part of the language that is specifies

States

  • As an automaton executes:
    • Changes in its internal condition
    • Each possible internal condition is called a state
  • The states form the internal memory of the automaton
  • A Finite Automaton (FA) has a finite number of states and no other form of memory

Diagrams and recognition

State transition diagram

  • A State Transition Diagram graphically represents an automaton
  • It consists of:
    • States (encircled letters)
    • Start State (state with short arrow pointing to it)
    • Transitions (arrows from one state to another)
    • Accepting State (double encircled letters)
  • A string is accepted if it leads from the start state to an accepting state
  • The set of strings that an automaton accepts is called its language

Example

  • Start State: A
  • Accepting State: C
  • Transitions: A â†’ C, A â†’ B, B â†’ C

  • The language of this automaton is {a, bc}
  • E.g. aa passes through an accepting state, but is not accepted itself

Skip/trap sate

  • State D is a sink state (no way out)
  • A non-accepting sink state is called a trap state
  • Trap states clutter diagrams and are usually not drawn

Trap-free diagram

  • Equivalent, trap-free diagram
  • Missing transitions are assumed to lead to the trap state

Proof: L = {A, BC}

  • Prove that: L = {a, bc}
    • Prove: {a, bc} âŠ† L
    • Prove: L âŠ† {a, bc}

Proof: {A, BC} âŠ† L

  • Prove that: {a, bc} âŠ† L
  • Prove that the strings a and bc are part of the language specified by the automaton
  • Recognize both strings using the automaton

Proof: L âŠ† {A, BC}

Prove that: L âŠ† {a, bc}

  • x âˆˆ L â†’ x âˆˆ {a, bc}
  • x âˆ‰ {a, bc} â†’ x âˆ‰ L (contrapositive)
  • Prove that no other strings than a and bc are part of the language described by the automaton
    • String has to start by a or b, otherwise it is not accepted
    • If string starts by a, then it cannot be followed by any other symbol, as there is no transition from state C
    • If string starts by b, then it cannot be followed by a or b, if the second symbol is a c, then there cannot be a next symbol

Exercise 1

1. Draw a transition diagram without a trap state for an FA that recognizes the language L, where: L = {x|x âˆˆ {a, b}âˆ— and there is no odd block of bs in x}

2. Draw a transition diagram without a trap state for an FA that recognizes the language L over Î£ = {a, b, c, d} that contains all and only the strings over x such that:

  1. x begins with dc
  2. x ends in a substring cd (where the câ€™s in 1 and 2 are not the same)
  3. between these substrings there is no other occurrence of cd

Cf. comments in java between / and /

Solution

  • NOT a solution!
  • Occurrence of c must lead to the end of the string here!

  • Problem solved

3. Draw a state transition diagram for each of the languages specified. Omit trap states. Be sure that each diagram, besides accepting all the strings described, also excludes all others. The languages are the sets of all strings over {a,b,c} that:

  1. start with c.
  2. end in c.
  3. contain exactly one c.
  4. contain at least one c.
  5. contain at least one c and are of length exactly 2.
  6. are of length at most 2.
  7. are of length at most n for some integer n.

Solution

Formal notation for finite automata

Definition: Finite Automata

A finite automaton M is a quintuple (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A), where:

  • Q is a finite set of states
  • Î£ is a finite set of symbols
  • q0 âˆˆ Q, where q0 is the start state
  • A âŠ† Q, where A is the set of accepting states
  • Î´ : Q Ã— Î£ â†’ Q

Î´ is the transition function, with as domain the set of all ordered pairs (q, Ïƒ)

Example

Specify a machine M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A) for the language {a} by giving the values of Q, Î£, Î´ and A*, and also by drawing the corresponding diagram.

Q = {q0},

Î£ = {a},

A = {q0} ,

Î´(q0, A) = q0.

  • Draw the transition diagram
  • Justify the claim that M accepts all strings over the alphabet beginning with a and no others

Solution

  • f the first symbol is a, the automaton will always stay in the accepting state q1, no matter what other symbols follow
  • If the first symbol is d, it will be trapped in the state q2, no matter what other symbols follow

Exercise 2

Draw a state transition diagram for comments in C or C++. These are the strings that

  1. begin with /*,
  2. end in */ without overlap (so /*/ is excluded), and
  3. have no other occurrence of */.

Solution

Exercise 3

Formally specify a machine M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A) by giving the values of Q, Î£, q0, Î´ and A corresponding to

  1. the state transition diagram in Example 9.4, as shown, with 6 being a partial function.
  2. the same diagram except that you first add the trap state and the transitions associated with it. Note that 6 is now a total function.

Solution

  1. M = ({A, B}, {a, b}, A, Î´, {A})

  2. M = ({A, B, C}, {a, b}, A, Î´, {A})

Exercise 4

Let M = ({q0, q1, q2, q3}, {a}, q0, Î´, {q, q3}), where Î´ is specified by the following table.

  1. Draw the state transition diagram for this finite automaton.
  2. Very briefly describe the language L(M) in English.
  3. Using a quintuple, give a complete specification of a two-state automaton that accepts L(M).

Solution

  • The language consists of strings over the alphabet Î£ = {a}, that have an odd number of symbols
  • M = ({q0, q1}, {a}, q0, Î´, {q1})

Closure of the transition function

Definition:

  • M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A)

  • Î´âˆ— : Q Ã— Î£âˆ— â†’ Q

  • For any q âˆˆ Q, Î´âˆ— (q,Î›) = q

  • For any q âˆˆ Q, any Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£ and any x âˆˆ Î£âˆ— , Î´âˆ— (q, xÏƒ) = Î´(Î´âˆ— (q, x), Ïƒ)

    Note that the definition is recursive!

Theorem : Î´âˆ— for strings of length 1

  • Theorem: âˆ€q âˆˆ Q : âˆ€Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£ for which |Ïƒ| = 1 : Î´âˆ— (q, Ïƒ) = Î´(q, Ïƒ)

  • Proof:

    • Î´âˆ— (q, Ïƒ) = Î´âˆ— (q,Î›Ïƒ) Substitution

      â€‹ = Î´(Î´âˆ— (q,Î›), Ïƒ) Closure of Î´ (recursive case)

      â€‹ = Î´(q, Ïƒ) Closure of Î´ (base case)

Example

  • M = ({q0, q1, q2}, {a, d}, q0, Î´, {q1})

  • Proof that ad takes M to state q1

  • Proof:

    • Î´âˆ—(q0, ad) = Î´(Î´âˆ—(q0, a), d) Closure of Î´ (recursive case)

      â€‹ = Î´(Î´(q0, a), d) Theorem Î´âˆ— for strings of length 1

      â€‹ = Î´(q1, d) Evaluation

      â€‹ = q1 Evaluation

Exercise 5

Specify just the the transition function of a finite automaton for the second state transition diagram in Exercise 1.3. Omit the trap state. Label the states q0, q1, q2, q3 and q4.

Solution

Exercise 6

For your automaton in Exercise 5, give the values of Î´âˆ— for the arguments shown here:

  1. Î´âˆ—(q1, dcba)
  2. Î´âˆ—(q0, dcd)
  3. Î´âˆ—(q0, dccccd)

Solution

Recognized language

Definition: Language recognized by a FA

  • The language L(M) recognized by a finite automaton M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A) is the set of all strings x âˆˆ Î£âˆ— such that Î´âˆ— (q0, x) âˆˆ A
  • M accepts the strings of L(M)
  • M rejects the strings of Î£âˆ— Â L(M)

Algorithm: Recognizing the language of a FA

  • q: current state, x: input string, Ïƒ: current symbol, â‡: assignment
  • dequeue: remove an element from the front and return it
  • Algorithm returns TRUE (accept) or FALSE (reject)

Nondeterministic finite automata

General idea

In contrast to Deterministic Finite Automata (DFAs), Nondeterministic Finite Automata (NFAs) can have more than 1 transition for a single symbol out of a state

Example

For the finite language L = {ab, ac}, draw an NFA state transition diagram, giving each string of L its own states and transitions, sharing only the start state

Characteristics

  • An NFA makes a series of choices that lead to acceptance of the input whenever this is possible
  • Codomain of Î´:
    • DFA: Q : Set of states
    • DFA: 2Q : Powerset (all subsets) of the set of states

Definition: nondeterministic FA

  • M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A)
  • Î´ : Q Ã— Î£ â†’ 2Q

Definition: nondeterministic generalized transition function

  • M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A)

  • Î´ : Q Ã— Î£ â†’ 2Q

  • For any q âˆˆ Q, Î´âˆ— (q,Î›) = {q}

  • For any q âˆˆ Q, any Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£, and any x âˆˆ Î£âˆ— \[Î´^âˆ—(q,xÏƒ)=âˆª_{pâˆˆÎ´^âˆ—(q,x)}Î´(p, Ïƒ)\]

Definition: Language recognized by a NFA

  • The language L(M) recognized by a NFA M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A) is the set of all strings x âˆˆ Î£âˆ— such that Î´âˆ—(q0, x) âˆ© A â‰  âˆ…
  • The NFA accepts the strings of L(M)
  • The NFA rejects the strings of Î£âˆ— Â L(M)

Example

Consider the language L = {x | x âˆˆ {a, b}} and x ends with ab}. This language contains, for example, the string bbab, but not abba. Draw a state transition diagram for both a DFA and an NFA to recognize L*. Make each as simple as possible.

Solution

Removing nondeterminism

Simulating NFAs

  • How to turn NFAs into real computational devices?

    • backtracking
    • parallel computing
    • simulate it using a DFA

  • Simulation also proofs that NFAs are not more powerful than DFAs: they recognize the same class of language

  • After consuming a, there is no way to know whether the NFA is in q0 or q1
  • We tolerate this uncertainty: our state of knowledge about the current state is {q0, q1}
  • The states of knowledge become the states of a new, deterministic automaton

Subset construction

Definition

The subset construction, S, is a function, S : N â†’ D, that applies to any NFA, M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, A), to yield a DFA Mâ€² = S(M) = (Qâ€² , Î£â€² , qâ€²0 , Î´â€² , Aâ€²), where the following relationships hold between the parts of M and Mâ€² :

  • Î£â€² = Î£

  • qâ€²0 = {q0}

  • Qâ€² âŠ† 2Q

  • Î´â€² : Qâ€² Ã— Î£ â†’ Qâ€² , where \[âˆ€qâ€²âˆˆ Q : âˆ€Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£ : Î´ â€² (q â€² , Ïƒ) = âˆª_{q âˆˆ qâ€²} Î´(q, Ïƒ)\]

  • Aâ€² = {qâ€² âˆˆ Qâ€² |qâ€² âˆ© A â‰  âˆ…}

Algorithm

Example

Find a DFA equivalent to this NFA:

Note:

  • No row stating where to go from q1
  • This is reasonable as we are never sure to be in state q1
  • Table is complete, as it has a row for every â€œstate of knowledgeâ€ that can be reached directly or indirectly from q0

Exercise 7

For both the DFA and NFA in Example, evaluate Î´âˆ—(q0, x) for each of the following strings:

  1. ab
  2. abab
  3. ak , where k â‰¥ 1

Exercise 8

Create an NFA for the set of all strings over {a, b} ending in abab and use the subset construction to convert it to a DFA. The NFA should have a self-loop on the start state labeled with both a and b. Transitions labeled a and then b, a, and b should take the NFA from q0 to q1 and then to q2, q3 and q4, which is accepting.

Exercise 9

This problem concerns automata for the language L consisting of all strings over {a, b} that end in either adab or baa.

  1. Draw the transition diagram of an NFA for L starting with the same states and transitions as in Exercise 8 and adding some states by a similar technique, so that transitions labeled b and then a take the NFA from q0 to a new accepting state. Label the new states q5, ...
  2. Use the subset construction to convert your NFA to a DFA expressed as a quintuple.

Î›-transitions

General idea

  • Just like nondeterminism, Î›-transitions allow simpler solutions

  • They can also be converted into a deterministic form by simulation

  • An NFA that allows Î›-transitions is called a Î›-NFA

  • Î›-NFA allow Î› as a label on transitions

    • Such a transition consumes no symbol

Example

Î›-NFA formal definition

  • M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, Î», A)

  • Î» : Q â†’ 2 Q

  • For any state qi and input Ïƒ: the next state qj âˆˆ Î´(qi , Ïƒ) âˆª Î»(qi)

    • Using Ïƒ if choice was based on Î´
    • Not using Ïƒ if choice was based on Î»

Î»-closure

Yields the set of all states reachable by zero or more Î›-transitions

Definition:

  • n = |Q|

Î›-Elimination

    1. For each q âˆˆ Q, compute and record Î»âˆ— (q) (needed for the next two steps)

    2. For each q âˆˆ Q and Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£, compute Î´â€² , knowing that \[Î´â€² (q, Ïƒ) = âˆª_{pâˆˆÎ»^âˆ—(q)}Î´(p, Ïƒ)\]

  1. For each q âˆˆ Q, if Î»âˆ—(q) âˆ© A â‰  âˆ…, then make q a member of Aâ€²

  2. Compute Qâ€² by eliminating unreachable states

  1. : A â€² = A = {q3, q4}

(d): Eliminate q2

Exercise 10

Give both a nondeterministic and a deterministic finite automaton for the language L in which each string contains the substring aa and at some later point the substring bb. Thus, for example, baaababba âˆˆ L but bbaa âˆ‰ L.

Exercise 11

Carry out the following steps to get a simple, correct state-transition diagram for aâˆ— bâˆ—. Begin with the simple diagram for aâˆ— in Exercise 3 and a similar one for bâˆ—. Use these two diagrams together with the correct diagram construction operation for concatenation (introducing a Î›-transition). to get a diagram for aâˆ— bâˆ—. Draw this diagram. Then demonstrate the process of Î›-elimination by showing the successive results of applying steps (i)-(iii) of Algorithm 9.3.

Exercise 12

Give an automaton with Î› and another without Î› for the language L in which each string consists of an even number of as followed by an even number of bs. Recall that 0 is even.

Previous exam questions

  • Convert the following Î›-NFA into a DFA
  • M = ({q0, q1, q2}, {a, b}, q0, Î´, {q2})

Regular languages

Definition: Regular Languages

A language L is a regular language if (and only if) there exists an FA M such that L = L(M)

Closure properties

  • The set of regular languages is closed for:
    • Concatenation
    • Closure
    • Union
    • Intersection
    • Set Difference
    • Symmetric difference
    • Complementation
  • This means that the result of applying these operations to regular languages L1 and L2 always is a regular language itself
  • Closure can be proven by constructing an FA for the result

Closure of L1L2

  • Theorem: If L1 and L2 are regular languages, then their concatenation L = L1L2 is a regular language

  • Proof:

    • L1 = L(M1) where M1 = (Q1, Î£1, q0,1, Î´1, A1)
    • L2 = L(M2) where M2 = (Q2, Î£2, q0,2, Î´2, A2)
    • New machine L = L(M) where M = (Q1 âˆª Q2, Î£1 âˆª Î£2, q0,1, Î´, A2)
    • New transition function contains all transitions from Î´1 and Î´2 and Î›-transitions from each state in A1 to q0,2
    • Finish proof by showing that L = L(M) = L1L2

Closure OF L1*

  • Theorem: If L1 is a regular language, then L = L1* is a regular language.

  • Proof:

    • New machine L = L(M) where M = (Q1 âˆª {q0}, q0, Î´, {q0})
    • New transition function contains all transitions from Î´1 and Î›-transitions from q0 to q{0, 1} and from each state in A1 back to to q0
    • Finish proof by showing that L = L(M) = L1*

Closure of L1 âˆª L2

  • Theorem: If L1 and L2 are regular languages, then L = L1 âˆª L2 is a regular language.

  • Proof:

    • New machine L = L(M) where M = (Q1 Ã— Q2, Î£,(q0,1, q0,2) , Î´, A)
    • New transition function: Î´((q1, q2), Ïƒ) = (Î´1(q1, Ïƒ), Î´2(q2, Ïƒ)) for every q1 âˆˆ Q1, q2 âˆˆ Q2 and Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£
    • New accepting states: A = {(q1, q2)|q1 âˆˆ A1 or q2 âˆˆ A2}

Closure of L1 âˆ© L2

  • Theorem: If L1 and L2 are regular languages, then L = L1 âˆ© L2 is a regular language.

  • Proof:

    • New machine L = L(M) where M = (Q1 Ã— Q2, Î£,(q0,1, q0,2) , Î´, A)
    • New transition function: Î´((q1, q2), Ïƒ) = (Î´1(q1, Ïƒ), Î´2(q2, Ïƒ)) for every q1 âˆˆ Q1, q2 âˆˆ Q2 and Ïƒ âˆˆ Î£
    • New accepting states: A = {(q1, q2)|q1 âˆˆ A1 and q2 âˆˆ A2}

Example

Find an FA for the language L, over Î£ = {a,b}. of strings that have both an odd number of as and an odd number of bs. Now clearly L1 âˆ© L2 where

L1 = {x | x âˆˆ {a,b} âˆ§ x contains an odd number of as}, and L1 = {x | x âˆˆ {a,b} x âˆ§ contains an odd number of bs}

Closure of Î£ Â L1

  • Theorem: If L1 is a regular language, then L = Î£ Â L1 is a regular language.

  • Proof:

  • New machine L = L(M) where M = (Q, Î£, q0, Î´, Q Â A)

  • Transition function must be total (add trap state if necessary)

Exercise 13

Show that the regular languages are closed under set difference. In particular, show that if L1 and L2 are regular then L1 Â L2 is also regular.

Exercise 14

Use the cross-product technique to build an FA for this language over E = {a, b}:

L = {x | there is at most one a in x âˆ§ there is at least one b in x}.

Exercise 15

Prove by mathematical induction that if L is a regular language (an FA language), then âˆ€k âˆˆ N: Lk is a regular language (an FA language)

entry.title: Inheritance
entry.content:
Discussion 4: Inheritance

CS61B: Data structure

Video

JUnit Tests

What are the advantages and disadvantages of writing JUnit tests?

  • Advantages:
    1. Keeps your code organized - each test corresponds to different building blocks of your program
    2. You can debug your code locally and find which part of your program is not working
    3. Provides documentation that your program actually works
    4. Can reduce the amount of test code you need to write because you can reuse code
  • Disadvantages:
    1. Hard to use for higher-level testing

Creating Cats

Given the Animal class, fill in the definition of the Cat class so that when greet() is called, â€œCat [name] says: Meow!â€ is printed (instead of â€œAnimal [name] says: Huh?â€). Cats less than the ages of 5 should say â€œMEOW!â€ instead of â€œMeow!â€.

Donâ€™t forget to use @Override if you are writing a function with the same signature as a function in the superclass.

public class Animal {protected String name, noise;protected int age;public Animal(String name, int age) {this.name = name;    this.age = age;    this.noise = "Huh?";    }        public String makeNoise() {        if (age < 5) {            return noise.toUpperCase();        } else {            return noise;        }    }    public void greet() {        System.out.println("Animal " + name + " says: " + makeNoise());    }}public Cat(String name, int age) {    super(name, age); // Call superclass' constructor.    this.noise = "Meow!"; // Change the value of the field.}@Overridepublic void greet() {System.out.println("Cat " + name + " says: " + makeNoise());}}

Raining Cats and Dogs

  1. Assume that Animal and Cat are defined as above. What would Java print on each of the indicated lines?
public class Dog extends Animal {public Dog(String name, int age) {        super(name, age);        noise = "Woof!";    }@Override    public void greet() {        System.out.println("Dog " + name + " says: " + makeNoise());    }    public void playFetch() {        System.out.println("Fetch, " + name + "!");    }}public class TestAnimals {    public static void main(String[] args) {        Animal a = new Animal("Pluto", 10);        Cat c = new Cat("Garfield", 6);        Dog d = new Dog("Fido", 4);                a.greet(); // (A) Animal Pluto says: Huh?        c.greet(); // (B) Cat Garfield says: Meow!        d.greet(); // (C) Dog Fido says: WOOF!        a = c;        ((Cat) a).greet(); // (D) Cat Garfield says: Meow!        a.greet(); // (E) Cat Garfield says: Meow!    }}
  1. Consider what would happen if we added the following to the bottom of main under line 27:
a = **new** Animal("Fluffy", 2); c = a;

Would this code produce a compiler error? What if we set the second line to be c = (Cat) a instead?

This code would produce a compiler error. This is because we are trying to assign a variable of static type Animal to a variable of static type Cat. Since Animal is a more generic type than Cat, not all Animals are Cats. This specifically fails at compile time because Java runs a check before executing code to prevent you form assigning things of the wrong type.

If we were set the second line to be c = (Cat) a instead, this code will fail at runtime instead. This is because by casting a to Cat, we are telling the Java compiler that we know that a actually contains a Cat, even though it is statically typed to be an Animal. When Java goes to execute the code, it tries to assign the Animal to c, which errors.

  1. Consider what would happen if we instead added the following to the bottom of main under line 27:
a = new Dog("Spot", 10);d = a

Why would this code produce a compiler error? How could we fix this error?

This code produces a compiler error in the second line. The static type of d is Dog while the static type of a is Animal. Dog is a subclass of Animal, so this assignment will fail at compile time because not all Animals are Dogs. Use casting to address the problem.

d = (Dog) a;

This represents a promise to the compiler that at runtime, a will be bound to an object that is compatible with the Dog type.

Note: The @Override tag specifies that the function overrides a parent classâ€™s function. Note 2: You can only call one other constructor from a constructor, and the call has to be on the first line. This call is â€œsuperâ€ which means the superclassâ€™ constructor. You can use â€œthis(...)â€ to call a different constructor defined in the same class.) Note 3: A runtime error would occur if we lie during casting. (That if â€œaâ€ was not actually a Dog object, and instead was a Cat or something else, the code would fail at runtime.)

An Exercise in Inheritance Misery Extra

Cross out any lines that cause compile-time errors or cascading errors (failures that occur because of an error that happened earlier in the program), and put an X through runtime errors (if any). Donâ€™t just limit your search to main, there could be errors in classes A,B,C. What does D.main output after removing these lines?

class A {    public int x = 5;    public void m1() { System.out.println("Am1-> " + x); }    public void m2() { System.out.println("Am2-> " + this.x); }    public void update() { x = 99; }}class B extends A {    public void m2() { System.out.println("Bm2-> " + x); }    public void m2(int y) { System.out.println("Bm2y-> " + y); }    public void m3() { System.out.println("Bm3-> " + "called"); }}class C extends B {    public int y = x + 1;    public void m2() { System.out.println("Cm2-> " + super.x); }\\ public void m4() { System.out.println("Cm4-> " + super.super.x); } can't do super.superpublic void m5() { System.out.println("Cm5-> " + y); }}class D {public static void main (String[] args) {\\ B a0 = new A(); Dynamic type must be B or subclass of B\\ a0.m1(); cascading: prev line failed, so a0 can't be initialized\\ a0.m2(16); cascading: prev line failed, so a0 can't be initializedA b0 = new B();System.out.println(b0.x); [prints "5"]b0.m1(); [prints "Am1-> 5"]b0.m2(); [prints "Bm2-> 5"]\\ b0.m2(61); m2 (int y) not defined in static type of b0B b1 = new B();b1.m2(61); [prints "Bm2y-> 61"]b1.m3(); [prints "Bm3-> called"]A c0 = new C();c0.m2(); [prints "cm2-> 5"]\\ C c1 = (A) new C(); Can't assign c1 to an AA a1 = (A) c0;C c2 = (C) a1;c2.m3(); [print Bm3-> called]\\ c2.m4(); C.m4() is invalidc2.m5(); [print Cm5-> 6]((C) c0).m3(); [print Bm3-> called]\\ (C) c0.m2(); NOT RUNTIME ERROR This would cast the result of what the method returns andit returns void therefore compile-time errorb0.update();b0.m1(); [print Am1-> 99]}}

entry.title: Artificial Neural Networks
entry.content:
Artificial Neural Networks

Outline

  • Motivation for neural processing
  • Neural basis
  • Perceptrons
  • Training
  • Testing

Motivation

  • Computers are not like brains/bodies
    • they are better than brains at some things
      • symbolic calculations
      • reliably doing what they are told
    • they are (much) worse than brains/bodies at others
      • understanding human language
      • learning
      • perceiving (ie seeing, hearing)
  • Question
    • Can we build computers and/or programs that are (more) like brains?
    • If so, is it useful?

von Neumann architecture

Neural architecture

  • The brain doesnâ€™t seem to have a CPU
    • Instead, it has many simple, parallel, asynchronous units, called neurons
  • Each neuron is a single cell, with
    • some relatively short fibres, called dendrites
    • one long fibre, called an axon
  • The end of the axon branches out into more short fibres
  • Each fibre â€œconnectsâ€ to the dendrites and cell bodies of other neurons
    • The â€œconnectionâ€ is actually a tiny gap, called a synapse
  • Axons are transmitters, dendrites are receivers

Neural architecture: neuron

  • The fibres of surrounding neurons emit chemicals (neurotransmitters) that move across the synapse and change the electrical potential applied to the cell body
    • Sometimes the transmission across the synapse increases the potential, and sometimes decreases it
  • When the potential reaches a certain threshold, an electrical pulse, or action potential, travels down the axon, eventually reaching all the branches, causing them to release their neurotransmitters
    • And so on through the network

Neural architecture: neuroplasticity

  • Neuroplasticity or brain plasticity is the brainâ€™s ability to change during life
  • The brain can reorganise itself
    • by forming new connections between brain cells (neurons)
  • Neuroplasticity occurs in the brain
    • At the beginning of life: when the immature brain organizes itself
    • After brain injury: to compensate for lost functions or maximize remaining ones
    • Throughout life: whenever something new is learned and memorised
  • For a long time, it was believed that as we age, the connections in the brain become fixed
    • Research has now shown that, during life, the brain never stops changing through learning
  • When you become an expert in a specific kind of knowledge, the areas in your brain that deal with this type of skill will grow
    • For instance, London taxi drivers have a larger posterior hippocampus than London bus drivers
    • It is because this region of the hippocampus is specialised in acquiring and using complex spatial information in order to navigate efficiently
    • Taxi drivers have to navigate around London, using The Knowledge, whereas bus drivers follow a limited set of routes
  • There are changes to neurons that seem to reflect or enable learning
    • The synaptic connections exhibit plasticity
      • The degree to which a neuron will react to a stimulus across a particular synapse is subject to change over time (long-term potentiation)
    • Neurons create new connections to other neurons
    • Other changes in structure also seem to occur, some less well understood than others

The Neuron as a device

  • There are around neurons 1012 in the human brain
    • with, perhaps, 1014 or so synapses
  • Neurons are slow devices
    • Tens of milliseconds to do something
    • Jerome Feldman translates this into the â€œ100 step program constraintâ€™â€™
      • Most of the AI tasks we want to do take people less than a second
      • So any brain â€œprogramâ€ canâ€™t be longer than 100 neural â€œinstructionsâ€
  • No particular unit seems to be more important than any other
    • Destroying any one brain cell has little effect on overall processing

How do neurons do it?

  • All the billions of neurons in the brain are active at once â€£ So this is truly massive parallelism
  • But itâ€™s probably not the kind of parallelism that we are used to in conventional Computer Science
    • Sending messages (i.e., complex patterns that encode information) is probably too slow to work
    • So information is probably encoded some other way
      • e.g., by the connections themselves
  • Maybe we can explain cognition by densely connected networks transmitting simple signals
    • Connectionist computing (Feldman)
    • Parallel Distributed Processing (PDP; Rumelhart, McClelland, Hinton)
    • (Artificial) Neural Networks

Perceptrons

  • Many connectionists use the same simple model of a neural system
  • There is a collection of units, each of which has
    • some weighted inputs from other units
      • inputs represent the degree to which other units are active (firing)
      • weights represent how much the unit is affected by the activity of the other units
    • a threshold that the sum of the weighted inputs must exceed to cause firing
    • a single output that connects to (an)other unit(s)
      • if the unit fires, the resulting action potential goes this way
  • xi are inputs, reals between 0 and 1 (standard net) or -1 and 1 (bipolar net)
  • wi are weights, reals
  • wn is usually set at the threshold with xn = 1(bias)
  • y is the weighted sum of inputs including the threshold (activation level)
  • o is the output

The output is computed using a function that determines how far the perceptronâ€™s activation level is below or above 0

  • Note that this is a loose approximation to what happens in biology
    • Perceptrons transmit information via real-valued numbers as inputs arrive
      • real neurons fire all the time, changing their firing rate, from a few pulses per second to a few hundred pulses per second
      • spiking neural networks simulate this directlyâ€”beyond scope of current module
  • The weights in perceptrons are not fixed, and can change
    • learning in a neural network is achieved by adjusting weights

The Big Questions for Neural Nets

  • How do we wire up a network of perceptrons?
    • i.e., what â€œarchitectureâ€ do we use?
  • How does the network represent knowledge?
    • i.e., what do the nodes and combinations of nodes mean?
  • How do we set the weights?
    • i.e., how does learning take place?

Simplest architecture: a perceptron

  • A basic perceptron computes o = f( X . W )
    • X . W = âˆ‘i wi xi = w1 . x1 + w2. x2 + ... + wn . 1
    • g( x ) = 1 if x â‰¥ 0.5 and 0 otherwise
      • g is the activation or transfer function
      • more complex, continuous functions (esp. sigmoid) can be used, but they all have the same basic purpose: to push the output values towards the extremes
      • without this non-linearity, the network can only learn simple linear functions
      • sigmoid function is differentiable, whereas sharp threshold is not

Logical function AND

  • Perceptrons can simulate basic logic gates, such as AND
aba+b-1output
1111
1000
0100
00-10

Logical function OR

aba+b+0output
1121
1011
0111
0000

Training perceptrons

  • Pereceptrons can be trained to compute a specific function
  • Basic training procedure
    • Start with a perceptron with any values for the weights (usually random)
    • Apply the input, let the perceptron compute the answer
    • If the answer is right
      • do nothing
    • If the answer is wrong
      • modify the weights by adding or subtracting the input vector (perhaps scaled smaller)
    • Iterate over all the input vectors, repeating as necessary, until the perceptron learns what we want, to within a predefined degree of error
  • The intuition behind the basic training algorithm this is
    • If the unit should have gone on, but didnâ€™t, increase the influence of the inputs that are on
      • adding the input (or a fraction thereof) to the weights will move in the right direction
    • If the unit should have been off, but was on, decrease the influence of the units that were on
      • subtracting the input (of a fraction thereof) from the weights moves in the right direction

Training the logical OR function

abbiasoutput
1110
1011
0111
0011
  • Initially the weights are all 0
    • the weight vector, W = (0 0 0)
  • Now we cycle through the inputs and change the weights as necessary

Training the logical AND function

abbiasoutput
0010
0110
1010
1111
  • Initially the weights are all 0
    • the weight vector, W = (0 0 0)
  • Now we cycle through the inputs and change the weights as necessary
  • Make your own table:
    • Input Weights Result Action

And now, with Î± = 0.2

Generalised training procedure

  • Start with a perceptron with any values for the weights (0 or random)
    • Feed the input, let the perceptron compute the answer
    • If the answer is right
      • do nothing
    • If the answer is wrong
      • add this factor to each weight: Î” wi = Î± ( y â€“ h ) inputi
  • Iterate over all the input vectors, repeating as necessary, until (i.e., the weight vector converges, or |Î”W| â‰¤ a given constant)
    • each cycle through the input data is called an epoch
  • Values:
    • Î± is the learning rate, 0 < Î± â‰¤ 1; it prevents the values from jumping around wildly
    • y is the desired output
    • h is the actual output

Single-layer perceptron networks

  • In a single layer perceptron network there are
    • input units
    • output units
  • There are as many perceptrons as output units
    • each input unit is connected to every output unit â€£ each connection has a weight
    • each output has a soft thresholding function, e.g. sigmoid (more later)
  • It is possible to learn multiple functions with one training sequence
    • outputs are now vectors (as inputs always were)

Classifying using a perceptron

  • A (bipolar) perceptron can learn to classify data, into 2 categories
    • Convergence after ~500 iterations
      • W = (-1.13 -1.1 10.9)
      • -1.3 * x1 + -1.1*x2 + 10.9 = 0
x1x2output
1.01.01
9.46.4-1
2.52.11
8.07.7-1
0.52.21
7.98.4-1
7.07.0-1
2.80.81
1.23.01
7.86.1-1

Single-layer perceptron networks

  • We can generalise the weight updating algorithm for each perceptron in the net, given a differentiable activation function, g:
    • Î”wi,j = Î± . xi . ( yj â€“ hj ) . gâ€²( Î£kwk,j. xk )
      • Î± is the learning rate, which controls the amount of adjustment at each step
      • yi , hi are the desired and actual node outputs, respectively
      • ( yj â€“ hj ) is the error in the current node output, compared with the example
      • gâ€² is the derivative of the activation function; for sigmoid, gâ€² = g( 1 â€“ g )
      • Î£kwk,j. xk is the value before activation at the current node à¹ ( yj â€“ hj ) . gâ€²(Î£kwk,j. xk) is called the Î” value (see Russell and Norvig)
    • the gâ€² term adjusts the amount of error correction depending on the slope of the activation function
  • A stopping criterion for training is based on the overall error, E
    • E = 0.5 . Î£i ( yj â€“ hj )2
    • This can be forced to 0, or to some allowable level of approximation

The bad news: the X-OR problem

  • As we can see from the graph, the classifier is computing a straight line between two linearly separable sets of points, dividing the space in two
    • with more inputs, it would be a plane or hyper-plane
  • If there is no straight line that partitions the set, a single perceptron cannot learn the classification
    • Exclusive OR is one such case

The solution: multi-layered NNs

  • The solution to this problem is to build neural networks from layers of perceptrons
  • Confusing terminology
    • We have so far talked about the perceptron as though it were a single thing
    • It is in fact two layers of values, one input and one output
      • with weighted connections connecting them
    • When we talk about multiple layers, we use the number of layers of values to say how many there are
  • It is mathematically proven that a network of three layers (of values) with a linear outputs layer is enough to approximate any function
    • there is, then, 1 hidden layer of perceptrons
    • Cybenkoâ€™s theorem, 1989, for sigmoid activation; Hornik, 1991, generalised

A (tiny) multilayer feed-forward neural network

  • Now there are two sets of weights, one for each layer
    • How do we train the network? The simple perceptron algorithm wonâ€™t work here

Network training in general

  • In general, there could be as many input units, as many hidden units and as many output units as you like
    • each unit is connected to every unit in the next layer, and only to the next layer
    • each connection has a weight
    • each unit in the hidden layer has an output modifier function, usually sigmoid
  • Too many units leads to long training times and overfitting to data (more on that later)
  • Too few units leads to inability to learn
  • There is no known procedure to compute the required number
    • so skill and judgement is required!

Back-propagation training

  • It turns out that we can reuse the training algorithm
    • apply it once per perceptron layer (so twice, in a net with 1 hidden layer)
    • start at the output layer
  • Because this is working in the opposite direction from the data flow
    • (in a feed-forward network)
    • it is called back-propagation
  • Key Idea
    • a hidden node j causes part of the error identified between the inputs and a given output node i, in proportion to its connection weight to i
    • so we compute the hidden layer error values by dividing the output layer error values in proportion to the connections from the hidden layer to the output layer

Back-propagation algorithm

  • Compute Î” values for output units, using observed error
  • Starting with output layer, and working towards input layer
    • propagate Î” values back from layer L to layer L â€“ 1
      • for each node j in layer ( L â€“ 1 ): Î”j = gâ€²( Î£kwj,k. Î” k )
    • update weights between layer L â€“ 1 and layer L

Testing the trained network

  • We can train a network to model a dataset in as much detail as we like
  • However, we quite often want a network to generalise
    • ie, not just learn the values we told it (we know them already) but estimate the (assumed continuous) functions that gave rise to them
  • If we train perfectly, we may over-fit, and miss that generality
  • To overcome this problem, divide the data into training sets and test sets, and perform cross-validation
    • for example, reserve 10% of the data for testing, and use 90% for training
      • compare the predicted 10% of values with the originals
    • better, use 10-fold cross-validation:
      • partition the data into 10 subsets
      • cross-validation 90% vs. 10% on each combination of the 10 subsets
    • can be the stopping criterion, but it is more expensive than local error

Neurally inspired computing

  • Much neural network research makes biologically implausible assumptions about how neurons work
    • backpropagation is biologically implausible
    • this is â€œneurally inspired computingâ€ rather than â€œbrain scienceâ€
  • None of the neural network models distinguish humans from dogs from dolphins from flatworms
    • Whatever distinguishes â€œhigherâ€ cognitive capacities (language, reasoning) may not be apparent at this low level of analysis
  • Relation between NN and â€œsymbolic AIâ€?
    • Some claim NN models donâ€™t have symbols and representations
    • Others think of NNs as simply being an â€œimplementation-levelâ€ theory
    • NNs started out as a branch of statistical pattern classification
    • Other more structured statistical methods are now tending to take over, but ANNs are still popular in many applications
