entry.title: From sequence to structure
entry.content:
From sequence to structure - Secondary structure prediction

VUB 4018221FNR Algorithms in Computational biology and bioinformatics

Video Part 1

Protein secondary structure prediction 6:00

Why proteins? 8:34

  • Interacting is what proteins do!
    • Proteins can interact with many types of molecules, including with other proteins, with lipids, with carboyhydrates, and with DNA.
  • Abundance in cells: Proteins in the cell are vastly complicated
    • It has been estimated that average-sized bacteria contain about 2 million proteins per cell.

Bioinformatics, DNA and proteins 12:20

totalpercentage
Evidence at protein level206220.05%
Evidence at transcript level8188051.91%
Inferred from homology989325223.10%
Predicted3208920074.94%

The key method to investigate proteins is understand its level, like how to catalyse reaction and which signa, that is related to structural biology.

Structural biology 15:38

What do we want to find out? 23:03

  • How does a protein interact with a ligand?

    • What does ibuprofen do?

  • What do protein complexes look like?

    • E.g. How do pili from bacteria form?

Protein behaviour 26:29

Everything constructed proteins move all the time.

Structural relationship of proteins and amino acids

Amino acids are the building blocks of polypeptides and proteins. In polypeptides and proteins, amino acids molecules are linked to each other by polypeptide bonds. The sequence of amino acids in polypeptide is encoded by the DNA.

Sequence and structure 41:40

  • Protein folding

  • The structure is encoded in the sequence, but how?

    • 100 amino acid protein
      • 198 backbone angles
      • 3 conformations each
      • 3198 possibilities!

  • How do we get from a sequence to secondary or tertiary structure? 47:17

    • Experimental data!
      • NMR, X-ray, â€¦
      • But what if you donâ€™t have any? â€“ Bioinformatics!

Protein secondary structure prediction 1:10:32

How do we define secondary structure classes?

  • Hydrogen bonding 1:10:48

    • Hydrogen on electronegative atom (N, O) has partial positive charge
    • Can form a hydrogen bond with another electronegative atom

  • Regular patterns of hydrogen bonding in secondary structure elements 1:16:35

  • DSSP (hydrogen bond estimation algorithm) 1:17:54

    • 1983, in Pascal

    • Simple definition for backbone hydrogen bond

      • r is distance
      • N, H backbone atoms from residue i
      • O, C backbone atoms from residue j

    • Assigns secondary structure based on patterns

      • Î± helix (H), i â†’ i+4
      • Î² strand (E), long set of connected hydrogen bonds
      • 310 helix (G), i â†’ i+3
      • And othersâ€¦

  • Look at the local conformation of the amino acid.

  • Using structural biology data

Is there bias in the input data? 1:43:07

  • Reference structure data set is crucial

    • Not too much overlap between sequences!

  • In general, proteins with less than 25-30% sequence identity between them

  • Other considerations

    • Structure quality and origin, â€¦

  • Only about 6000 out of 80000 proteins

  • Define secondary structure

    • DSSPH

      • bonds

    • STRIDE

      • H bonds and (Î¦,Î¨)

    • DEFINE

      • Interatomic distances

  • Secondary structure is a human concept!

  • Atom coordinate information from tertiary structure is converted into discrete secondary structure states

  • This is what is used to develop secondary structure predictors.

Video Part 2 1:02 ~ 1:50:17

How do we prepare and clean up the data?

Input data 2:27

  • Need clean protein structure data with bias removed as much as possible
    • What about sequence overlap? Relatively common problem, does someone already have a solution
  • Look for servers/articles/â€¦ â€“ Common bioinformatics approach 3:56
    • With a bit of luck the data are still live and accessible
  • Determine which cutoffs/dataset to use for your approach 5:25
    • Very strict:
      • Only X-ray crystallography
      • Resolution of 1.6 Ã… or better (lower value)
      • Sequence identity cutoff of 25%
      • cullpdb_pc20_res1.6_R0.25_d120323_chains1998
  • What is in the PISCES file? 6:27

  • Run DSSP and STRIDE on 498 PDB structure 8:16
    • Original set reduced for computational reasons
  • Parse and interpret results
    • Files for DSSP and for STRIDE

  • Associated information 9:26
  • Protein family, from CATH

Other issues 11:39

Proteins are dynamic

Example 12:22:

Does a given amino acid always fully adopt one type of secondary structure in reality?

  • No!
  • Even possible that it switches secondary structure
    • E.g. plaque formation in Alzheimers, where Î± helices from native protein form Î²strands in plaques.
Could you avoid using structures? 15:47

  • Develop predictions directly from data for protein in solution

  • NMR data is recorded on proteins in solution

    • Estimate in-solution secondary structure populations from NMR observations
    • Get secondary structure fractions, not statesâ€¦

Variability! 16:50

How will we validate how well our approach works? 18:02

Validation 20:35

  • Understand how well the method works
    • Plan ahead
  • Need independent test set
    • Cannot use data that is included in statistical analysis or training of method
  • Jackknife (leave-one-out) 23:50
    • If method can be primed fast enough, leave out one protein, train the method, test it on the protein that you took out, ...
  • But what measures or scores do you use to assess how well your method works? 25:03
  • Do you look at only what you predict correctly? Or also at what you predict incorrectly?

Protein secondary structure prediction

Q3 measure 35:35

\[Q_3 = \frac{N_{residues\_correctly\_predicted}}{N_{residues\_total}}\]

  • Random prediction should give 0.33
  • Real random prediction gives 0.38
    • Frequencies of secondary structure are not the same
  • Bad predictions can give high scores ...

Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) 40:48

  • Predicted for each secondary structure state
  • Uses false/true positives and false/true negative

\[MCC = \frac{TPÃ—TN-TPÃ—FN}{\sqrt{(TP+FP)(TP+FN)(TN+FP)(TN+FN)}}\]

  • Sensitivity (hit rate, recall)

    TPR = TP / (TP + FN)

  • Specificity

    SPC = TN / (FP + TN)

  • Report MCC always per secondary structure class
  • Multi-class definition also available

\[MCC_{multiclass} = \frac{\sum_k\sum_l\sum_mC_{kk}C_{lm}-C_{kl}C_{mk}}{\sqrt{\sum_k(\sum_lC_{kl})(\sum_{k'|k'â‰ k}\sum_{l'}C_{k'l'})}\sqrt{\sum_k(\sum_lC_{lk})(\sum_{k'|k'â‰ k}\sum_{l'}C_{l'k'})}}\]

Sov measure 50:29

Segment-based, heuristic

  • Punishes broken predictions

Predictions 53:30

  • Model based
    • Preferably using some actual experimental data
  • Machine learning
    • Many approaches, training steps essentia

Chou-Fasman 54:42

  • Original attempt at predicting secondary structure
  • Chou and Fasman (1970s)
  • Based on very limited number of protein structures

Statistical propensity for each amino acid (R) to adopt a certain secondary structure (S)

Chou-Fasman algorithm
  • Assign Î±/Î² propensities to each amino acid

  • Find region with 4/6 connected residues pÎ± > 1.0
    • Extend on both ends until:
      • 4 connected residues have average pÎ± < 1.0 â†’ End of Î± helix
    • Total segment longer than 5 residues, average pÎ± > pÎ² ?
      • Assign as Î± helix

  • Find region with 3/5 connected residues pÎ² > 1.0
    • Extend on both ends until:
      • 4 connected residues have average pÎ² < 1.0 â†’ End of Î² sheet
    • Average pÎ² > 1.05 and average pÎ² > pÎ±?
      • Assign as Î² sheet
  • Repeat for whole sequence
  • If Î±/Î² overlap, choose which one by highest average p

Overall Chou-Fasman algorithm:

  • Based on statistics
  • Very simple
    • Per-residue, no residue interactions included
    • Algorithm cutoffs are pretty arbitrary
  • But gives better than random results!
    • Q3 score of 42-52% depending on protein family

GOR method 1:11:22

  • Evolved from GOR to GOR-V

    • Jean Garnier, David Osguthorpe, Barry Robson

  • Based on information theory approach (Bayes)

    • Self-information
    • Directional information
    • Pair information

  • Clearly defined model to get to results

  • Self-information (related to Chou-Fasman)

  • Self-information, more general

Calculated for the three conformations, the highest value of Eq. (2) for one of the conformations S will be the predicted conformation and will be the propensity for that residue to be in that conformation, usually expressed in centinat units when natural logarithms are used.

  • Include local sequence information
    • How often do you see a residue in relation to a secondary structure element at position j?

\[I(Î”S_j;R_1,..., R_n ) = \log[P(S_j, R_1,..., R_n )/ P(n âˆ’ S_j, R_1,..., R_n )]+log[P(n âˆ’ S)/ P(S)]\]

GOR I/II 1:21:22
GOR I and II approximation
  • Self and directional information
    • 26 proteins, ~4500 residues (1978, GOR I)
  • Uses windows of 17 residues
    • For residue at position j, consider j-8 to j+8

  • GOR I and II implementation

  • GOR I resultsâ€¦
    • Has Q3 around 49%, but includes turns
    • Bad at Î² sheet, tweaks get higher Q3 (up to 60%)

GOR III 1:35:05
GOR III approximation
  • 68 proteins, 12000 residues (1987)

  • The results
    • GOR III has Q3 around 63%

How to improve this method?

GOR IV 1:37:06
GOR IV approximation
  • 267 proteins, 63000 residues (1996)
  • Consider information for all residue pairs

  • GOR IV implementation

  • Residue at position j in conformation S (and n-S):
    • For threonine T at position j-8:
      • Probability of histidine H at position j-7
      • Same for j-6 to j+8
    • For histidine H at position j-7:
      • â€¦

  • Residue at position j in conformation S (and n-S):

  • Probability threonine T at position j-8

  • Probability histidine H at position j-7

  • â€¦

  • The results

    • have mean Q3 of 64.4%
    • Example sequence of each protein class
      • Zvelebil and Baum, Understanding Bioinformatics, Garland Science.
      • All Î±, all Î², Î±/Î² and Î±+Î²
    • Ranges from 39.2% (Î±+Î²) to 67.2% (Î±/Î²)

GOR V 1:45:06
  • Uses multiple sequence alignment
    • Structure is more conserved than sequence
      • Insertions/deletions not as common in Î±helices andÎ²sheets, more so in loops.
    • PSI-BLAST on query sequence
      • Get set of sequences with high identity
        • Cutoff 30% if lots of hits, lower to 20% if not that many
      • Predict secondary structure for each sequence
      • Average predictions for each residue
  • Various other improvements
    • 513 proteins, 84107 residues (2002)
  • The resultsâ€¦
    • Has mean Q3 of 73.5%
    • Q3 ranges from 60.3% (allÎ²) to 84.3% (allÎ±)

  • Why is Î± â€˜easierâ€™ than Î²?

Video Part 3

Secondary structure for unknown sequence

Zpred

  • Based on GOR
    • Uses homologous sequence information
      • Averaging of prediction per residue
      • Calculates conservation value
  • Some amino acids are more similar to each other than othersâ€¦
    • Related to physical characteristics (of the side chain), not DNA sequence mutation variation
  • Amino acid characteristics
  • Conservation value
    • Zvelebil conservation number (Cn)
      • 1.0 for identical residue
      • 0.9 for residues with same characteristics (e.g. I and L)
      • Subtract 0.1 for every different characteristic
        • R positive, polar
        • V aliphatic, hydrophobic, small
        • 5 differences; conservation 0.9 â€“ (0.1 x 5) = 0.4
      • Gaps get all characteristics â€“ Results in low conservation value!
  • The resultsâ€¦
  • Q3 ranges from 44.9% (allÎ²) to 76.9% (allÎ±)
  • Results for all Î² are worse than GOR IVâ€¦

Nearest-neighbour method

  • Proteins similar sequence share same fold
    • Assumption: also true for short stretches
  • Examine query sequence with same window
    • Identify best-matching fragments
    • Look at most prevalent secondary structure for middle residue

PREDATOR

  • Identifies potentially hydrogen-bonded residues
    • Î± helices, parallel and antiparallel Î²sheet
  • Nearest-neighbor for secondary structure
    • Î± helices, Î²sheet and coil
  • Propensities
    • Turns
  • Combines results
  • Can use homologous sequences
    • Pairwise alignments!
  • The results without homologousâ€¦
    • Q3 ranges from 49.0% (Î±+Î²) to 66.4% (Î±/Î²)
    • Similar to GOR IV
  • The results with homologousâ€¦
    • Q3 ranges from 54.2% (Î±+Î²) to 80.5% (Î±/Î²)
    • Again homologous sequences helpâ€¦
  • Results

Hidden Markov model

  • Discrete Markov process
  • Transition probabilities expressed in transition matrix

Discrete Markov process

  • Probability for Sun-cloud-rain-rain-sun?

  • First have to define starting state (sun), then: \[P = P(sun |sun)Ã— P(cloud |sun)Ã—P(rain | cloud)Ã— P(rain |rain)Ã— P(sun |rain)P = 0.50 Ã— 0.30 Ã—0.35Ã— 0.40 Ã— 0.10 = 0.0021\]

  • Can get probability for sequence of related events

    • Dependence only on previous state(s)!
    • Markov chain

Hidden Markov Model (HMM)

  • Define:

    • Hidden states (N=3) \[S = \{S_1, S_2,..., S_N\}\]

    • State of model at step n \[q_n\]

    • Observations (M=20) \[V = \{v_1, v_2,..., v_m \}\]

    • State transition matrix \[A = \{p_{i|j}\}\\p_{i|j} = P(q_{n+1} = i | q_{n} = j),1â‰¤ i, j â‰¤ N\]

    • Emission distribution \[E = \{e_j(k)\}\\e_j(k) = P(V_kat n | q_n = S_{j});1â‰¤ j â‰¤ N,1â‰¤ k â‰¤ M\]

    • Initial state distribution \[Ï€= Ï€_{i}\\Ï€_{i} = P(q_1 = S_j),1â‰¤ j â‰¤ N\]

  • 3-state secondary structure HMM

    • Produce observation sequence
      • Choose an initial state Sj according to Ï€; step q1
      • Choose an emission observation vk based on state
      • Proceed to step qn+1, pick state Si using transition probabilities from matrix A
      • Again emission, proceed or stop, â€¦

  • Have to â€˜recoverâ€™ the hidden state probabilities from a known observed sequence

    • Calculate all state sequences of sequence length T?
      • 2TNT calculations; not efficient
    • Forward algorithm
      • Start with first amino acid in sequence
        • Calculate probabilities for observing next amino acid in sequence for each secondary structure combination
      • N2T calculations

  • Hidden states model can be made more complex to take more variables into account

    • Hydrophobicity, charge bias, helix length, â€¦
    • Incorporate homologous sequence

  • For example HHPred

Machine learning

  • Neural networks
  • Random forests
  • Support vector machine
  • â€¦

Neural networks

  • Layers with connected nodes or units

  • Many architectures now possible for neural networks
    • Is a world in itself
  • Always crucial is the network training
    • Training set
      • With as little bias as possible
      • Is used to make the neural network â€˜learnâ€™
  • Complexity of network to fit problem
    • Want predictions as â€˜generalâ€™ as possible!
Network training
  • Test set
    • To validate results and avoid overfitting

PHD

  • Uses two neural networks
    • First sequence-to-structure
      • Predict secondary structure
    • Second structure-to-structure
      • Takes output of first network
      • Correlate conformations for neighbouring residues
  • The resultsâ€¦
    • Q3 ranges from 73.5% (allÎ²) to 87.9% (allÎ±)
    • Much betterâ€¦

Example:

PROF

  • Predict secondary structure with different approaches
    • GOR-type, multiple sequence alignment, â€¦
  • Use neural network to choose final prediction
  • The resultsâ€¦
    • Q3 ranges from 58.15 (allÎ²) to 90.7% (allÎ±)

PSIPRED

  • Similar to PHD
    • But with first PSI-BLAST multiple alignment step
  • The resultsâ€¦
    • Q3 ranges from 65.4% (allÎ²) to 94.4% (allÎ±)

Hurray for neural networks

  • Give the best results overall
  • Black box
  • Does not contribute to our understanding of how sequence encodes secondary structureâ€¦
  • Lots of effort going towards â€˜understandable AIâ€™
    • But not so easy

Meta- or consensus predictors

  • Combine results from different approaches
  • Increases confidence in positives

Combination methods

For example JPred

JPred

Bioinformatics approach

Combine results from servers

  • Own scripts or workflow managers (TAVERNA)

Which data in the end?

Sequence to secondary structure

  • Validation
    • Community testing efforts (CASP, CAFASP)
    • Many approaches already tried beforeâ€¦
    • Always worth checking out!
  • What does the input data mean?
    • Understand the results
    • Know what can be used as input in the first place
  • What does the output of each method mean?
    • What are you using it for?
    • Accuracy, confidence, â€¦
  • Why again?
    • Enormous amount of sequence-only data â€“ Identify structured regions:
      • Can give insights in possible function
      • Can help in deciding where to mutate sequence
  • But!
    • Sequences can adopt multiple secondary structure in different circumstances...
      • Absolute truths are rare in biology!
    • Alpha-helix easier than beta-sheetâ€¦
  • Can probably only get up to ~90% accuracy

entry.title: Testing
entry.content:
Testing

CS61B: Data structure

Video

How Does a Programmer Know That Their Code Works?

In the real world, programmers believe their code works because of tests they write themselves.

  • Knowing that it works for sure is usually impossible.
  • This will be our new way.

Sorting: The McGuffin for Our Testing Adventure

To try out this new wayâ„¢, we need a task to complete.

  • Letâ€™s try to write a method that sorts arrays of Strings.

In this lecture weâ€™ll write sort, as well as our own test for sort.

  • Even crazier idea: Weâ€™ll start by writing testSort first!

Ad Hoc Testing vs. JUnit

Ad-Hoc Testing is Tedious

public class TestSort {    /** Tests the sort method of the Sort class. */    public static void testSort() {        String[] input = {"beware" , "of", "falling", "rocks"};        String[] expected = {"beware" , "falling", "of", "rocks"};        Sort.sort(input); /* JUnit saves us the trouble of writing code like this (and more!). */        for (int i = 0; i < input.length; i += 1) {          if (!input[i].equals(expected[i])) {              System.out.println("Mismatch at position " + i + ", expected: '" + expected[i] +                              "', but got '" + input[i] + "'");              return;        }        }    }     public static void main(String[] args) {  testSort();    }}

JUnit: A Library for Making Testing Easier (example below)

public class TestSort {  /** Tests the sort method of the Sort class. */    public static testSort() {    String[] input = {"cows", "dwell", "above", "clouds"};    String[] expected = {"above", "cows", "clouds", "dwell"};    Sort.sort(input);     org.junit.Assert.assertArrayEquals(expected, input);  }   public static void main(String[] args) {    testSort();  }}

Selection Sort

Back to Sorting: Selection Sort

Selection sorting a list of N items:

  • Find the smallest item.
  • Move it to the front.
  • Selection sort the remaining N-1 items (without touching front item!).

Letâ€™s try implementing this.

public class Sort {/** Sorts strings destructively. */public static void sort(String[] x) {        // Find the smallest item        // Move it to the front        // Selection sort the rest (using recursion)        sort(x, 0);}/** Sorts x starting at position start. */private static void sort(String[] x, int start) {    if (start == x.length) {        return;        }    int smallestIndex = findSmallest(x, start);    swap(x, start, smallestIndex);    sort(x, start + 1);    }/** Swap item a with b. */public static void swap(String[] x, int a, int b) {    String temp = x[a];    x[a] = x[b];    x[b] = temp;    }/** Return the index of the smallest String in x, starting at start. */public static int findSmallest(String[] x, int start) {        int smallestIndex = start;        for (int i = start; i < x.length; i += 1) {            int cmp = x[i].compareTo(x[smallestIndex]);            // from the internet, if x[i] < x[smallestIndex], cmp will be -1.            if (cmp < 0) {                smallestIndex = i;            }        }        return smallestIndex;    }}

The Evolution of Our Design

Now we have all the helper methods we need, as well as tests that make us pretty sure that they work! All thatâ€™s left is to write the sort method itself.

Very Tricky Problem

Bad But Tempting Solution

Without changing the signature of public static void sort(String[] a), how can we use recursion? What might the recursive call look like?

public static void sort(String[] x) {    int smallest = findSmallest(x);    swap(inputs, 0, smallest);    // recursive call??    // sort(x[1:]); â† Would be nice, but not possible!}

Some languages support sub-indexing into arrays. Java does not.

  • Bottom line: No way to get address of the middle of an array.

Good Solution

public static void sort(String[] x) {    sort(x, 0); }
/** Destructively sorts x starting at index k */public static void sort(String[] x, int k) {    ...    sort(x, k + 1);}

Major Design Flaw in findSmallest

We didnâ€™t properly account for how findSmallest would be used.

  • Example: Want to find smallest item from among the last 4:

  • We need another parameter so that itâ€™s actually useful for sorting.

And Weâ€™re Done!

Often, development is an incremental process that involves lots of task switching and on the fly design modification.

Tests provide stability and scaffolding.

  • Provide confidence in basic units and mitigate possibility of breaking them.
  • Help you focus on one task at a time.

In larger projects, tests also allow you to safely refactor! Sometimes code gets ugly, necessitating redesign and rewrites (see project 2).

One remaining problem: Sure was annoying to have to constantly edit which tests were running. Letâ€™s take care of that.

Simpler JUnit Tests (using two new syntax tricks)

Simple JUnit

New Syntax #1: org.junit.Assert.assertEquals(expected, actual);

  • Tests that expected equals actual.
  • If not, program terminates with verbose message.

Weâ€™ve already seen this throughout today.

JUnit does much more:

  • Other methods like assertEquals include assertFalse, assertNotNull, etc., Link.
  • Other more complex behavior to support more sophisticated testing.

Better JUnit

The messages output by JUnit are kind of ugly, and invoking each test manually is annoying.

New Syntax #2 (just trust me):

  • Annotate each test with @org.junit.Test.

  • Change all test methods to non-static.

    # Yes this is weird, as it implies youâ€™d be instantiating TestSort.java. In fact, JUnit runners do this. I donâ€™t know why.

  • Use a JUnit runner to run all tests and tabulate results.

    • IntelliJ provides a default runner/renderer. OK to delete main.
    • If you want to use the command line instead, see the jh61b runner in the lab 3 supplement. Not preferred.
    • Rendered output is easier to read, no need to manually invoke tests!

There is a lot of black magic happening here! Just accept it all for now.

Even Better JUnit

It is annoying to type out the name of the library repeatedly, e.g. org.junit.

Test and org.junit.Assert.assertEquals.

New Syntax #3: To avoid this weâ€™ll start every test file with:

import org.junit.Test;import static org.junit.Assert.*;

This will magically eliminate the need to type â€˜org.junitâ€™ or â€˜org.junit.Assertâ€™ (more after the midterm on what these imports really mean).

Testing Philosophy (Web Video Only)

Correctness Tool #1: Autograder

Idea: Magic autograder tells you code works.

  • We use JUnit + jh61b libraries.

Why?

  • Less time wasted on â€œboringâ€ stuff.
  • Determines your grade.
  • Gamifies correctness

Why not?

  • Autograders donâ€™t exist in real world.
  • Errors may be hard to understand.
  • Slow workflow.
  • No control if grader breaks / misbehaves.

Autograder Driven Development (ADD)

The worst way to approach programming:

  • Read and (mostly) understand the spec.
  • Write entire program.
  • Compile. Fix all compilation errors.
  • Send to autograder. Get many errors.
  • Until correct, repeat randomly:
    • Run autograder.
    • Add print statements to zero in on the bug.
    • Make changes to code to try to fix bug.
[63, 12, 91, 5, 0]got to this spot, lt is: 1got to this spot, lt is: 2got here![63, 12, 0, 5, 91]got to this spot, lt is: 3got to this spot, lt is: 4got here![5, 12, 0, 63, 91]Test Failed. Expected: ...

Correctness Tool #2: Unit Tests

Idea: Write tests for every â€œunitâ€.

  • JUnit makes this easy!

Why?

  • Build confidence in basic modules.
  • Decrease debugging time.
  • Clarify the task.

Why not?

  • Building tests takes time.
  • May provide false confidence.
  • Hard to test units that rely on others.
    • e.g. how do you test addFirst?

Test-Driven Development (TDD)

Steps to developing according to TDD:

  • Identify a new feature.
  • Write a unit test for that feature.
  • Run the test. It should fail. (RED)
  • Write code that passes test. (GREEN)
    • Implementation is certifiably good!
  • Optional: Refactor code to make it faster, cleaner, etc.

A Tale of Two Workflows

TDD is an extreme departure from the naive workflow.

  • Whatâ€™s best for you is probably in the middle.
$ python sort.py[63, 12, 91, 5, 0]got to this spot, lt is: 1got to this spot, lt is: 2got here![63, 12, 0, 5, 91]got to this spot, lt is: 3got to this spot, lt is: 4got here![5, 12, 0, 63, 91]

Correctness Tool #3: Integration Testing

Idea: Tests cover many units at once.

  • Not JUnitâ€™s focus, but JUnit can do this.

Why?

  • Unit testing is not enough to ensure modules interact properly or that system works as expected.

Why not?

  • Can be tedious to do manually.
  • Can be challenging to automate.
  • Testing at highest level of abstraction may miss subtle or rare errors.

More On JUnit (Extra)

What is an Annotation?

Annotations (like org.junit.Test) donâ€™t do anything on their own.

@Testpublic void testSort() {  ...}

Runner uses reflections library to iterate through all methods with â€œTestâ€ annotation. Pseudocode on next slide.

Sample Runner Pseudocode

Runner uses reflections library to iterate through all methods with â€œTestâ€ annotation.

List<Method> L = getMethodsWithAnnotation(TestSort.class, org.junit.Test);int numTests = L.size();int numPassed = 0;for (Method m : L) {    result r = m.execute();    if (r.passed == true) { numPassed += 1; }    if (r.passed == false) { System.out.println(r.message);}}System.out.println(numPassed + â€œ/â€ + numTests + â€œ passed!â€);

Overview

Why Test Code? In the real world, chances are you wonâ€™t have an autograder. When your code gets deployed into production, it is important that you know that it will work for simple cases as well as strange edge cases.

Test-Driven Development When provided an autograder, it is very easy to go â€œautograder happyâ€. Instead of actually understanding the spec and the requirements for a project, a student may write some base implementation, smash their code against the autograder, fix some parts, and repeat until a test is passed. This process tends to be a bit lengthy and really is not the best use of time. We will introduce a new programming method, Test-Driven Development (TDD), where the programmer writes the tests for a function BEFORE the actual function is written. Since unit tests are written before the function is, it becomes much easier to isolate errors in your code. Additionally, writing unit test requires that you have a relatively solid understanding of the task that you are undertaking. A drawback of this method is that it can be fairly slow and it can be easy to forget to test how functions interact with each other.

JUnit Tests JUnit is a package that is used to debug programs in Java. An example function that comes from JUnit is assertEquals(expected, actual). This function asserts that expected and actual have the same value. There are a bunch of other JUnit functions such as assertEquals, assertFalse, and assertNotNull.

When writing JUnit tests, it is good practice to write â€˜@Testâ€™ above the function that is testing. This allows for all your test methods to be run non statically.

entry.content:
Recursion

Q1: Num eights

Write a recursive function num_eights that takes a positive integer x and returns the number of times the digit 8 appears in x. Use recursion - the tests will fail if you use any assignment statements.

Watch the hints video for somewhere to start.

Q2: Ping-pong

The ping-pong sequence counts up starting from 1 and is always either counting up or counting down. At element k, the direction switches if k is a multiple of 8 or contains the digit 8. The first 30 elements of the ping-pong sequence are listed below, with direction swaps marked using brackets at the 8th, 16th, 18th, 24th, and 28th elements:

Index1234567[8]9101112131415[16]17[18]1920212223
PingPong Value1234567[8]7654321[0]1[2]10-1-2-3
Index (cont.)[24]252627[28]2930
PingPong Value[-4]-3-2-1[0]-1-2

mplement a function pingpong that returns the nth element of the ping-pong sequence without using any assignment statements.

You may use the function num_eights, which you defined in the previous question.

Use recursion - the tests will fail if you use any assignment statements.

Hint: If you're stuck, first try implementing pingpong using assignment statements and a while statement. Then, to convert this into a recursive solution, write a helper function that has a parameter for each variable that changes values in the body of the while loop.

Watch the hints video for somewhere to start.

Q3: Missing Digits

Write the recursive function missing_digits that takes a number n that is sorted in increasing order (for example, 12289 is valid but 15362 and 98764 are not). It returns the number of missing digits in n. A missing digit is a number between the first and last digit of n of a that is not in n. Use recursion - the tests will fail if you use while or for loops.

Watch the hints video for somewhere to start.

Q4: Count coins

Given a positive integer total, a set of coins makes change for total if the sum of the values of the coins is total. Here we will use standard US Coin values: 1, 5, 10, 25 For example, the following sets make change for 15:

  • 15 1-cent coins
  • 10 1-cent, 1 5-cent coins
  • 5 1-cent, 2 5-cent coins
  • 5 1-cent, 1 10-cent coins
  • 3 5-cent coins
  • 1 5-cent, 1 10-cent coin

Thus, there are 6 ways to make change for 15. Write a recursive function count_coins that takes a positive integer total and returns the number of ways to make change for total using coins. Use the next_largest_coin function given to you to calculate the next largest coin denomination given your current coin. I.e. next_largest_coin(5) = 10.

Hint: Refer the implementation of count_partitions for an example of how to count the ways to sum up to a total with smaller parts. If you need to keep track of more than one value across recursive calls, consider writing a helper function.

Just for Fun Questions

This question demonstrates that it's possible to write recursive functions without assigning them a name in the global frame.

Q5: Anonymous factorial

The recursive factorial function can be written as a single expression by using a conditional expression.

However, this implementation relies on the fact (no pun intended) that fact has a name, to which we refer in the body of fact. To write a recursive function, we have always given it a name using a def or assignment statement so that we can refer to the function within its own body. In this question, your job is to define fact recursively without giving it a name!

Write an expression that computes n factorial using only call expressions, conditional expressions, and lambda expressions (no assignment or def statements). Note in particular that you are not allowed to use make_anonymous_factorial in your return expression. The sub and mul functions from the operator module are the only built-in functions required to solve this problem:

entry.title: ALists, Resizing, vs. SLists
entry.content:
ALists, Resizing, vs. SLists

CS61B: Data structure

Video

A Last Look at Linked Lists

Doubly Linked Lists

Behold. The state of the art as we arrived at in last weekâ€™s lecture. Through various improvements, we made all of the following operations fast:

  • addFirst, addLast
  • getFirst, getLast
  • removeFirst, removeLast

Arbitrary Retrieval

Suppose we added get(int i), which returns the ith item from the list.

Why would get be slow for long lists compared to getLast()? For what inputs?

  • Have to scan to desired position.
  • Slow for any i not near the sentinel node.
  • How do we fix this?
    • Will discuss (much later) sophisticated changes that can speed up lists.
    • For now: Weâ€™ll take a different tack: Using an array instead (no links!).

Naive Array Lists

Random Access in Arrays

Retrieval from any position of an array is very fast.

  • Independent* of array size.
  • Ultra fast random access results from the fact that memory boxes are the same size (in bits).

Our Goal: AList.java

//         0 1  2 3 4 5 6 7// items: [6 9 -1 2 0 0 0 0 ...]// size: 5/* Invariants: addLast: The next item we want to add, will go into position size getLast: The item we want to return is in position size - 1 size: The number of items in the list should be size.*/public class AList {    private int[] items;        private int size;    public AList() {        items = new int[100];        size = 0;    }        public void addLast(int x) {        items[size] = x;        size += 1;    }    public int getLast() {        return items[size - 1];    }    public int get(int i) {        return items[i];    }    public int size() {        return size;    }}

AList Invariants:

  • The position of the next item to be inserted is always size.
  • size is always the number of items in the AList.
  • The last item in the list is always in position size - 1.

The Abstract vs. the Concrete

When we removeLast(), which memory boxes need to change? To what?-

  • size
  • size and items
  • size and items[i] for some i
  • size, items, and items[i] for some i
  • size, items, and items[i] for many different i
public int removeLast() {    int returnItem = items[size - 1];    items[size - 1] = 0;    /*    Setting deleted item to zero is not necessary to preserve invariants, and thus not necessary for correctness.    */    size -= 1;      return returnItem;}

The Mighty AList

Key Idea: Use some subset of the entries of an array.

What happens if we insert into the AList above? What should we do about it?

Resizing Arrays

When the array gets too full (size==items.length), e.g. addLast(11), just make a new array:

  • int[] a = new int[size+1];
  • System.arraycopy(...) # we call this process â€œresizingâ€
  • a[size] = 11;
  • items = a; size +=1;

Resizing Array Code

public void addLast(int x) {    if (size == items.length) {    int[] a = new int[size + 1];    System.arraycopy(items, 0, a, 0, size);    items = a;      }      items[size] = x;    size += 1;}
/* Much Better */private void resize(int capacity) {    int[] a = new int[capacity];    System.arraycopy(items, 0, a, 0, size);    items = a;} public void addLast(int x) {    if (size == items.length) {resize(size + 1);    }    items[size] = x;    size += 1;}

Runtime and Space Usage Analysis

Suppose we have a full array of size 100. If we call addLast two times, how many total array memory boxes will we need to create and fill (for just these 2 calls)?

  • 0
  • 101
  • 203
  • 10302

Bonus question: What is the maximum number of array boxes that Java will track at any given time? Assume that â€œgarbage collectionâ€ happens immediately when all references to an object are lost.

Array Resizing

Resizing twice requires us to create and fill 203 total memory boxes.

  • Bonus answer: Most boxes at any one time is 203.
  • When the second addLast is done, we are left with 102 boxes.

Suppose we have a full array of size 100. If we call addLast until size = 1000, roughly how many total array memory boxes will we need to create and fill?

  • 1,000
  • 500,000
  • 1,000,000
  • 500,000,000,000
  • 1,000,000,000,000

Total array boxes created/copied: 101 + 102 + â€¦ + 1000Since sum of 1 + 2 + 3 + â€¦ + N = N(N+1)/2, sum(101, â€¦, 1000) is close to 500,000.

Bonus question: What is the maximum number of array boxes that Java will track at any given time? Assume that â€œgarbage collectionâ€ happens immediately when all references to an object are lost.

Resizing Slowness

Inserting 100,000 items requires roughly 5,000,000,000 new containers.

  • Computers operate at the speed of GHz (due billions of things per second).
  • No huge surprise that 100,000 items took seconds.

Fixing the Resizing Performance Bug

How do we fix this?

Geometric resizing is much faster: Just how much better will have to wait.

/* Unusably bad */public void addLast(int x) {    if (size == items.length) {        resize(size + RFACTOR);    }    items[size] = x;    size += 1;}/* Great performance. This is how the Python list is implemented. */public void addLast(int x) {    if (size == items.length) {resize(size * RFACTOR);    }    items[size] = x;    size += 1;}

Performance Problem #2

Suppose we have a very rare situation occur which causes us to:

  • Insert 1,000,000,000 items.
  • Then remove 990,000,000 items.

Our data structure will execute these operations acceptably fast, but afterwards there is a problem.

  • What is the problem?

An AList should not only be efficient in time, but also efficient in space.

  • Define the â€œusage ratioâ€ R = size / items.length;
  • Typical solution: Half array size when R < 0.25.

Generic ALists

public class AList {    private int[] items;        private int size;     public AList() {        items = new int[8];          size = 0;    }     private void resize(int capacity) {        int[] a = new int[capacity];        System.arraycopy(items, 0, a, 0, size);        items = a;    }        public int get(int i) {        return items[i];    }...
public class AList<Glorp> {    private Glorp[] items;        private int size;     public AList() {        items = (Glorp []) new Object[8];          size = 0;    }     private void resize(int cap) {        Glorp[] a = (Glorp []) new Object[cap];        System.arraycopy(items, 0, a, 0, size);        items = a;    }    public Glorp get(int i) {        return items[i];    }...

When creating an array of references to Glorps:

  • (Glorp []) new Object[cap];
  • Causes a compiler warning, which you should ignore.

Why not just new Glorp[cap];

  • Will cause a â€œgeneric array creationâ€ error.

Nulling Out Deleted Items

Unlike integer based ALists, we actually want to null out deleted items.

  • Java only destroys unwanted objects when the last reference has been lost.
  • Keeping references to unneeded objects is sometimes called loitering.
  • Save memory. Donâ€™t loiter.

Loitering Example

Changing size to 2 yields a correct AList.

  • But memory is wasted storing a reference to the red sign image.

By nulling out items[2], Java is free to destroy the unneeded image from memory, which could be potentially megabytes in size

Obscurantism in Java

We talk of â€œlayers of abstractionâ€ often in computer science.

  • Related concept: obscurantism. The user of a class does not and should not know how it works.
    • The Java language allows you to enforce this with ideas like private!
  • A good programmer obscures details from themselves, even within a class.
    • Example: addFirst and resize should be written totally independently. You should not be thinking about the details of one method while writing the other. Simply trust that the other works.
    • Breaking programming tasks down into small pieces (especially functions) helps with this greatly!
    • Through judicious use of testing, we can build confidence in these small pieces, as weâ€™ll see in the next lecture.

Overview

Lists vs. Arrays Our DLList has a drawback. Getting the iâ€™th item is slow; we have to scan through each item in the list, starting from the beginning or the end, until we reach the iâ€™th item. For an array named A, however, we can quickly access the iâ€™th item using bracket notation, A[i]. Thus, our goal is to implement a list with an array.

AList The AList will have the same API as our DLList, meaning it will have the same methods as DLList (addLast(), getLast(), removeLast(), and get(int i)). The AList will also have a size variable that tracks its size.

AList Invariants There are a few invariants for our AList.

  • addLast: The next item we want to add, will go into position size.
  • getLast: The item we want to return is in position size - 1.
  • size: The number of items in the list should be size.

Implementing AList Each AList has an int[] called items.

  • For addLast, we place our item in items[size].
  • For getLast, we simply return items[size - 1].
  • For removeLast, we simply decrement size (we donâ€™t need to change items). Thus, if addLast is called next, it simply overwrites the old value, because size was decremented. However, it is good practice to null out objects when they are removed, as this will save memory. Notice how closely these methods were related to the invariants.

Abstraction One key idea of this course is that the implementation details can be hidden away from the users. For example, a user may want to use a list, but we, as implementers, can give them any implementation of a list, as long as it meets their specifications. A user should have no knowledge of the inner workings of our list.

Array Resizing When the array gets too full, we can resize the array. However, we have learned that array size cannot change. The solution is, instead, to create a new array of a larger size, then copy our old array values to the new array. Now, we have all of our old values, but we have more space to add items.

Resizing Speed In the lecture video, we started off resizing the array by one more each time we hit our array size limit. This turns out to be extremely slow, because copying the array over to the new array means we have to perform the copy operation for each item. The worst part is, since we only resized by one extra box, if we choose to add another item, we have to do this again each time we add to the array.

Improving Resize Performance Instead of adding by an extra box, we can instead create a new array with size * FACTOR items, where FACTOR could be any number, like 2 for example. We will discuss why this is fast later in the course.

Downsizing Array Size What happens if we have a 1 million length array, but we remove 990,000 elements of the array? Well, similarly, we can downsize our array by creating an array of half the size, if we reach 250,000 elements, for example. Again, we will discuss this more rigorously later in the course.

Aside: Breaking Code Up Sometimes, we write large methods that do multiple things. A better way is to break our large methods up into many smaller methods. One advantage of this is that we can test our code in parts.

Generic AList Last time, we discussed how to make a generic DLList. We can do something similar for AList. But we find that we error out on array creation. Our problem is that generic arrays are not allowed in Java. Instead, we will change the line:

items = new Item[100];

to:

items = (Item[]) new Object[100];

This is called a cast, and we will learn about it in the future.

entry.title: Discussion 3
entry.content:
Recursion

A recursive function is a function that is defined in terms of itself. A good example is the factorial function. Although we havenâ€™t finished defining factorial, we are still able to call it since the function body is not evaluated until the function is called. Note that when n is 0 or 1, we just return 1. This is known as the base case, and it prevents the function from infinitely recusing. Now we can compute factorial(2) in terms of factorial(1), and factorial(3) in terms of factorial(2), and factorial(4) â€“ well, you get the idea.

There are three common steps in a recursive definition:

  1. Figure out your base case: The base case is usually the simplest input possible to the function. For example, factorial(0) is 1 by definition. You can also think of a base case as a stopping condition for the recursion. If you canâ€™t figure this out right away, move on to the recursive case and try to figure out the point at which we canâ€™t reduce the problem any further.
  2. Make a recursive call with a simpler argument: Simplify your problem, and assume that a recursive call for this new problem will simply work. This is called the â€œleap of faithâ€. For factorial, we reduce the problem by calling factorial(n-1).
  3. Use your recursive call to solve the full problem: Remember that we are assuming the recursive call works. With the result of the recursive call, how can you solve the original problem you were asked? For factorial, we just multiply (n âˆ’ 1)! by n.

Another way to understand recursion is by separating out two things: â€œinternal correctnessâ€ and not running forever (known as â€œhaltingâ€)

A recursive function is internally correct if it is always does the right thing assuming that every recursive call does the right thing. For example, the factorial function reproduced to the right is internally correct, since 2! = 2 and n! = n âˆ— (n âˆ’ 1)! are both true statements.

The bad factorial function does not halt on all inputs, however, since factorial(1) results in a call to factorial(0), and then to factorial(-1) and so on.

A recursive function is correct if and only if it is both internally correct and halts; but you can check each property separately. The â€œrecursive leap of faithâ€ is temporarily placing yourself in a mindset where you only check internal correctness.

Questions

Write a function that takes two numbers m and n and returns their product. Assume m and n are positive integers. Use recursion, not mul or *!

Hint: 5*3 = 5 + 5*2 = 5 + 5 + 5*1.

For the base case, what is the simplest possible input for multiply?

If one of the inputs is one, you simply return the other input.

For the recursive case, what does calling multiply(m - 1, n) do? What does calling multiply(m, n - 1) do? Do we prefer one over the other?

The first call will calculate a value that is n less than the total, while the second will calculate a value that is m less.

Either recursive call will work, but only multiply(m, n - 1) is needed.

Below is the iterative version of is prime, which returns True if positive integer n is a prime number and False otherwise:

Implement the recursive is prime function. Do not use a while loop, use recursion. As a reminder, an integer is considered prime if it has exactly two unique factors: 1 and itself.

Write a procedure merge(n1, n2) which takes numbers with digits in decreasing order and returns a single number with all of the digits of the two, in decreasing order. Any number merged with 0 will be that number (treat 0 as having no digits). Use recursion. Hint: If you can figure out which number has the smallest digit out of both, then we know that the resulting number will have that smallest digit, followed by the merge of the two numbers with the smallest digit removed.

Define a function make fn repeater which takes in a one-argument function f and an integer x. It should return another function which takes in one argument, another integer. This function returns the result of applying f to x this number of times.

Make sure to use recursion in your solution.

entry.title: Recursion
entry.content:
Recursion

Video

Recursive Functions

Definition: A function is called recursive if the body of that function calls itself, either directly or indirectly

Implication: Executing the body of a recursive function may require applying that function

Digit Sums

2+0+1+9 = 12

  • If a number a is divisible by 9, then sum_digits(a) is also divisible by 9
  • Useful for typo detection!

  • Credit cards actually use the Luhn algorithm, which we'll implement after sum_digits

The Problem Within the Problem

The sum of the digits of 6 is 6.

Likewise for any one-digit (non-negative) number (i.e., < 10).

The sum of the digits of 2019 is

That is, we can break the problem of summing the digits of 2019 into a smaller instance of the same problem, plus some extra stuff.

We call this recursion

Sum Digits Without a While Statement

The Anatomy of a Recursive Function

Recursion in Environment Diagrams

Iteration vs Recursion

Iteration is a special case of recursion

Verifying Recursive Functions

Is fact implemented correctly?

  1. Verify the base case
  2. Treat fact as a functional abstraction!
  3. Assume that fact(n-1) is correct
  4. Verify that fact(n) is correct

Mutual Recursion

The Luhn Algorithm

Used to verify credit card numbers

  • First: From the rightmost digit, which is the check digit, moving left, double the value of every second digit; if product of this doubling operation is greater than 9 (e.g., 7 * 2 = 14), then sum the digits of the products (e.g., 10: 1 + 0 = 1, 14: 1 + 4 = 5)
  • Second: Take the sum of all the digits

The Luhn sum of a valid credit card number is a multiple of 10

Recursion and Iteration

Converting Recursion to Iteration

Can be tricky: Iteration is a special case of recursion.

Idea: Figure out what state must be maintained by the iterative function

More formulaic: Iteration is a special case of recursion.

Idea: The state of an iteration can be passed as arguments.

entry.title: DLLists, Arrays
entry.content:
DLLists, Arrays

CS61B: Data structure

Video

Doubly Linked Lists

Summary of Last Time (From IntList to SLList)

One Downside of SLLists

Inserting at the back of an SLList is much slower than the front.

public void addFirst(int x) {    sentinel.next = new IntNode(x, sentinel.next);} public void addLast(int x) {    size += 1;    IntNode p = sentinel;    while (p.next != null) {        p = p.next;    }     p.next = new IntNode(x, null);}

Improvement #7: Goal: Fast addLast

How could we modify our list data structure so that addLast is also fast?

Suppose we want to support add, get, and remove operations for both ends, will having a last pointer result for fast operations on long lists?

  • Yes
  • No

If not, which operations would be slow?

  • Requires setting 9â€™s next pointer to null, and point last at the 9 node.

    # i.e. slow because we have to find the â€œ9â€ node.

We added .last. What other changes might we make so that remove is also fast?

  • Add backwards links from every node.
  • This yields a â€œdoubly linked listâ€ or DLList, as opposed to our earlier â€œsingly linked listâ€ or SLList.

Note: Arrows point at entire nodes, not fields! Example: last holds the address of the last node, not the item field of the sentinel node

Doubly Linked Lists (Naive)

Non-obvious fact: This approach has an annoying special case: last sometimes points at the sentinel, and sometimes points at a â€˜realâ€™ node.

Doubly Linked Lists (Double Sentinel)

One solution: Have two sentinels.

Doubly Linked Lists (Circular Sentinel)

Improvement #8: Fancier Sentinel Node(s)

While fast, adding .last and .prev introduces lots of special cases.

To avoid these, either:

  • Add an additional sentBack sentinel at the end of the list.
  • Make your linked list circular, with a single sentinel in the middle.

DLList Summary

Generic Lists

Integer Only Lists

One issue with our list classes: They only supports integers.

public class SLList {    private IntNode sentinel;    private int size;        public class IntNode {        public int item;        public IntNode next;        ...    }    ...}SLList s1 = new SLList(5);s1.addFirst(10);/*Works fine*/SLList s2 = new SLList("hi");s2.addFirst("apple");/*Error*/

SLists

Java allows us to defer type selection until declaration.

public class SLList<BleepBlorp> {    private IntNode sentinel;    private int size;    public class IntNode {        public BleepBlorp item;        public IntNode next;        ...    }    ...}SLList<Integer> s1 = new SLList<>(5);s1.insertFront(10); SLList<String> s2 = new SLList<>("hi");s2.insertFront("apple");

Generics

  • In the .java file implementing your data structure, specify your â€œgeneric typeâ€ only once at the very top of the file.
  • In .java files that use your data structure, specify desired type once:
    • Write out desired type during declaration.
    • Use the empty diamond operator <> during instantiation.
  • When declaring or instantiating your data structure, use the reference type.
    • int: Integer
    • double: Double
    • char: Character
    • boolean: Boolean
    • long: Long
    • etc.
DLList<Double> s1 = new DLList<>(5.3);double x = 9.3 + 15.2;s1.insertFront(x);

Arrays

Getting Memory Boxes

To store information, we need memory boxes, which we can get in Java by declaring variables or instantiating objects. Examples:

  • int x;
    • Gives us a memory box of 32 bits that stores ints.
  • Walrus w1;
    • Gives us a memory box of 64 bits that stores Walrus references.
  • Walrus w2 = new Walrus(30, 5.6);
    • Gives us a memory box of 64 bits that stores Walrus references, and also gives us 96 bits for storing the int size (32 bits) and double tuskSize (64 bits) of our Walrus.

Arrays are a special kind of object which consists of a numbered sequence of memory boxes.

  • To get ith item of array A, use A[i].
  • Unlike class instances which have have named memory boxes.

Arrays consist of:

  • A fixed integer length (cannot change!)
  • A sequence of N memory boxes where N=length, such that:
    • All of the boxes hold the same type of value (and have same # of bits).
    • The boxes are numbered 0 through length-1.

Like instances of classes:

  • You get one reference when its created.
  • If you reassign all variables containing that reference, you can never get the array back.

Unlike classes, arrays do not have methods.

Like classes, arrays are (almost always) instantiated with new.

Three valid notations:

  • x = new int[3];
    • Creates array containing 3 int boxes (32 x 3 = 96 bits total). Each container gets a default value.
  • y = new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
  • int[] z = {9, 10, 11, 12, 13};
    • Can omit the new if you are also declaring a variable.

All three notations create an array, which we saw on the last slide comprises:

  • A length field.
  • A sequence of N boxes, where N = length.
int[] z = null;int[] x, y; x = new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4, 5};y = x;x = new int[]{-1, 2, 5, 4, 99};y = new int[3];z = new int[0];int xL = x.length; String[] s = new String[6];s[4] = "ketchup";s[x[3] - x[1]] = "muffins"; int[] b = {9, 10, 11};System.arraycopy(b, 0, x, 3, 2);

Arraycopy

Two ways to copy arrays:

  • Item by item using a loop.
  • Using arraycopy. Takes 5 parameters:
    • Source array
    • Start position in source
    • Target array
    • Start position in target
    • Number to copy
System.arraycopy(b, 0, x, 3, 2);// (In Python): x[3:5] = b[0:2]

arraycopy is (likely to be) faster, particularly for large arrays. More compact code.

  • Code is (arguably) harder to read.

2D Arrays

Arrays of Array Addresses

  • Syntax for arrays of arrays can be a bit confounding. Youâ€™ll learn through practice (much later).

Array Boxes Can Contain References to Arrays!

  • Syntax for arrays of arrays can be a bit confounding. Youâ€™ll learn through practice (much later).

What Does This Code Do?

What will be the value of x[0][0] and w[0][0] when the code shown completes?

  1. x: 1, w: 1
  2. x: 1, w: -1
  3. x: -1, w: 1
  4. x: -1, w: -1
  5. Other

arraycopy parameters are:

  1. Source array
  2. Start position in source
  3. Target array
  4. Start position in target
  5. Number to copy
int[][] x = {{1, 2, 3}, {4, 5, 6}, {7, 8, 9}}; int[][] z = new int[3][];z[0] = x[0];z[0][0] = -z[0][0]; int[][] w = new int[3][3];System.arraycopy(x[0], 0, w[0], 0, 3);w[0][0] = -w[0][0];

Arrays vs. Classes

Arrays and Classes can both be used to organize a bunch of memory boxes.

  • Array boxes are accessed using [] notation.
  • Class boxes are accessed using dot notation.
  • Array boxes must all be of the same type.
  • Class boxes may be of different types.
  • Both have a fixed number of boxes.

Array indices can be computed at runtime.

int[] x = new int[]{100, 101, 102, 103};int indexOfInterest = askUser();int k = x[indexOfInterest];System.out.println(k);

Class member variable names CANNOT be computed and used at runtime.

String fieldOfInterest = "mass";Planet earth = new Planet(6e24, "earth");double mass = earth[fieldOfInterest];System.out.println(mass);

Class member variable names CANNOT be computed and used at runtime.

  • Dot notation doesnâ€™t work either.
String fieldOfInterest = "mass";Planet earth = new Planet(6e24, "earth");double mass = earth.fieldOfInterest;System.out.println(mass);

Another view

The only (easy) way to access a member of a class is with hard-coded dot notation.

int k = x[indexOfInterest];  /* no problem */ double m = p.fieldOfInterest;  /* won't work */double z = p[fieldOfInterest]; /* won't work *//* No (sane) way to use field of interest */double w = p.mass;             /* works fine */

The Java compiler does not treat text on either side of a dot as an expression, and thus it is not evaluated.

  • See a compilers or programming languages class for more!

Overview

SLList Drawbacks addLast() is slow! We canâ€™t add to the middle of our list. In addition, if our list is really large, we have to start at the front, and loop all the way to the back of our list before adding our element.

A Naive Solution Recall that we cached the size of our list as an instance variable of SLList. What if we cached the last element in our list as well? All of a sudden, addLast() is fast again; we access the last element immediately, then add our element in. But removeLast() is still slow. In removeLast(), we have to know what our second-to-last element is, so we can point our cached last variable to it. We could then cache a second-to-last variable, but now if I ever want to remove the second-to-last element, I need to know where our third-to-last element is. How to solve this problem?

DLList The solution is to give each IntNode a prev pointer, pointing to the previous item. This creates a doubly-linked list, or DLList. With this modification, adding and removing from the front and back of our list becomes fast (although adding/removing from the middle remains slow).

Incorporating the Sentinel Recall that we added a sentinel node to our SLList. For DLList, we can either have two sentinels (one for the front, and one for the back), or we can use a circular sentinel. A DLList using a circular sentinel has one sentinel. The sentinel points to the first element of the list with next and the last element of the list with prev. In addition, the last element of the listâ€™s next points to the sentinel and the first element of the listâ€™s prev points to the sentinel. For an empty list, the sentinel points to itself in both directions.

Generic DLList How can we modify our DLList so that it can be a list of whatever objects we choose? Recall that our class definition looks like this:

public class DLList { ... }

We will change this to

public class DLList<T> { ... }

where T is a placeholder object type. Notice the angle bracket syntax. Also note that we donâ€™t have to use T; any variable name is fine. In our DLList, our item is now of type T, and our methods now take T instances as parameters. We can also rename our IntNode class to TNode for accuracy.

Using Generic DLList Recall that to create a DLList, we typed:

DLList list = new DLList(10);

If we now want to create a DLList holding String objects, then we must say:

DLList<String> list = new DLList<>("bone");

On list creation, the compiler replaces all instances of T with String! We will cover generic typing in more detail in later lectures.

Arrays Recall that variables are just boxes of bits. For example, int x; gives us a memory box of 32 bits. Arrays are a special object which consists of a numbered sequence of memory boxes! To get the ith item of array A, use A[i]. The length of an array cannot change, and all the elements of the array must be of the same type (this is different from a Python list). The boxes are zero-indexed, meaning that for a list with N elements, the first element is at A[0] and the last element is at A[N - 1]. Unlike regular classes, arrays do not have methods! Arrays do have a length variable though.

Instantiating Arrays There are three valid notations for creating arrays. The first way specifies the size of the array, and fills the array with default values:

int[] y = new int[3];

The second and third ways fill up the array with specific values.

int[] x = new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4, 5};int[] w = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};

We can set a value in an array by using array indexing. For example, we can say A[3] = 4;. This will access the fourth element of array A and sets the value at that box to 4.

Arraycopy In order to make a copy of an array, we can use System.arraycopy. It takes 5 parameters; the syntax is hard to memorize, so we suggest using various references online such as this.

2D Arrays We can declare multidimensional arrays. For 2D integer arrays, we use the syntax:

int[][] array = new int[4][];

This creates an array that holds integer arrays. Note that we have to manually create the inner arrays like follows:

array[0] = new int[]{0, 1, 2, 3};

Java can also create multidemensional arrays with the inner arrays created automatically. To do this, use the syntax:

int[][] array = new int[4][4];

We can also use the notation:

int[][] array = new int[][]{{1}, {1, 2}, {1, 2, 3}}

to get arrays with specific values.

Arrays vs. Classes

  • Both are used to organize a bunch of memory.
  • Both have a fixed number of â€œboxesâ€.
  • Arrays are accessed via square bracket notation. Classes are accessed via dot notation.
  • Elements in the array must be all be the same type. Elements in a class may be of different types.
  • Array indices are computed at runtime. We cannot compute class member variable names.

entry.title: Proving with Predicates
entry.content:
Proving with Predicates

Inference rules

â†’ Introduction

  • Cf. propositional rule
  • p(x) and q(x) are propositions

If the only assumption about x is that it is a member of U, and if this assumption leads to the truth of q(x), then q must hold for every member of U

If at least one element of a set satisfies a predicate, this justifies the introduction of âˆƒ

âˆ§ Elimination

  • Also called instantiation
  • Generalises propositional âˆ§-elimination
  • If p is true for all possible arguments, it must be true for a particular one

  • a must not be the name of a particular member of U
  • a should not have been mentioned earlier in the proof

Proof strategies

From: âˆƒX âˆˆ U : P(X)

  • Proof by example
    • Show that p(x) is TRUE for a specific x
  • Algorithmic Proof
    • Give an algorithm for finding a specific x for which p(x) is TRUE
    • Prove that the algorithm cannot fail
  • âˆ€ Introduction
    • Assume x âˆˆ U and show that p(x) is a consequence
    • Important to assume x is an arbitrary element of U

FORM: Â¬âˆ€X âˆˆ U : P(X)

  • Proof by counterexample
    • Use a De Morgan law
    • (Â¬âˆ€x âˆˆ U : p(x)) â‰¡ (âˆƒx âˆˆ U : Â¬p(x))
    • Proof by example that there exists an x for which Â¬p is TRUE

FORM: âˆ€X âˆˆ N : P(X)

  • Proof by mathematical induction

Applying logic to mathematics

Introduction

New application domain:

  • New predicates
  • New inference rules

Rules

  • Subset Rule
    • A âŠ† B follows from âˆ€x âˆˆ A : (x âˆˆ B)
  • Set equality rule
    • A = B follows from A âŠ† B and B âŠ† A
  • Transitivity of <
    • a < c follows from a < b and b < c
    • E.g. =, âŠ† and â‰¡ are transitive as well
  • Pigeon hole principle
    • If n + 1 occurrences are assigned to n categories, there must be one category with at least two occurrences

Example proof

  • Definition:
    • âˆ€x âˆˆ N : Odd(x) â†”ï¸ âˆƒw âˆˆ N : (x = 2w + 1)
  • Prove:
    • â€œIf a and b are odd, then a times b is oddâ€
    • âˆ€a âˆˆ N : âˆ€b âˆˆ *N : (Odd(a) âˆ§ Odd(b) â†’ Odd(ab))

Exercise

Prove that for any n its successor times its predecessor is 1 less than its square. In other words, prove that âˆ€n âˆˆ N : P(n), where P(n) is (n + 1)(n - 1) = n2 - 1. You do not need mathematical induction for this. Use V introduction and arithmetic manipulations involving distributivity and associativity. You may regard other rules of algebra as common knowledge that do not need to be explicitly provided as justifications. Lay out your proof like the rules-of-inference proofs in Chapter 3, justifying each step by stating its rule of inference.

Solution

Prove: âˆ€n âˆˆ N : (n + 1)(n âˆ’ 1) = n2 âˆ’ 1

  1. [n âˆˆ N] Assumption
  2. (n + 1)(n âˆ’ 2) = n2 âˆ’ n + n âˆ’ 1 Distributivity
  3. (n + 1)(n âˆ’ 2) = n2 âˆ’ 1
  4. âˆ€n âˆˆ N : (n + 1)(n âˆ’ 2) = n2 âˆ’ 1 âˆ€ introduction

Mathematical induction

Introduction

  • Mathematical induction (MI) is used for proving things about infinite sets of propositions
  • Key idea: when trying to prove P(n), we assume that P(n âˆ’ 1) has already been established
  • This is called the inductive hypothesis

Base case and inductive step

  • A proof by MI has two parts:
    • Base case (BC): typically P(0)
    • Inductive step (IS): typically P(n âˆ’ 1) â†’ P(n)
  • When we make no assumptions about n except that n â‰¥ 1 , this is true for any n â‰¥ 1
  • Repeated use of the inductive step with modus ponens gives us: P(0) (from BC) â†’ P(1) â†’ P(2), â†’ ... â†’ P(n)

Rule of inference

Framework

Example

  • Show that, for any non-negative integer n, the sum of the first n integers is n(n + 1)/2
  • That is, prove P(n), n â‰¥ 0, where P(n) represents:

Example proof

Example proof: algebra

Strategies -1

If Q(n) is true for all integers â‰¥ k but false for k âˆ’ 1

  • Base: P(0) = Q(k)
  • General: P(n) = Q(n + k)

Predicate Q is only true for odd integers

  • P(n) = Q(2n + 1) or P(n) = Q(2n âˆ’ 1)

Predicate Q is only true for powers of 2

  • P(n) = Q(n2)7

Strategies -2

p(n) â†’ P(n + 1) as the inductive step

  • Sometimes eases algebraic manipulations
  • Now: n â‰¥ 0

When P(n) is an equation L(n) = R(n) and you show that L(n) = L(n âˆ’ 1) + Î± = ... = R(n âˆ’ 1) + Î² = R(n)

  • Showing that Î± = Î², together with the inductive hypothesis L(n âˆ’ 1) = R(n âˆ’ 1) concludes the proof

Example

Prove that âˆ€n â‰¥ 5 : 2n > n2

Exercise

Prove by mathematical induction that the sum of the first n odd integers is n2

Prove by mathematical induction that for any integer n â‰¥ 10, 2n > n3

Prove by mathematical induction: âˆ€n âˆˆ N : n â‰¥ 4 : n! â‰¥ 2n

Prove by mathematical induction:

Limits of logic

Soundness of rules

  • A rule is sound if it is true in all states, i.e. if it is a tautology
  • Soundness can for example be proved using truth tables
  • Propositional logic:
    • Start set: soundness proven by truth tables
      • E.g. modus ponens, modus tollens, ...
    • Rules proven by inference from this start set
      • E.g. transitivity of the conditional
      • These rules are equally sound

System of logic

A system of logic consists of:

  • A set of axioms
  • A set of inference rules

A system of logic is complete if:

  • All true expressions can be proven

A system of logic is consistent if:

  • It is impossible to prove any expression to be both true and false

Soundness, completeness and consistency

We seek a system:

  • with sound rules
  • that is complete
  • that is consistent

Such systems exist for propositional logic

Such systems do not exist for predicate logic (cf. GÃ¶delâ€™s incompleteness theorems)

Semiconductor Manufacturing: Silicon â†’ Wafers 3:41

From silicon ore to silicon wafers

Reduction of quartzite (SiO2) 5:38

Submerged electrode arc furnace

Reduction to ~98% pure Si (mostly Al & Fe impurities)

SiC(s) + SiO2(s) â†’ Si(l) + SiO(g) + CO(g)

Purification of silicon 8:40

Metallurgical grade Si â†’ Electronic grade Si

  • Fractional distillation process:

    Si(s) +3HCl(g) â†’ SiHCl3(g) +H2(g) +heat

  • Fluidized bed reactor @300Â°C:

    SiHCl3(g) +H2(g) â†’ Si(s) +3HCl(g)

  • Can be looped to increase purity to less than 1 part per 109.

Making polycrystalline Si into a monocrystalline Si 11:44

Starting from a seed crystal

Main used technique: Czochralski crystal growth method (>1412Â°C)

  • Suited for large Si wafers but may have some oxygen inclusion impurities.

Starting from a seed crystal

Alternative technique: Float zone technique

  • Very high purity but small wafers. Used for detectors, power devices, expensive high-efficiency solar panels (spacecraft). Also, highly transparent to THz waves.

Wafer shaping & cutting 18:06

Largest wafers used today: 300mm diameter, ~775Âµm thick

  • Remove both ends of ingot
  • Surface grinding, edge bevelling
  • Wafer cutting with industrial grade diamond.

Semiconductor manufacturing: Wafers â†’ Integrated circuits

Clean rooms 21:41

Design & contamination control

  • Modern IC chips have transistors in the 10nm range â†’ sub-Âµm particles may damage or destroy parts of chips â†’ cleanroom to minimize contaminants
  • More contaminants means lower wafer yield, performance (lifetime) and reliability
  • ISO cleanroom standards: maximum number of particles/volume bigger than some threshold
ContaminantExamplesSource
ParticlesDust, hair, flakes (Âµm range)Humans, equipment (friction), chemicals

Main categories of IC device manufacturing 27:53

Layering: growing and deposition

Layering: growing techniques 29:49

Consumes underlying silicon for forming new layer

Oxidation: Si + O2 â†’ SiO2

Nitration: 3Si + 2N2 â†’ Si3N4

  • Electrical isolation (oxide layer is superior)
  • Oxide layer acts as the active gate in MOSFET
  • Protective layer, passivation (nitride is superior), T resistance
  • Used for patterning
  • Variants: â€œwetâ€ and â€œdryâ€ oxidation

Layering: deposition techniques 34:28

Does not consume silicon, new layer is deposited

  • homo/hetero epitaxy
  • Silicon films: epitaxy layer, polysilicon
  • Dielectric Films: SiO2, Nitride, â€¦
  • Metals: aluminum, tungsten, TiN, â€¦
  • Used for Ga & As

  • Can be used for doping too

Depositing of thin metallic layers for

  • Contact metals in thin-film transistors
  • Hard disk production
  • Antireflection coating in optics
  • Inexpensive equipment â†’ relatively cheap
  • Relatively uniform and compact deposits, but not as much as CVD or sputtering
  • Generally use for layers > 1Âµm

Lithography & Etching

Patterning or Lithography 44:41

Selectively mask or expose parts of the wafer

  • Determines the critical dimensions of the device (now 10nm & 7nm)
  • Highly defect sensitive (pattern creation & alignment)
  • Reticle: hard copy of design â†’ made with laser writing or electron beam
  • Developing-expose through mask; first phase is reversible

Typically in conjunction with lithography

  • Dry etching: exposure to ion bombardment for dislodging surface material

Doping: making extrinsic semiconductors 55:11

Achieving specific dopant concentration & distribution, creating junctions

  • Thermal diffusion (impurity source can be solid, liquid or gaseous)
    • High T: lithography canâ€™t be used â†’ SiO2 layer

  • Ion implantation
    • Around room T, conventional lithography possible
    • Leads to damage of wafer surface â†’ post annealing

Packaging 1:00:30

Readying the IC for use

System on a Chip (SoC): all components integrated into one chip

System on a Package (SoP): all components integrated into one chip (e.g., In mobile phones)

Functions of packaging:

  1. Lead system
  2. Physical protection
  3. Minimizing environmental impact
  4. Heat dissipation

Handling interconnects

  • Wirebond

  • Flip-Chip

  • Chip-Stack

Example: MOSFET fabrication steps 1:04:50

NMOS

  1. Lightly P-doped substrate
  2. Oxidation (thick field oxide)
  3. Lithography + oxide etching
  4. Thin, high-quality oxide layer for FET gate formation
  5. Polysilicon deposition (gate electrode material + interconnect medium in IC)
  6. Polysilicon etching
  7. Oxide etching h) High concentration n-doping
  8. Insulating oxide layer
  9. Etching step
  10. Metallization layer (Al) for interconnects

Memory technologies

The Memory hierarchy in a computer 1:09:43

Optimizing cost and speed

Static random-access memory 1:13:45

Properties:

  • Volatile
  • Bits are stored as on/off switches
  • No charges to leak
  • No refreshing needed when powered
  • More complex construction
  • Larger per bit
  • More expensive
  • Faster
  • Primarily used for caching
  • Digital â†’ uses flip-flops

Operation

Dynamic random-access memory 1:24:20

Propertiesï¼š

  • Volatile
  • Bits stored as charge in capacitors
  • Charges leak â†’ Need to refresh circuits periodically
  • Simpler construction
  • Smaller per bit
  • Less expensive
  • Slower
  • Main memory (Computer â€œRAMâ€)
  • Essentially analogue â†’ charge level determines value

Operation

DDR RAM generations

Flash memory 1:33:52

Introduction

Flash memory stores information in an array of memory cells made from floating gate transistors.

  • Non-volatile
  • Traditional single-level cell (SLC) devices: 1 bit/cell
  • Newer multi-level cell (MLC) devices can store multiple bits/cell by choosing between multiple levels of charge.

Reading of a single cell

Writing of cells: tunnelling

NOR Flash memory

NAND Flash memory

NOR vs NAND flash

  • NOR Flash

    • Faster to read than NAND

    • Slower to erase & write

    • Larger cells

    • More expensive

      â†’ Use in mobile devices, tablets, ...

  • NAND Flash

    • Slower to read than NOR

    • Faster to erase & write

    • Much smaller cells

    • Less expensive

      â†’ High memory density

      â†’ Good for SD cards, Digital cameras, USB sticks

Hard Disk Drives (HDD) 1:49:55

Introduction

  • Magnetic storage
  • About 90% of data centre storage

Basic operation

  • Reading head floats only a few nm above the ferromagnetic film of the disk platter.
  • Current in write head induces magnetic field â†’ alters bits
  • Read element will detects voltage changes, induced by motion over the magnetic field.
  • Transition to perpendicular recording in ~2005 â†’ more magnetically stable, stronger fields â†’ boost in density
  • In modern HDDs take up less than 50 nm/bit

Helium sealed drives

  • Drag on rotating platters scales as ğœŒğ‘£3.
  • Helium is ~7 less dense than air + has better thermal conductivity
    • Reduction in power
    • Lower turbulence
    • Better cooling
  • More thinner platters possible â†’ more capacity
  • Introduced to the market in 2013

Challenge: the superparamagnetic effect

  • Individual grains are only ~8nm in diameter

  • Physical limit - the superparamagnetic effect: magnetization can randomly flip direction under the influence of temperature.

  • Current materials do not allow to go below ~7nm grains.

  • Coercivity is a measure of the ability of a ferromagnetic material to withstand an external magnetic field without becoming demagnetized.

  • Higher coercivity means higher stability, but also harder to write to â†’ new writing technologies needed.

  • Microwave-Assisted Magnetic Recording (MAMR) uses 20-40 GHz frequencies to bombard the disk platter with a circular microwave field, lowering its coercivity and enabling the bit value to be written.

  • Heat-Assisted Magnetic Recording (HAMR) uses a tiny 200 mW laser beam to heat up the disk platter to 400 Â°C and permit the writing operation.

  • Heated-Dot Magnetic Recording (HDMR) extends HAMR, patterning the disk into small â€œdotsâ€. This allows to better focus the laser energy on individual dots.

  • Expected 10x gains in density over current HDDs on the market â†’ >100 TB HDDs

entry.title: Discussion 2
entry.content:
Higher Order Functions

A higher order function (HOF) is a function that manipulates other functions by taking in functions as arguments, returning a function, or both. For example, the function compose1 below takes in two functions as arguments and returns a function that is the composition of the two arguments.

HOFs are powerful abstraction tools that allow us to express certain general patterns as named concepts in our programs.

A Note on Lambda Expressions

A lambda expression evaluates to a function, called a lambda function.

For example, lambda y: x + y is a lambda expression, and can be read as â€œa function that takes in one parameter y and returns x + y.â€

A lambda expression by itself evaluates to a function but does not bind it to a name.

Also note that the return expression of this function is not evaluated until the lambda is called.

This is similar to how defining a new function using a def statement does not execute the functionâ€™s body until it is later called.

Unlike def statements, lambda expressions can be used as an operator or an operand to a call expression. This is because they are simply one-line expressions that evaluate to functions. In the example below, (lambda y: y + 5) is the operator and 4 is the operand.

Currying

One important application of HOFs is converting a function that takes multiple arguments into a chain of functions that each take a single argument. This is known as currying.

For example, the function below converts the pow function into its curried form:

Self Reference

Self-reference refers to a particular design of HOF, where a function eventually returns itself. In particular, a self-referencing function will not return a function call, but rather the function object itself. As an example, take a look at the print all function to the right.

Self-referencing functions will oftentimes employ helper functions that reference the outer function, such as the example to the right, print sums.

Note that a call to print sums returns next sum. A call to next sum will return the result of calling print sums which will, in turn, return another function next sum. This type of pattern is common in self-referencing functions.

. Small Note: This differs from recursion because typically each new call returns a new function rather than a function call. We have not yet covered recursion so donâ€™t worry too much about what this means!

Abstraction

Functional Abstractions

What does sum_squares need to know about square?

  • Square takes one argument. YES
  • Square has the intrinsic name square. NO
  • Square computes the square of a number. YES
  • Square computes the square by calling mul. NO

If the name â€œsquareâ€ were bound to a built-in function, sum_squares would still work identically.

Choosing Names

Names typically donâ€™t matter for correctness, but they matter a lot for composition

Names should convey the meaning or purpose of the values to which they are bound.

The type of value bound to the name is best documented in a function's docstring.

Function names typically convey their effect (print), their behaviour (triple), or the value returned (abs).
