Discussion 2: Extended Entity-Relationship Model

Background

Video

Exercise 1

Recap: Extended ER Model

  • ISA relationships

    Inheritance of entities

  • Aggregations

    Replace n-ary relations with a higher level entity

  • Part-Of Hierarchies

    Convention for indicating parts (already possible in ER but no formal syntax)

Twitter: Description 17:17

Twitter is a platform where users can register with a unique username (their Twitter handle). When logged in, they can post messages called â€™ Tweets â€™ that are max 120 characters long and optionally can contain an image, video or poll. However, a tweet can only contain one interactive component (either an image, video or poll). These tweets are uniquely identified by a number and can be liked by other users. Any user can reply to tweets and even â€™ retweet â€™/repost the tweet on their own homepage. Users can choose to follow other users to get notified on their activity.

How do we make sure only one interactive component (Media) can be used?

Note: This is a bit hard to read ... Split the drawing in parts

The common attribute is name, Create a Person entity link to Student and Employee.

How do we retweet a tweet? 30:31

  1. Add it as a media component similar to image, video and poll?
  2. Add an ISA relation to tweet for both a â€™Regularâ€™ and â€™Retweetedâ€™ tweet?
  3. Create an optional relation from Tweet to Tweet called â€™retweetâ€™, similar to a reply?
  4. Since retweets can not be replies as well, we can use the replyTo relation with some additional â€™retweetâ€™ flag?

EER Diagram

In the following exercises, you will receive a description of a database or application. Using this description, create an EER diagram that covers the requirements. You can make the EER diagrams on paper or use an online drawing tool such as https://draw.io.

Medical Database 50:00

Patients are identified by their social security number (SSN). They have a name, address (which consists of a street name, house number, postal code, city and country), telephone number, age and email address. They all have their preferred doctor. Doctors are also identified by their SSN. For each doctor a name, age, telephone number, address and specialities are stored.

Pharmaceutical companies will also be stored in the database. They are identified by their company name. Furthermore, their telephone number and address are stored along with a contact person. This contact person is identified by his SSN and has an age, address, telephone number and email address.

For each medicine, the name (unique) and formula is stored. Each medicine is made in a pharmaceutical company. Some medicines are made by only one pharmaceutical company, while others are made by several companies. Pharmacies sell medicines. Each pharmacy has its own prices for the medicines they sell.

Pharmacists (i.e., managers of pharmacies) are identified by their SSN. Similar to other persons they have an age, address and telephone number. Be aware that doctors can not be pharmacists as well. The pharmacies have a unique address and telephone number (this number is the same as the telephone number of the pharmacist).

Doctors prescribe medicines to patients. Of course, a patient can receive prescriptions from multiple doctors. Each prescription has a date, the medicines that were prescribed and their dose.

Pharmaceutical companies have long term contracts with certain pharmacies. Pharmacies may have such contracts with several pharmaceutical companies. For each contract, the start-and end date is specified and a list of medicines for which an agreement was reached. The full text of the contract is also stored.

Solution

Please note that the following EER-Models are one possible solution. The exercises can be interpreted in different ways but should be able to contain the data explained in the description. We use the original ER-cardinality style for these solutions.

For ease of readability we divided the solution in the ISA relations and the actual EER-model.

entry.title: Proof by Resolution
entry.content:
Proof by Resolution

Objectives

Learn about general-purpose theorem proving in predicate calculus

The Problem

Given

  • a knowledge base, KB (a set of sentences, S, and an interpretation, I)

Prove

  • a sentence, Î± (under the same interpretation, I)

Formally

  • Show that KB âŠ§ Î± à¹ KB entails Î± à¹ Î± follows from KB

The Toolbox

Modus ponens

  • Given { p â†’ q, p } âŠ‚ KB, is q true?
  • Yes: { p â†’ q, p } âŠ§ { q }

Modus Tollens

  • Given { p â†’ q, Â¬q } âŠ‚ KB, is p true?
  • No: { p â†’ q, Â¬q } âŠ§ { Â¬p }

We can form arbitrarily long â€œchainsâ€ of inference to prove a sentence

We can reason

  • forwards from what we know to what we want to prove
  • backwards from what we want to prove to what we know
    • backwards is generally more efficient: no search branches leading off-topic

Theorem Proving

A theorem proving process involves choosing and applying such rules until the desired sentence is shown to be entailed

Itâ€™s called a proof because the rules used are known, a priori, to be sound (i.e., correct)

However, choice of rule is hard, because you canâ€™t know that a particular rule chosen from a range will turn out to be the right one, in a long proof

  • e.g., Modus Ponens is incomplete
  • therefore, each time we use it, we also have to consider other possibilities
  • therefore, each time we use it, we create a set of alternative choices

Modus Ponens is incomplete

Consider these rules:

  • If it is raining (R), I will carry an umbrella (U)
  • If it is not raining (Â¬R), I will carry an umbrella (U)

It is easy to conclude (as a human) that I always carry an umbrella

  • { R â†’ U, Â¬R â†’ U } âŠ§ { U }
  • but this isnâ€™t provable using modus ponens alone
    • weâ€™d need the law of excluded middle: R âˆ¨ Â¬R

However, there is a more general rule, that is complete

Resolution

Unit resolution

  • { P âˆ¨ Q, Â¬Q } âŠ§ { P }

Generalised resolution

  • { P âˆ¨ Q, R âˆ¨ Â¬Q } âŠ§ { P âˆ¨ R }

Example: Umbrella again

Resolution refutation

This simple rule can be used as follows

  • add the negation of the sentence, S, to be proven to the KB
  • see if this leads to a contradiction

This idea applies the law of the excluded middle

  • if Â¬S is inconsistent with KB, then KB âŠ§ S

This is called resolution refutation

  • this is the basis of the â€œLogic Programmingâ€ language, Prolog

Notation

  • note that the premises are brought in when needed, not all at the top

Clausal Form

Resolution is a single, simple, sound, complete rule

  • But we had to do some manipulation first, to get the sentences into a form on which we could use it

This is clausal normal form (CNF)

  • Note that CNF also stands for Conjunctive Normal Form

Putting FOPC sentences into clausal form is a mechanical procedure that can be done without search

Clausal Normal Form in FOPC

  1. Rewrite â†’: a â†’ b â‡’ Â¬a âˆ¨ b

  2. Minimise the scope of negations using logical definitions given before

    • Â¬âˆƒx.A(x) â‡’ âˆ€x. Â¬A(x)
    • Â¬âˆ€x.A(x) â‡’ âˆƒx.Â¬A(x)
    • Â¬(A âˆ¨ B) â‡’ Â¬A âˆ§ Â¬B
    • Â¬(A âˆ§ B) â‡’ Â¬A âˆ¨ Â¬B
    • etc.

    Note that in this case, these definitions are unidirectional, so they are confluent

    • no need for searching through alternatives

  3. Rewrite remaining double negations: Â¬Â¬A â‡’ A

  4. Standardise variables apart

    • rename all quantified variables so that each quantifier is associated with a different name, regardless of its scope

  5. Skolemise all existential quantifiers

    A Skolem constant is a made-up name for an object that must exist (even though we donâ€™t know what it is)

    • âˆƒx.P(x) â‡’ P(A) where A is an arbitrary object in the allowable substitutions of x
    • Use a different arbitrary object for each quantifier

  6. Drop all universal quantifiers

    • At this point, all variables are universally quantified, because we Skolemised the existentials, so we no longer need to say so explicitly

  7. Convert the sentence into conjunctive normal form

    • a sentence in CNF is a conjunction of disjunctions of atomic sentences
      • recall that the resolution rule works on disjunctions
    • do this by rewriting under logical rules
      • de Morganâ€™s laws
      • distributivity of âˆ§ and âˆ¨

  8. Split the top-level conjunction up, to make a set of disjunctions

  9. Standardise the variables apart again, w.r.t. clauses

    • so that x in a given clause is not the same as x in another clause

Use the resulting set of clauses as KB in a resolution proof

First Order Term Unification

As a result of Skolemizing and removing universal quantifiers, we can introduce a new procedure for assigning values to variables

This is related to âˆ€ instantiation in the standard FOPC

  • effectively, we use the relevant Skolem constants to instantiate the variables

There is a deterministic algorithm for unification

The idea is to use literals of a given predicate which contain information about the values of variables (i.e., Skolem constants or functions) to deduce the values of variables in other literals of the same predicate

  • e.g. Father( x, y ) and Father( John, Jim ) are unified to Father( John, Jim )
  • with a unifier (or substitution set) of { John/x, Jim/y }
    • notation: a/x means â€œa replaces xâ€

To unify two terms (or literals):

  1. if either is a variable, let it be identical to the other, and add the resulting pair to the unifier; otherwise...
  2. compare their functors; if they do not match, then fail; otherwise...
  3. for each pair of respective arguments, unify the two arguments using this procedure.

Unification examples

  • P( x, y ) unified with P( A, B ) gives F( A, B ) unifier { A/x, B/y }
  • P( x, y ) unified with Q( A, B ) gives no unifier ( P â‰  Q )
  • P( F(x) ) unified with P( F( A ) ) gives P( F( A )) unifier { A/x }
  • P( F(x), x, u, u ) unified with P( F(y), z, z, A ) gives P( F( A ), A, A, A ) unifier { A/x, x/y, x/z, x/u }
    • note that we donâ€™t need to write down all the different permutations
      • this is enough to say that theyâ€™re all the same

Resolution example

Some rules

  • All people who are graduating are happy. All happy people smile. Jane is graduating

and a question

  • Is Jane smiling?

First convert to predicate logic

  • Premise
    • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ Graduating( Jane )
  • Goal
    • Smiling( Jane )

Convert to CNF

  • Premise
    • âˆ€x.Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x) âˆ§ Graduating( Jane )
  1. Rewrite â†’
    • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Â¬Happy(x) âˆ¨ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ Graduating( Jane )
  2. Reduce scope of negations: all minimal, so nothing to do
  3. Rewrite double negations: no double negations so nothing to do
  4. Standardise variables apart
    • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€y.(Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ Graduating( Jane )
  5. Skolemise existentials
    • no existentials, so nothing to do
  6. Drop all universal quantifiers
    • â–®â–®â–®â–® (Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ (Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ Graduating( Jane )
  7. Convert to CNF
    • already in CNF
  8. Separate into disjunctive clauses
    • Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)
    • Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)
    • Graduating( Jane )
  9. Standardise variables apart between clauses
    • no change: theyâ€™re already named apart

Resolution example with unification

Now, the only rules we need are

  • unification
  • resolution

Note that, in this proof, only the literals used are shown

  • but theyâ€™re all there, all the time

Example with existential quantification

Some rules

  • All people who are graduating are happy. All happy people smile. Someone is graduating.

and a question

  • Is anyone smiling?

First convert to predicate logic

  • Premise
    • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆƒx.Graduating(x)
  • Goal
    • âˆƒx.Smiling( x )

Conversion to CNF

This time Iâ€™ve added the negated goal to the premises, instead of later

  • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆƒx.Graduating(x) âˆ§ Â¬âˆƒx.Smiling(x)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Â¬Happy(x) âˆ¨ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆƒx.Graduating(x) âˆ§ Â¬âˆƒx.Smiling(x)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Â¬Happy(x) âˆ¨ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆƒx.Graduating(x) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Â¬Smiling(x)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€y.(Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ âˆƒz.Graduating(z) âˆ§ âˆ€u.Â¬Smiling(u)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€y.(Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ Graduating( Someone ) âˆ§ âˆ€u.Â¬Smiling(u)
  • (Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ (Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ Graduating( Someone ) âˆ§ Â¬Smiling(u)
  • { Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x), Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y), Graduating( Someone ), Â¬Smiling(u) }

Note that the proof is exactly the same as with the constant â€œJaneâ€

  • the only difference is that the variable u gets passed around instead

Example with universal quantification

Some rules

  • All people who are graduating are happy. All happy people smile. Everyone is graduating.

and a question

  • Is everyone smilingï¼Ÿ

First convert to predicate logic

  • Premise
    • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Graduating(x)
  • Goal
    • âˆ€x.Smiling(x)

Conversion to CNF

  • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Graduating(x) âˆ§ Â¬âˆ€x.Smiling(x)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Â¬Happy(x) âˆ¨ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Graduating(x) âˆ§ Â¬âˆ€x.Smiling(x)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Â¬Happy(x) âˆ¨ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Graduating(x) âˆ§ âˆƒx.Â¬Smiling(x)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€y.(Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ âˆ€z.Graduating(z) âˆ§ âˆƒu.Â¬Smiling(u)
  • âˆ€x.(Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€y.(Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ âˆ€z. Graduating(z) âˆ§ Â¬Smiling( Someone )
  • (Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x)) âˆ§ (Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y)) âˆ§ Graduating(z) âˆ§ Â¬Smiling( Someone )
  • { Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x), Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y), Graduating(z), Â¬Smiling( Someone ) }

Note that the proof is exactly the same as with the constant Jane

  • the difference is that the Skolem constant Someone gets passed around instead

Alternative proof

Here, we use general resolution first â€“ but the effect is the same

A (slightly) more realistic example

In this example, not all of the quantifiers match neatly up

Some rules and a question

  • All people who are graduating are happy. All happy people smile. Someone is graduating.
  • Is everyone smiling?

First convert to predicate logic

  • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆƒx.Graduating(x)
  • âˆ€x.Smiling(x)

Resolution-ready form

  • Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x), Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y) âˆ§ Graduating( Z ) âˆ§ Â¬Smiling( U ) ï¼ˆSkolem constantsï¼‰

We canâ€™t infer that everyone is smiling from the knowledge that one person is graduating

The other way round

In this example, not all of the quantifiers match neatly up

Some rules and a question

  • All people who are graduating are happy. All happy people smile. Everyone is graduating.
  • Is anyone smiling?

First convert to predicate logic

  • âˆ€x.(Graduating(x) â†’ Happy(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.(Happy(x) â†’ Smiling(x)) âˆ§ âˆ€x.Graduating(x)
  • âˆƒx.Smiling( x )

Resolution-ready form

  • Â¬Graduating(x) âˆ¨ Happy(x), Â¬Happy(y) âˆ¨ Smiling(y) âˆ§ Graduating(z) âˆ§ Â¬Smiling(u)

We can infer that one is person is smiling from the knowledge that everyone is graduating

Something to try

Express the following sentences in FOPC

  • Every man who owns a donkey beats it.
  • John looked at Jane in the park with the telescope.
  • All lecturers except Geraint are boring.

Real-time Operating Systems

Video 2:07:06 ~ 2:30:40

Embedded and Real-Time operating systems Concepts

  1. Embedded Systems
  2. Real-Time Systems
  3. Real-Time Operating Systems

What is an embedded system? 2:08:43

An embedded system can be defined as:

â€œA system whose principal function is not computational, but which is controlled by a computer embedded within it.â€

  • Computing systems embedded within electronic devices
  • Billions of units produced yearly, versus millions of desktop units
  • Perhaps 50 per household and per automobile
  • Largely used in healthcare devices

Application example: coffee machine 2:09:30

PSoC Enables:

  • Liquid-tolerant capacitive touch interface for buttons and sliders
  • Proximity detection
  • LED control
  • Door lock control

Some common characteristics of embedded systems

Single-functioned

  • Executes a single program, repeatedly

Tightly-constrained

  • Low cost, low power, small, fast, etc.

Reactive and real-time

  • Continually reacts to changes in the systemâ€™s environment
  • Must compute certain results in real-time without delay

Software VS. hardware trade-offs 2:09:59

Key points - Comparation 2:10:46

Embedded design perspective 2:11:11

Program and data memory space

  • Embedded processors often very limited
    • e.g., 64 Kbytes program, 256 bytes of RAM (expandable)
  • Registers: How many are there?
    • Only a direct concern for assembly-level programmers
  • I/O, Interrupts
    • How communicate with external signals?

Embedded operating systems 2:11:36

On embedded systems, an O.S. is an optional software layer providing low-level services to a program (application).

  • Platform-specific hardware abstraction layers
  • File management, disk access
  • Keyboard/display interfacing
  • Integrated power-management systems
  • Device drivers for common peripherals
  • Scheduling multiple programs for execution
    • Or even just multiple threads from one program
  • Program makes system calls to the OS

Types (Skipped in video)

The main types of embedded OS are as follows:

  • Single System Control Loop: Such a operating system is designed to run the only single task.
  • Multi-Tasking Operating System: As the name suggests that this operating system can perform multiple tasks.
  • Rate Monotonic Operating System: It is a type of operating system that ensures that task runs in a system can run for a specific interval of time and for a specific period of time.
  • Preemptive Operating System: A preemptive operating system is a type of multitasking operating system that interprets the preemptive predominance for tasks. A higher priority is task is always defined and run before a lower priority task.
  • Real Time Operating System: A real-time operating system is the one which serves real time applications.

Categories of embedded devices 2:13:01

Class 0: These devices are the most constrained. They are typically sensor nodes(or motes) in a sensor network.

Class 1: These devices are able to talk to each other but via constrained protocols.

Class 2: These devices are the less constrained and can use the same stacks of protocols used in personal computers and servers.

Popular 2:15:22

Low-power IoT systems: open source real-time operating system designed for lowpower

  • Contiki OS
    • Focused on providing a simple platform to develop IoT applications
    • Oriented to 6LoWPAN and 802.15.4 wireless technologies.
  • TinyOS
    • component-based OS written in NesC
    • used for networked wireless sensors
    • provides interrupt management and FIFO scheduling in a few hundred bytes of code
  • Riot OS, Android Things, Windows IoT,â€¦

Real-time Operating Systems: provide short reaction times for real-time tasks

  • FreeRTOS
    • FreeRTOS provides methods for multiple threads or tasks, mutexes, semaphores and software timers.
    • Low-power management is limited to sleep mode, and no deep-sleep mechanism is implemented by default.
  • ChibiOS/RT
    • Designed for context-switch performance
    • The concept behind the scheduler is a fixed priority preemption, with priority inheritance mechanisms for priority inversion avoidance.

And many more...

What is a Real-Time System? 2:16:54

â€œReal-time programs or systems must guarantee response with a specified time constraint (aka deadlines) imposed by environmentâ€

A system is said to be Real Time if it is required to complete itâ€™s work & deliver itâ€™s services on time.

Result in severe consequences if logical and timing correctness are not met

Example â€“ Flight Control System

  • All tasks in that system must execute on time.

Non Example â€“ PC system

Embedded VS. Real-Time Systems 2:17:44

Embedded system: is a computer system that performs a limited set of specific functions. It often interacts with its environment.

RTS: Correctness of the system depends not only on the logical results, but also on the time in which the results are produced.

Examples 2:18:23

Real Time Embedded:

  • Nuclear reactor control
  • Flight control
  • Basically any safety critical system
  • GPS
  • Defibrillator

Real Time, but not Embedded:

  • Stock trading system
  • Skype
  • Pandora
  • Radar control systems

Embedded, but not Real Time:

  • Home temperature control
  • Sprinkler system
  • Washing machine, refrigerator, etc.
  • Blood pressure meter

Control systems

Example 1 2:19:32

A simple one-sensor, one-actuator control system

Pseudo-code for this system:

set timer to interrupt periodically with period T;at each timer interrupt do    do analog-to-digital conversion to get y;    compute control output u;    output u and do digital-to-analog conversion;end do

T is called the sampling period. T is a key design choice.

Typical range for T: seconds to milliseconds.

Example 2 2:21:21

Multimedia:

  • Want to process audio and video frames at steady rates.
    • TV video rate is 30 frames/sec. HDTV is 60 frames/sec.
    • Telephone audio is 16 Kbits/sec. CD audio is 128 Kbits/sec.
  • Other requirements: Lip synchronization, low jitter, low end-to-end response times (if interactive).
  • General examples:
    • Video capture.
    • Digital filtering.
    • Video and voice compression/decompression.
    • Radar signal processing.
  • Response times range from a few milliseconds to a few seconds.
  • Typically simpler than control systems

Example 3 2:22:22

Real-time databases:

  • Examples: stock market, airline reservations, etc.
  • Transactions must complete by deadlines.
  • Main dilemma: Transaction scheduling algorithms and real-time scheduling algorithms often have conflicting goals.
  • Data is subject temporal consistency requirements.

The "Window of scarcity" 2:23:18

Resources may be categorized as:

  • Abundant: Virtually any system design methodology can be used to realize the timing requirements of the application.
  • Insufficient: The application is ahead of the technology curve; no design methodology can be used to realize the timing requirements of the application.
  • Sufficient but scarce: It is possible to realize the timing requirements of the application, but careful resource allocation is required.

Recipe for Real-Time 2:24:38

Main ingredients:

  • Multitasking
  • Priority
  • Preemption

Task Response Latency (TRL):

  • Time elapsed between interrupt and task runs

Jitter

  • Î” = (max - min)samplesTRL

Characteristics 2:25:58

  • Systems composed of 2 or more cooperating, concurrent processes with stringent execution time constraints
  • Communication and synchronization between processes for these systems is critical
  • Expected deterministic response
  • Deterministic â‰  necessarily fast
  • Concurrency
  • Error tolerance
  • A correct, but late, response is an error. Consequences?
    • It depends on the type of real-time system

Real-Time System

Types

Soft real-time systems 2:27:40
  • Tasks are performed as fast as possible
  • Late completion of jobs (with some acceptably low probability) is undesirable but not fatal.
  • System performance degrades as more & more jobs miss deadlines
  • Also known as â€œbest effortâ€ systems
  • Example:
    • web sites and services
    • computer games
Firm real-time systems 2:28:23
  • Tasks are performed as fast as possible
  • Late completion of jobs is undesirable but not fatal.
  • Results discarded after deadline.
Hard real-time systems 2:29:16
  • Tasks have to be performed on time
  • Failure to meet deadlines is fatal
  • Example:
    • Flight Control System
    • Vehicle subsystems control
Operational definition 2:30:00

Hard Real Time System

  • Validation by probably correct procedures or extensive simulation that the system always meets the timings constraints

Soft/Firm Real Time System

  • Demonstration of jobs meeting some statistical constraints suffices.
  • Example â€“ Multimedia System
    • 25 frames per second on an average

Terms

State: A unique operating condition of the system.

Task: A single thread of execution through a group of related states.

Task Manager â€“

  • Responsible for maintaining the current state of each task.
  • Responsible for providing each task with execution time.

Application: Set of multiple small tasks.

Processors: They are also known as active resources. They are important for the execution of a job.

Definitions

Worst case execution time

Definition: The Worst Case Execution Time (WCET) is an upper bound on the execution time of a task.

  • Computing such a bound is undecidable
    • Possible for programs without recursion and finite loops
      • Pipeline hazards, interrupts, caches -> serious overestimates

Approaches:

  • for hardware: typically requires hardware synthesis
  • for software: requires availability of machine programs; complex analysis
Average execution time

Estimated cost and performance values

  • Difficult to generate sufficiently precise estimates; Balance between run-time and precision

Accurate cost and performance values

  • Can be done with normal tools (such as compilers). As precise as the input data is.

Task periodicity

Period and deadline

Period of a task (if periodic)

  • Repeating time interval the task must complete one execution within
    • E.g., period = 100 ms
    • Task must execute once every 100 ms
  • Usually determined by the description of the system
    • E.g., refresh rate of display is 27 times/sec
    • Period = 37 ms

Execution deadline

  • Amount of time task must be completed by after it has started
    • E.g., execution time = 5 ms, deadline = 20 ms, period = 100 ms
    • Task must complete execution within 20 ms after it has begun regardless of its period
    • Task begins at start of period, runs for 4 ms then is preempted
    • Task suspended for 14 ms, then runs for the remaining 1 ms
    • Completed within 4 + 14 + 1 = 19 ms which meets deadline of 20 ms
    • Without deadline process could be suspended for much longer

Types

  • Periodic Tasks
  • Sporadic Tasks
  • Aperiodic Tasks
Periodic Tasks

Periodic Task repeats itself regularly after a certain fixed time interval.

Periodic tasks are sometimes referred to as clock-driven tasks

The fixed time interval after which a task repeates is called the period of the task.

If ğ‘‡ğ‘– is a periodic task, then the time from till the occurrence of the first instance of ğ‘‡ğ‘– is denoted by Ï•ğ‘– and it is called the phase of the task.

ğ‘‡ğ‘– = (Ï•ğ‘– ğ‘’ğ‘– , ğ‘ğ‘– , â…†ğ‘–)

  • Ï•ğ‘– : the phase
  • ğ‘’ğ‘– : the worst case execution time
  • ğ‘ğ‘– : the periodicity
  • â…†ğ‘– : the deadline

A vast majority of the tasks present in a typical real-time system are periodic

Sporadic Tasks

A sporadic task is one that recurs at random instants

A sporadic task ğ‘‡ğ‘– can is represented by three tuples:

ğ‘‡ğ‘– = (ğ‘’ğ‘– , ğ‘”ğ‘– , â…†ğ‘–)

Where ğ‘’ğ‘– is the wost case execution time of an instance of the task and ğ‘‘ğ‘– is the relative deadline.

The minimum separation ğ‘”ğ‘– indicates that once an instance of sporadic task occurs, the next instance cannot occur before ğ‘”ğ‘– time unit have elapsed.

The criticality level may vary.

Aperiodic Tasks

An aperiodic task can arise at random instants.

Two or more instances of an aperiodic task might occur at the same time instant because minimum separation ğ‘”ğ‘– can be zero.

Aperiodic task can recur in quick succession.

Soft real-time systems can tolerate a few deadline misses, so aperiodic tasks are generally soft real time tasks.

Task scheduling

Scheduler

Real-time systems must meet timing requirements when multiple concurrent processes implemented on single general-purpose processor

  • Not true multitasking

Scheduler is a special process that decides when and for how long each process is executed

The main role of task scheduling refers to identifying the order in which tasks should execute in a system.

A schedule for a given set of tasks is thus an assignment of time-frames and resources to individual tasks.

There exist multiple scheduling algorithms.

  • The time instants at which scheduling decisions are taken are called scheduling points.
  • Their quality is identified by a term called processor utilization.

A good scheduling algorithm should lead to 100% processor utilization.

Classification

Based up to scheduling points, scheduling algorithms can be classified into the following categories:

  • Clock driven scheduling: the scheduling points are the interrupts received from a periodic clock
    • Table driven
    • Cyclic
  • Event driven scheduling: the scheduling points correspond to different events in the system such as when an instance of a task finishes execution.
    • Simply priority scheduling
    • Rate monotonic scheduling (RMS)
    • Earliest deadline first (EDF) scheduling
Clock driven scheduling

This type of schedulers are called static schedulers.

Clock driven scheduler works in synchronism with clock or timer signal, which periodically generates interrupts.

Simplified scheduled due to knowing in advance:

  • The set of tasks
  • Their periodicity values
  • Execution times required
  • Deadlines

Drawback: this type of schedulers is their inability to handle aperiodic and sporadic tasks

Types:

  • Table driven
  • Cyclic
Table driven scheduling

Table driven schedulers use a precomputed table that stores the tasks to be run at different clock intervals.

Top table provides an example of a set of 3 tasks, their periodicity and their execution time.

A possible schedule for this set of tasks is shown in the bottom table.

Cyclic scheduling

A major problem with table-driven scheduling is the size of the schedule table.

In cyclic scheduling, the major cycle (equal to the least common multiple of periodicity tasks) is divided into a number of equal sized minor cycles or frames.

One or more frames are allocated to individual tasks.

The schedule table stores the tasks to be run for different frames, so the size of the tables is reduced to be equal to the number of frames.

The selection of the frame size becomes an issue:

  • A large frame size implies lesser number of frames in a major cycle.
  • It may lead to wastage of CPU time as for most of the tasks, execution time may be much smaller than the frame size.

The constraints behind selection of a frame size are the following:

  • Minimize context switching
  • Schedule table minimization
  • Satisfaction of task deadlines
Limitations

Problems of clock driven scheduling strategies:

  • their inability to handle a large number of tasks.
  • determining the proper frame size
  • sporadic and aperiodic tasks cannot be handled efficiently
Priorities

Tasks with highest priority always selected first by scheduler

  • Typically determined statically during creation or dynamically during execution

Priority queue

  • Runnable tasks again added as created or become runnable
  • Task with highest priority chosen when new task needed
  • If multiple tasks with same highest priority value then selects from them using first-come first-served
Event driven scheduling

The scheduling of sporadic and aperiodic tasks have led to the design of event driven schedulers

Priorities are assigned to tasks.

There are three important schedulers in this category:

  1. Foreground-background scheduling
  2. Rate Monotonic scheduling (RMS)
  3. Earliest Deadline First (EDF) scheduling
Foreground-background scheduling

Small systems of low complexity

These systems are also called â€œsuperloopsâ€

An application consists of an infinite loop of desired operations (background)

Interrupt service routines (ISRs) handle asynchronous events (foreground)

Critical operations must be performed by the ISRs to ensure the timing correctness

Thus, ISRs tend to take longer than they should

Rate Monotonic scheduling

Rate Monotonic Scheduling is a static-priority-based event driven scheduling algorithm for periodic tasks.

The priorities are assigned to the tasks based on their periodicity values.

Rate monotonic scheduling

  • Processes with shorter periods have higher priority
  • Typically used when execution deadline = period

The theory underlying Rate Monotonic Scheduling is the Rate Monotonic Analysis, that uses simple model of the system stated as follows:

  1. All Processes run on a single CPU, thus there is no task parallelism
  2. Context switching time ignored
  3. Execution time for different invocations of a task are same and constant
  4. Tasks are totally independent of each other
  5. The deadline of an instance of a task occurs at the end of its period

Advantages:

  • The major advantage of Rate Monotonic Scheduling is its simplicity.
  • Since the priorities are static, a simple array of tasks can be used as the data structure.
  • Another good feature is its ability to handle transient overloads efficiently. It cannot lead to higher priority tasks missing deadlines.
  • Almost all the commercial real-time operating systems support Rate Monotonic Scheduling policy

Disadvantages:

  • It is difficult to handle aperiodic and sporadic tasks.
  • Rate Monotonic Scheduling does not produce optimal results if deadlines differ from periodicity of tasks.
  • In Deadline Monotonic Algorithm priorities are assigned to the tasks based on their deadlines
    • Processes with shorter deadlines have higher priority
    • Typically used when execution deadline < period
    • If deadlines are different from periodicity, there may be cases in which Rate Monotonic Scheduling fails but Deadline Monotonic Scheduling produce valid schedules.
    • On the contrary, wherever Deadline Monotonic Scheduling fails, Rate Monotonic Scheduling also fails
Deadline Monotonic scheduling

Deadline Monotonic Scheduling is a static-priority-based event driven scheduling algorithm for periodic tasks that assigns priorities to the tasks based on their deadlines values.

Deadline monotonic scheduling

  • Processes with shorter deadlines have higher priority
  • Typically used when execution deadline < period

Earliest Deadline Monotonic scheduling

Earliest Deadline First Scheduling is a dynamic priority algorithms in which priority of an instance of a task depends on its deadline.

Unlike Rate Monotonic scheduling, the priority of a task is not fixed for all instances.

The priority changes dynamically during the lifetime of the system.

Disadvantages:

  • Earliest Deadline First Scheduling is less predictable.
  • Earliest Deadline First Scheduling is less controllable in the sense that we cannot control the response time of a task
  • Implementation overhead is higher than fixed priority approaches.
  • Transient overload problem
  • Domino effect

Role of an OS in Real-Time Systems

RTOS provide mechanisms, primitives, and guidelines for building real-time systems

Standalone Applications

  • Often no OS involved(bare metal)
  • Micro-controller based Embedded Systems

But many Real Time Applications are huge & complex

  • Multiple threads
  • Complicated Synchronization Requirements
  • File system / Network / Windowing support
  • OS primitives reduce the software design time

Real-time operating systems are specialised operating systems which manage the processes in the RTS.

Responsible not only for process management and resource (processor and memory) allocation.

Do not normally include facilities such as file management.

Why use an RTOS?

Here are important reasons for using RTOS:

  • It offers priority-based scheduling, which allows you to separate analytical processing from non-critical processing.
  • The Real time OS provides API functions that allow cleaner and smaller application code.
  • Abstracting timing dependencies and the task-based design results in fewer interdependencies between modules.
  • RTOS offers modular task-based development, which allows modular task-based testing.
  • The task-based API encourages modular development as a task, will typically have a clearly defined role. It allows designers/teams to work independently on their parts of the project.
  • An RTOS is event-driven with no time wastage on processing time for the event which is not occur

Features of RTOS

RTOS provide:

  • Task management
  • Timers
    • Periodic
    • Aperiodic/Watchdogs
  • Task priorities
  • Reduced context switching time
  • Interrupt latency
  • Non-virtual Memory

For embedded

  • â€¢ Occupy very less memory
  • Consume fewer resources
  • Response times are highly predictable
  • Unpredictable environment
ProcessorsMIPS
Microcontrollers~20
ARM7100-133
ARM9180-250
Strong ARM206
Intel Xscale400
Mips4Kcore400
x86

Advantages of RTOS

  • Maximum consumption: Maximum utilization of devices and system. Thus more output from all the resources.
  • Task Shifting: Time assigned for shifting tasks in these systems are very low.
  • Focus On Application: Focus on running applications and less importance to applications which are in queue.
  • Real Time Operating System In Embedded System: Since size of programs are small, RTOS can also be embedded systems like in transport and others.
  • Error Free: These types of systems are error free.
  • Memory Allocation: Memory allocation is best managed in these type of systems

Responsibility of an RTOS

  • Process (task) management
    • Scheduler
    • Synchronization mechanism
      • Inter-Process Communication (IPC)
      • Semaphores
  • Memory management
  • Interrupt service mechanism
  • I/O management
  • Development Environments
  • Communication subsystems (Option)
  • Board Support Packages (BSP)

Components of RTOS

  • The Scheduler
  • Symmetric Multiprocessing (SMP)
  • Function Library
  • Memory Management
  • Fast dispatch latency
  • User-defined data objects and classes

Popular Real-Time Operating Systems

  • FreeRTOS
    • Scalable real time kernel designed specifically for small embedded systems.
    • RTOS Scheduler - preemptive, cooperative and hybrid configuration options, with optional time slicing.
    • Round robin with time slicing, mutexes with priority inheritance and recursive mutexes.
    • 6K to 12K ROM footprint
  • Neutrino/QNX
    • Real-time microkernel surrounded by optional processes (resource managers) that provide POSIX and UNIX compatibility
    • Microkernels typically support only the most basic services
    • Optional resource managers allow scalability from small ROM-based systems to huge multiprocessor systems connected by various networking and communication technologies
    • Preemptive process scheduling using FIFO, round-robin, adaptive, or priority-driven scheduling
    • 32 priority levels per process
    • Microkernel < 10 Kbytes and complies with POSIX real-time standard

Factors for selecting an RTOS

Performance: Performance is the most important factor required to be considered while selecting for a RTOS.

Middleware: if there is no middleware support in Real time operating system, then the issue of time-taken integration of processes occurs.

Error-free: RTOS systems are error-free. Therefore, there is no chance of getting an error while performing the task.

Embedded system usage: Programs of RTOS are of small size. So we widely use RTOS for embedded systems.

Maximum Consumption: we can achieve maximum consumption with the help of RTOS.

Task shifting: Shifting time of the tasks is very less.

Unique features: A good RTS should be capable, and it has some extra features like how it operates to execute a command, efficient protection of the memory of the system, etc.

What's important in Real-Time

Metrics for real-time systems differ from that for time-sharing systems

  • Schedulability is the ability of tasks to meet all hard deadlines
  • Latency is the worst-case system response time to event
  • Stability in overload means the system meets critical deadlines even if all deadlines cannot be met

Disadvantages of RTOS

Limited tasks: RTOS system can run minimal tasks together, and it concentrates only on those applications which contain an error so that it can avoid them.

Poor multi-tasking: RTOS is the system that concentrates on a few tasks. Therefore, it is really hard for these systems to do multi-tasking.

Limited switching: Minimum switching of tasks is done in Real time operating systems.

Device Driver And Interrupt signals: Specific drivers are required for the RTOS so that it can offer fast response time to interrupt signals, which helps to maintain its speed.

Use Heavy System Resources: Plenty of resources are used by RTOS, which makes this system expensive.

Thread Priority: The tasks which have a low priority need to wait for a long time as the RTOS maintains the accuracy of the program, which are under execution.

Complex Algorithm: The algorithms are very complex and difficult for the designer

Summary

  • RTOS is an operating system intended to serve real time application that process data as it comes in, mostly without buffer delay.
  • It offers priority-based scheduling, which allows you to separate analytical processing from noncritical processing.
  • Important components of RTOS system are:
    1. The Scheduler
    2. Symmetric Multiprocessing
    3. Function Library
    4. Memory Management
    5. Fast dispatch latency
    6. User-defined data objects and classes
  • Three types of RTOS:
    1. Hard time
    2. Soft time
    3. Firm time
  • RTOS system occupy very less memory and consume fewer resources
  • Performance is the most important factor required to be considered while selecting for a RTOS.
  • General-Purpose Operating System (GPOS) is used for desktop PC and laptop while Real-Time Operating System (RTOS) only applied to the embedded application.
  • Real-time systems are used in Airlines reservation system, Air traffic control system, etc.
  • A major drawback of RTOS is that the system only concentrates on a few tasks.

entry.title: Relational Model and Relational Algebra
entry.content:
Relational Model and Relational Algebra

Video Part 1 42:57 ~ end

Relational Model

Theory for data management developed by Edgar F. Codd while working at IBM:

  • data independence
    • between logical and physical level
  • set-based query language
    • relational query language
  • normalisation
    • avoid redundancy

IBM first did not implement the relational model in order to "protect" their IMS/DB revenues

IBM's System R (1974) was a DBMS prototype implementing Codd's relational model

  • first implementation of the Structured English Query Language (SEQUEL)
    • later renamed to Structured Query Language (SQL)

The System R prototype finally led to the development of different commercial DBMSs including IBM's DB2, Oracle or Microsoft SQL Server

Relational Database 47:40

A relational database consists of a number of tables

  • each table row defines a relationship between a set of values

There is an analogy between the concept of a table (collection of relationships) and the mathematical concept of a relation

  • in the following we therefore talk about relations instead of tables
  • -> a relational database consists of a collection of relations

Information is normally partitioned into different relations since the storage in a single relation would lead to

  • a replication of information (redundancy)
  • a large number of necessary null values

While tables are used at the logical level, different storage structures can be used at the physical level

  • data independence

Relation 52:23

The column headers of a table are called attributes and for each attribute ai there is a set of permitted values called the domain Di of ai

Given the domains D1, D2, ..., Dn, a relation r is defined as a subset of the cartesian product D1 Ã— D2 Ã— ... Ã— Dn

A relation r is a set of n-ary tuples ti = (a1, a2,..., an) where each ai âˆˆ Di

  • the number of attributes is called a relation's degree
  • the number of tuples is called a relation's cardinality

Since a relation is a set of tuples, the order of the tuples is irrelevant

  • each tuple is distinctive (no duplicate tuples)

The order of attributes is irrelevant

The domain of each attribute has to be atomic

  • all members of the domain have to be indivisible units
  • a relation with only atomic values is normalised (first normal form)

Multiple attributes can have the same domain Di

  • we will see later how the domain types can be defined (in SQL)

A tuple variable is a variable that stands for a tuple

  • its domain is defined by the set of all tuples

The special null value is part of any domain Di

  • used to represent an unknown or non-existing value
  • null values are not easy to handle (not the same as empty string)
    • avoid null values whenever possible

Example of a Relation 1:01:06

Let us assume that we have the following attributes with their domains

  • name = {Merckx, Frisch, Botta, ...}
  • street = {Bahnhofstrasse, Pleinlaan, Via Nassa, ...}
  • city = {Zurich, Brussels, Lugano, Paris, ...}

Then

r = {(Merckx, Pleinlaan, Brussels),

â€‹ (Frisch, Bahnhofstrasse, Zurich),

â€‹ (Botta, Via Nassa, Lugano),

â€‹ (Botta, Bahnhofstrasse, Lugano)}

forms a relation over name Ã— street Ã— city

Relational Database Example 1:02:21

relational database schema
Customer (customerID, name, street, postcode, city)
CD (cdID, name, duration, price, year)
Order (orderId, customerID, cdID, date, amount, status)
Supplier (supplierID, name, city)

Database Schema 1:04:28

The logical design of a database is defined by the database schema

A database instance is a snapshot of the data stored in a database at a given time

A relation schema R = (A1, A2,..., An) is defined by a list of attributes

  • by convention, the name of a relation schema starts with an uppercase letter (in contrast to relations)
    • e.g. Customer (customerID, name, street, postcode, city)
  • a relation can be defined based on the relation schema
    • e.g. customer = (Customer)
  • a relation instance contains the relation's actual values (tuples)

Keys 1:06:52

For the keys we use the same terminology as introduced earlier for the ER model

K âŠ† R is a superkey of R if the values of K uniquely identify any tuple of possible relation instances r(R)

  • t1 and t2 âˆˆ r and t1 â‰  t2 -> t1[K] â‰  t2[K]
  • e.g. {cdID} and {cdID, name} are both superkeys of CD

K is a candidate key if K is minimal

  • e.g. {cdID} is a candidate key of CD

The DB designer has to choose one of the candidate keys for each relation schema as primary key

  • if possible, the value of a primary key should not change or only in very rare cases

Foreign Keys 1:11:03

A relation schema may have one or multiple attributes that correspond to the primary key of another relation schema and are called foreign keys

  • e.g. customerID is a foreign key of the order relation schema
  • note that a foreign key of the referencing relation can only contain values that occur in the primary key of the referenced relation or it must be null -> referential integrity

Video Part 2

Query Language

A query language is a language that is used to access (read) information stored in a database as well as to create, update and delete information (CRUD)

There are different types of query languages:

  • procedural
    • e.g. relational algebra
  • declarative
    • e.g. Structured Query Language (SQL)

The relational algebra as well as the tuple and domain relational calculus form the basis for "higher level" query languages (e.g. SQL)

Relational Algebra 5:37

The relational algebra consists of six fundamental operations

unary operations:

  • selection: Ïƒ
  • projection: Ï€
  • rename: Ï

binary operations:

  • union: â‹ƒ
  • set difference: â€”
  • cartesian product: Ã—

An operator takes one (unary) or two (binary) relations as input and returns a new single relation as output

Based on the six fundamental operations, we can define additional relational operations (add no additional power)

  • set intersection: â‹‚
  • natural join: â‹ˆ
  • theta join: Î¸
  • equijoin: Î¸
  • semijoin: â‹‰
  • division: Ã·
  • assignment: â†

Extended operations with additional expressiveness

  • generalised projection
  • aggregate function
  • outer join

Selection (Ïƒ) 9:00

Goal: Select specific tuples (rows) from a relation (table)

Ïƒp(r) = {t | t âˆˆ r and p(t)}

  • p is a selection predicate
    • consists of terms pi connected by an and (âˆ§), or (âˆ¨) or not (Â¬)
  • a term pi has the form attributem operator attributen or constant
    • the available operators are: =, â‰ , >, <, â‰¥, â‰¤

Examples

"Find all tuples in the customer relation that are in the city of Zurich and have a postcode greater than 8010."

Ïƒcity = "Zurich" âˆ§ postcode > 8010 (customer)

Examples

A selection predicate may contain a comparison between two attributes

"Find all tuples in the cd relation with a value for the duration attribute that is equal to the year of release."

Ïƒduration = year (cd)

Attention

The selection operation in relational algebra has a different meaning than the SELECT statement used in SQL

  • SELECT in SQL corresponds to a projection in relational algebra

Projection (Ï€) 11:51

Goal: Select specific attributes (columns) from a relation

Ï€A1, A2,..., Am(r)

  • returns a relation instance that only contains the columns for which an attribute Ai has been listed
  • duplicate tuples are removed from the resulting relation (set)

Example

"Return the name and city of all tuples in the customer relation."

Ï€name,city(customer)

Composition of Relational Operations 14:53

Since the result of a relational operation is a new single relation instance, multiple operations can be combined

Example

"Find the names of all customers who live in Zurich."

Ï€name (Ïƒcity = "Zurich" (customer))

Union: â‹ƒ 16:04

Goal: Unify tuples from two relations

r â‹ƒ s = {t | t âˆˆ r or t âˆˆ s}

  • r and s must have the same degree (same number of attributes)
  • the corresponding attribute domains must have a compatible type

Example

"Find the names of persons who are either customers or suppliers."

Ï€name (customer) â‹ƒ Ï€name (supplier)

Set Difference (â€”) 18:39

Goal: Find tuples that are in one relation but not in another relation

r - s = {t | t âˆˆ r and t âˆ‰ s}

  • r and s must have the same degree
  • the corresponding attribute domains must have a compatible type
  • finds tuples that are in a relation r but not in another relation s

Example

"Find the names of suppliers who are no customers."

Ï€name (customer) â€” Ï€name (supplier)

Cartesian product (Ã—) 19:36

Goal: Combine information from any two relations

r Ã— s = {tu | t âˆˆ r and u âˆˆ s}

  • the attribute names of r(R) and s(S) have to be distinct
    • attributes with the same name have to be renamed via the rename operator Ï

Example

Ï€name (customer) Ã— Ï€city (customer)

Example

"List the names of all customers with at least one order."

Ï€name(Ïƒcustomer.customerID = order.customerID (customer Ã— order) )

Note that we will later see another operator (natural join) for the combination of two tables based on common attributes

Rename (Ï) 24:30

Goal: Rename a relation or an attribute

Ïx(E)

  • renames the result of expression E to x

Ïx(A1,A2,...,An)(E)

  • renames the result of expression E to x and renames the attributes to A1, A2,..., An

Example

Ïperson(name,location)(Ï€name,city (customer))

Example

"Find the price of the most expensive CD in the cd relation."

Ï€price(cd) - Ï€cd.price(Ïƒcd.price < d.price (cd Ã— Ïd (cd)))

Formal Definition 29:11

A basic relational algebra expression is either a relation from the database or a constant relation

The set of all relational algebra expressions is defined byï¼š

  • E1 â‹ƒ E2
  • E1 â€” E2
  • E1 Ã— E2
  • Ïƒp(E1)
  • Ï€A1,A2,...,Am(E1)
  • Ïx(A1,A2,...,An)(E1)

Set Intersection 34:11

r âˆ© s = {t | t âˆˆ r or t âˆˆ s}

  • r and s must have the same degree
  • the corresponding attribute domains must have a compatible type

Note that the set intersection can be implemented via a pair of set difference operations

  • r âˆ© s = r - (r - s)

Example

"Find the names of people who are customers and suppliers."

Ï€name(customer) âˆ© Ï€name(supplier)

Natural Join (â‹ˆ) 36:25

r â‹ˆ s = Ï€Râ‹ƒS (Ïƒr.A1 = s.A1 âˆ§ r.A2 = s.A2 âˆ§ ... âˆ§ r.An = s.An (r Ã— s))

Keep all tuples of the cartesian product r Ã— s that have the same value for the shared attributes of r(R) and s(S)

  • the natural join is an associative operation: r â‹ˆ s â‹ˆ t = r â‹ˆ (s â‹ˆ t)

Example

"List the name and street of customers whose order is still open."

Ï€name,street(Ïƒstatus="open"(order â‹ˆ customer))

note that we could do the selection first (more efficient)

  • we will review this later when discussing query optimisation

Theta Join (Î¸) and Equijoin 47:49

r â‹ˆp s =Ïƒp(r Ã— s)

where the predicate p is of the form r.Ai Î¸ s.Aj and Î¸ is a comparison operator ( =, â‰ , >, <, â‰¥, â‰¤)

Example

customer â‹ˆpostcode â‰¤ duration (Ïcd(cdID,cdName,duration,price,year) (cd))

An equijoin (r â‹ˆp s) is a special form of a theta join where only the equality operator (=) may be used

  • note that a natural join is a equijoin over all common attributes of a relation r and s

Semijoin (â‹‰) 49:39

r â‹‰ s = Ï€A1,A2,...,An (r â‹ˆ s)

  • where A1, A2,..., An are all the attributes of r

Example

"List the customers whose order is still open."

customer â‹‰ Ïƒstatus="open" (order)

Division (Ã·) 52:30

r Ã· s = {t | t âˆˆ Ï€R-S(r) and âˆ€ u âˆˆ s â†’ tu âˆˆ r}

  • for the relations r(R) and s(S) and S âŠ† R
  • suited for queries that include the phrase "for all"

Example

r Ã· s

Assignment (â†) 55:37

variable â† E

Works like an assignment in programming languages

Assignments must always be made to temporary relation variables

  • no database modification

Example

  • temp1 â† Ï€name, street(Ïƒstatus = "open"(order â‹ˆ customer))
  • temp2 â† Ï€name, street(Ïƒcity = "Brussels" (customer))
  • result â† temp1 âˆª temp2

Generalised Projection (Ï€) 59:16

Ï€F1,F2,...,Fm(E)

generalisation of the project operation that supports the projection to arithmetic expressions F1, F2,..., Fm

Example

"Show a list of the names of all CDs together with a reduced price (80% of the original price)."

Ï€name, price Â· 0.8 as reducedPrice (cd)

Aggregate Function 1:01:16

Examples

Outer Joins (âŸ•) 1:09:20

  • left outer join (âŸ•)
    • keeps all tuples of the left relation
    • non-matching parts filled up with null values
  • right outer join (âŸ–)
    • keeps all tuples of the right relation
    • non-matching parts filled up with null values
  • full outer join (âŸ—)
    • keeps all tuples of both relations
    • non-matching parts filled up with null values

The left outer join (âŸ•), right outer join (âŸ–) and full outer join (âŸ—) are extensions of the natural join operation

Computes the natural join and then adds the tuples from one relation that do not match the other relation

  • filled up with null values

Example

customer âŸ• order

Null Values 1:17:09

A null value means that the value is unknown or non-existent

Primary key attributes can never be null (entity integrity)

The result of an arithmetic operation that involves a null value is null

For grouping and duplicate elimination null values are treated like other values (two null values are the same)

Null values are ignored in aggregate functions

Database Modifications 1:20:22

A database may be modified by using one of the following operations

  • insert
  • update
  • delete

These operations are defined via the assignment operator

Insert 1:21:28

r â† r âˆª E

To insert new data into a relation we can

  • explicitly specify the tuples to be inserted
  • write a query and insert the result tuple set

Example

cd â† cd âˆª {(3, "Chromatic", 3012, 16.50, 1994)}

Update 1:22:09

r â† Ï€F1,F2,...,Fn(r)

Update specific values in a tuple r

Fi is either the old value of r or a new value if the attribute has to be updated

Example

"Increase the price of all CDs by 10%."

cd â† Ï€cdID, name, duration, priceÂ Â· 1.1, year (cd)

Delete 1:23:23

r â† r - E

A delete is expressed similar to a query except that the result is removed from the database

Cannot remove single attributes

Example

"Remove the CD with the name 'Carcassonne' from the database."

cd â† cd - Ïƒname="Carcassonne" (cd)

entry.title: Input/Output
entry.content:
Basis of OS - Input/Output

Video 57:51 ~ 1:54:06

Principles of I/O hardware 59:33

IO devices

Different people look at I/O hardware in different ways:

  • Electrical engineers look at it in terms of chips, wires, power supplies, motors, and all the other physical components that comprise the hardware.
  • Programmers look at the interface presented to the software.

I/O devices can be divided into two categories:

  • block devices
  • character devices.

This classification scheme is not perfect because some devices do not fit in, but the model of block and character devices is general enough that it can be used as a basis.

Device controllers 1:02:14

I/O devices have components:

  • mechanical component (the device itself)
  • electronic component (device controller)

The electronic component is the device controller

  • may be able to handle multiple devices

Controller's tasks:

  • convert serial/parallel bit stream to block of bytes
  • perform error correction as necessary
  • make available to main memory

I/O Communication:

  • Memory-Mapped I/O
  • Direct Memory Accesses
  • Interruptions

Memory-mapped I/O 1:03:41

How the CPU communicates with the control registers and also with the device data buffers?

  1. Separate I/O and memory space (Standard I/O or I/O-mapped I/O)
  2. Memory-mapped I/O
  3. Hybrid

x86

  1. A single-bus architecture (old architectures)
  2. A dual-bus memory architecture (current architectures)

Direct Memory Access (DMA) 1:09:45

DMA Features 1:14:25

DMA controllers vary considerably in their sophistication.

More complex DMA controllers can be programmed to handle multiple transfers at the same time.

Many buses can operate in two modes:

  • word-at-a-time (former) mode => cycle stealing
  • block mode => burst mode

Not all computers (or embedded systems) use DMA.

Interrupt-driven I/O using vectored interrupt 1:16:49

Without interrupt controller

When an interruption happens, the processor suspends current program, jumps to an Interrupt Service Routine, or ISR

What is the address (interrupt address vector) of the ISR?

Vectored interrupt

  • Peripheral must provide the address
  • Common when microprocessor has multiple peripherals connected by a system bus

With an interrupt controller 1:21:20

Connections between devices and interrupt controller actually use interrupt lines on the bus rather than dedicated wires

Principles of I/O hardware 1:22:46

Goals of I/O software

Device independence

  • programs can access any I/O device
  • without specifying device in advance
    • (floppy, hard drive, or CD-ROM)

Uniform naming

  • name of a file or device a string or an integer
  • not depending on which machine

Error handling

  • handle as close to the hardware as possible

Synchronous vs. asynchronous transfers.

  • Asynchronous (interrupt-driven): CPU starts, but continues processing until the interruption occurs
    • Easier
    • High-performance applications
  • Synchronous (blocking)

Buffering

  • Decouple data rates

Sharable vs. dedicated devices

There are three fundamentally different ways that I/O can be performed from the software perspective:

  • Programmed I/O (simplest)
  • Interrupt-driven I/O
  • I/O using DMA

Programmed I/O 1:26:26

Interrupt-driven I/O 1:28:43

Interrupts allow CPU to do something else while waiting for the I/O device.

Writing a string to the printer using interrupt-driven I/O.

  1. Code executed at the time the print system call is made.
  2. Interrupt service procedure for the printer

I/O using DMA 1:29:32

An obvious disadvantage of interrupt-driven I/O is that an interrupt occurs on every character.

Interrupts take time, so this scheme wastes a certain amount of CPU time.

DMA controller feed the characters to the printer one at time, without the CPU being bothered.

Printing a string using DMA.

  1. Code executed when the print system call is made.
  2. Interrupt-service procedure.

I/O software layers 1:30:38

I/O software is typically organized in four layers

  1. Interrupt Handlers
  2. Device drivers
  3. Device-independent operating system software
  4. User-level I/O software

Interrupt handlers 1:31:16

Interrupt handlers are best hidden

  • have driver starting an I/O operation block until interrupt notifies of completion

Interrupt procedure does its task

  • then unblocks driver that started it

Steps must be performed in software after interrupt completed

Device drivers 1:33:18

Logical position of device drivers is shown here

Communications between drivers and device controllers goes over the bus

  • Operating systems define a standard interface
  • Different systems handle loading drivers in different ways.
  • A device driver has several functions.
    • Communicate with the device-independent software
    • Initialize the device
    • Manage its power requirements
    • Log events
  • Device driver functionality
    1. A typical driver starts out by checking the input parameters to see if they are valid.
    2. The driver may check if the device is currently in use.
    3. Controlling the device means issuing a sequence of commands to it.
    4. After the commands have been issued, one of two situations will apply.
      1. the device driver must wait until the controller does some work for it
      2. the operation finishes without delay, so the driver need not block
    5. After the operation has been completed, the driver must check for errors
    6. It returns some status information for error reporting back to its caller.
    7. Finally, driver executes the request or waits for the next one

Device-Independent I/O software 1:37:58

Although some of the I/O software is device specific, other parts of it are device independent.

The basic function of the device-independent software is to perform the I/O functions that are common to all devices and to provide a uniform interface to the user-level software.

Functions of the device-independent I/O software

Uniform interfacing 1:38:41

A major issue in an operating system is how to make all I/O devices and drivers look similar.

One aspect of this issue is the interface between the device drivers and the rest of the operating system.

  1. Without a standard driver interface
  2. With a standard driver interface

Uniform interfacing works as follows:

  • Functions: For each class of devices the operating system defines a set of functions that the driver must supply.
  • Naming: The device-independent software takes care of mapping symbolic device names onto the proper driver.
    • For example, in UNIX a device name, such as /dev/disk0
  • Protection: The system administrator can then set the proper permissions for each device.

Buffering 1:42:35

  1. Unbuffered input
  2. Buffering in user space
  3. Buffering in the kernel followed by copying to user space
  4. Double buffering in the kernel

Networking may involve many copies

User-space I/O software 1:46:55

Layers of the I/O system and the main functions of each layer

Look for the rows where all premises hold (grey rows). Then look at the values of the propositions. When all premises hold, only proposition H is always true. Then we can prove that the Unicorn is horned, but not whether it is magical, mortal or a mammal.

This set is inconsistent since the first sentence â€œbirds can flyâ€ is not always true, only most of the time. That is why formal logic is not always a good tool to model common sense reasoning. Extensions of logic allow automated reasoning in the presence of exceptions.

4. For each of the following sentences, answer the following question. How many models for the propositions A, B and C satisfy the sentence? Remember that a model is a True/False assignment for all available propositions

entry.title: Some relevant molecular biology
entry.content:
Some relevant molecular biology

VUB 4018221FNR Algorithms in Computational biology and bioinformatics

Video 56:35 ~ end + Slides

The cell

  • The fundamental unit of life
  • All cells have very similar internal mechanisms
  • Cells reproduce themselves passing along all the necessary information to reproduce all functionality (heredity)
  • Cells are a bit like computers since they have to respond to all kinds of information: food, threats, ...

There are two big classes: Procaryotes and eukaryotes

All information concerning the functional and structural elements of the cell is encoded in the DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)

  • Information from one kind of cells can be treated by other kinds of cells
  • DNA is part of a chromosome

DNA contains information to produce thousands of proteins:

  • A gene is a part of a DNA string that encodes a particular protein
  • The genome is the collection of all DNA molecules

A human has 46 DNA molecules in every cell organised in chromosomes.

In procaryotes, like bacteria, there is often one circular DNA molecule

The structure of DNA and RNA 1:06:00

DNA and RNA are linear structures that consist of 4 types of nucleotides.

A nucleotide is constructed of 3 parts (Fig. A) : a base , a sugar and a phosphate group

The difference between the four types is in the base part, which can be either A,T,G or C.

DNA molecules consist of millions of these nucleotides

The beginning of the DNA is annotated with 5â€™ and the end with 3â€™

a strand = a sequence of nucleotides

DNA consists of two complementary strands

RNA consist of a single strand

These molecules also assume a 3D form, where complementary parts of the RNA strand can interact through hydrogen bonds

The base-pairing is now between: A-U et C-G (Uracil (U) replaces Thymine (T) in RNA !!)

The central dogma of molecular biology 1:18:42

The genes are translated into proteins in two steps

  • step 1 : transcription
    • Parts of the DNA are copied into shorter RNA strands called messenger RNA (mRNA)
  • step 2 : translation
    • The mRNA is translated by the RNA-polymerase into a sequence of amino acids = proteins

DNA replication 1:19:31

During cell division the two DNA strands are separated

Both strands acts as templates on which the complementary strands are formed

RNAs 1:25:38

Messenger RNA (mRNA)

Transfer RNA (tRNA)

Ribosomal RNA (rRNA)

Transcription 1:27:08

mRNA is a strand that is complementary to the noncoding strand of the DNA

The number of mRNA corresponds to the gene expression level in the cell

Translation 1:32:54

Translation from mRNA to proteins

  • uses transfer RNA (tRNA) to perform the translation

the mRNA is read in blocks of 3 nucleic acids (=codon)

  • 43 possibilities = 64 codons
  • BUT only 20 amino acids

The translation is done by the ribosome

  • The ribosome starts at the 5â€™ and moves into the direction of the 3â€™
  • It catches tRNA molecules which can associate with specific codon combinations in the mRNA
  • The amino acids linked to the tRNA, become associated through a peptide bond with the already existing sequence

There is no superposition with the codon

Evolution 1:40:16

The analysis of the different genomes provides information on the evolutionary relationships between the different species

Heredity = transfer of genetic information from the parent to the offspring

When a cell divides, the DNA is copied and divided over the two new cells.

Sometimes this process produces errors (mutations) that can

  • Improve the functionality of the cell = selective advantage
  • Destroy the functionality of the cell = cell dies
  • Does not change the functionality of the cell = selectively neutral

Continuous trial and error allows cells and organisms to evolve

Certain DNA parts are more prone to evolutionary change than others

  • e.g. the non-coding regions in DNA

Yet regions important for proteins function need to be conserved

New genes are build out of old ones in 2 ways

Duplication and divergence 1:45:48

Proteins 1:56:54

The majority of objects inside a cell are proteins

Proteins are

  • the elements that define the structure of a cell
  • The robots that perform almost every function inside the cell

The human genome contains 30000 to 35000 proteins

Structural levels 1:57:19

Primary structure 1:58:16

Like DNA and RNA, proteins are sequences of highly modular building blocks = amino acids

Amino acids 1:59:06

All amino acids (AA) are build out of 3 parts :

  • the central CÎ±
  • nitrogen group
  • sidechain group

The AA are chained together by peptide bonds

Folding 2:01:12

The possible conformations of the main chain (backbone) are limited

The sequence of amino acids folds in the lowest energy conformation

BUT remember the structure is not static, it breathes !

Binding to another protein or molecule may cause structural changes

The folding of a proteins is orchestrated by three types of interactions between the AA

Tertiary structure 2:06:20

The folded 3D structure is the tertiary structure of a protein

Secondary structure 2:06:47

Analyzing the tertiary structure of proteins has resulted in the discovery of some geometric regularities

helices and strands in the structure are produced by hydrogen bonds between the NH and CO groups

Between 50% and 80% of the residues in a protein can be classified in terms of these regular structures

Î± helices and Î² strands 2:07:47

Protein domains 2:10:18

Proteins can also consist of multiple globular

parts = domains

WW domains occur in many different proteins across life 2:11:25

Alignment of WW domains from different proteins 2:13:23
